revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-25 16:07:29.000000000', 'message': "Avoid stuck task_state on snapshot image failure

Fixes bug LP 1101136

Previously if the glance interaction failed prior to an
instance being snapshot'd or backed up, the task state
remained stuck at image_snapshot/backup.

The normal task state reversion logic did not kick in,
as this is limited to the compute layer, whereas the
intial glance interaction occurs within the API layer.

Now, we avoid this problem by delaying setting the task
state until the initial image creation has completed.

Change-Id: Id498ae6b3674306743013e4fe99837da8e2031b5
"}, {'created': '2013-01-28 10:13:42.000000000', 'message': "Avoid stuck task_state on snapshot image failure

Fixes bug LP 1101136

Previously if the glance interaction failed prior to an
instance being snapshot'd or backed up, the task state
remained stuck at image_snapshot/backup.

The normal task state reversion logic did not kick in,
as this is limited to the compute layer, whereas the
intial glance interaction occurs within the API layer.

Now, we avoid this problem by delaying setting the task
state until the initial image creation has completed.

Change-Id: Id498ae6b3674306743013e4fe99837da8e2031b5
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid stuck task_state on snapshot image failure

Fixes bug LP 1101136

Previously if the glance interaction failed prior to an
instance being snapshot'd or backed up, the task state
remained stuck at image_snapshot/backup.

The normal task state reversion logic did not kick in,
as this is limited to the compute layer, whereas the
intial glance interaction occurs within the API layer.

Now, we avoid this problem by delaying setting the task
state until the initial image creation has completed.

Change-Id: Id498ae6b3674306743013e4fe99837da8e2031b5

messages:
[{'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21008/2/check/gate-heat-pep8/1845 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21008/2/check/dev-heat-coverage/696 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-02-01 19:07:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure about this:

- The arbitrary 200s timeout will break all our templates with WaitConditions in them

- We have no real way of knowing what a reasonable timeout will be per-resource (particularly now we support pluggable user-defined resources, we can't have a top-level hard-coded timeout like this IMO, if we must have this, then it has to be configurable per resource before we merge it)

- There is an existing stack_create timeout mechanism, whereby a user (who is in a position to know what a reasonable timeout number is) may pass a timeout in at stack creation time (via the TimeoutInMinutes parameter to the CreateStack API call).  Since any per-resource timeout will result in the entire stack creation failing anyway, IMO it makes sense to just implement this parameter and treat the timeout on a per-stack basis rather than per-resource.

- The delete timeout I can agree with a bit more, but personally I'd rather fix the resources - e.g do we really need to be doing while True loops in the instance resource, or can it be modified to e.g use nova notifications to tell us when an operation has been completed?  Not sure on the status of this, but e.g:

http://wiki.openstack.org/ResourceMonitorAlertsandNotifications"}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-02-03 22:56:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree, with SteveH here:

Note: we do have a stack wide timeout that is implemented.
it is just really big by default (parser.py:230).

The other thing is hopefully really soon we will implement
parallel resource startup and so each resource will have
longer to start."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-11 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-11 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Put timer on create/delete operation

If create or delete never finishes on a resource, heat could
block indefinately with no way to recover the failure.

This patch introduces a timeout period after which a failure is returned.
After the failure is returned, the stack can be deleted.

The timeout period that expired is listed within the event-list operation.

Fixes: Bug #1072948

Change-Id: I2e0d60f15d426d1b0da1a92454ad1526b7c658aa

[{'created': '2013-01-13 22:38:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add oslo version handling.

Produce versions off of tags, which avoids the need to have a post-release
commit changing the version number. Also, make use of parse_requirements
since the code is in the tree now.

Change-Id: Id14ca6567e896cc9b413606d1089c912693025a2
'}, {'created': '2013-02-03 01:36:29.000000000', 'message': "Add oslo version handling.

Produce versions off of tags, which avoids the need to have a post-release
commit changing the version number. Also, make use of parse_requirements
since the code is in the tree now.

The results of this are that versioned releases can now be driven purely from
git tags without the need for special version-bump commits.

Since this introduces the oslo code-copying that wasn't previously in use in
swift, it's worth pointing out that the goal is to get oslo-version and
oslo-setup turned in to proper libraries. There are some circular dependency
problems inside of setuptools that prevent this at the moment, which means
the actual solution is a patch to distribute itself... which we're working on.
But since that patch is unlikely to land in this cycle, we're sticking with
the oslo update.sh copying tool until we can get the code where it needs to be
upstream.

Change-Id: Id14ca6567e896cc9b413606d1089c912693025a2
"}]
commit_message:
Add oslo version handling.

Produce versions off of tags, which avoids the need to have a post-release
commit changing the version number. Also, make use of parse_requirements
since the code is in the tree now.

The results of this are that versioned releases can now be driven purely from
git tags without the need for special version-bump commits.

Since this introduces the oslo code-copying that wasn't previously in use in
swift, it's worth pointing out that the goal is to get oslo-version and
oslo-setup turned in to proper libraries. There are some circular dependency
problems inside of setuptools that prevent this at the moment, which means
the actual solution is a patch to distribute itself... which we're working on.
But since that patch is unlikely to land in this cycle, we're sticking with
the oslo update.sh copying tool until we can get the code where it needs to be
upstream.

Change-Id: Id14ca6567e896cc9b413606d1089c912693025a2

commit_message:
Parse testr output through subunit2pyunit.

When running through run_tests.sh, filter the testr output through
subunit2pyunit so that incremental progress can be seen. Should be
a step towards folks seeing incremental test progress.

Change-Id: Ic90669acabaa1c8b64aae80349bff3d3deaf59fa

commit_message:
Move initial root contents into a hook.

This is a necessary but not complete step towards supporting Fedora and Suse
distributions. Further work is needed (e.g. to quiesce daemons on
installation).

Change-Id: If3ea6093d41a21de755db52328226b84b5a3ede6

commit_message:
Remove sendfile as a dependency.

This is dead code anyway, since heat-cfn doesn't handle large binary files like glance.

Fixes bug 1087530

Change-Id: Iaba7adce088b20136ece0828d4085679fcbab731

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-08 11:42:47.000000000', 'message': 'heat clients : Make boto client select http/https from configfile

Currently we hardcode is_secure=False, but boto supports configuration
of this option from the config file (either ~/.boto or /etc/boto.cfg)
so better to do that

NOTE - you will need to update your boto config to include is_secure=0
to retain current (non https) behavior, since it defaults to on

ref bug 1117594

Change-Id: Ic13e8604f12d3d5be4ec132a1bc04ae7624ec85d
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat clients : Make boto client select http/https from configfile

Currently we hardcode is_secure=False, but boto supports configuration
of this option from the config file (either ~/.boto or /etc/boto.cfg)
so better to do that

NOTE - you will need to update your boto config to include is_secure=0
to retain current (non https) behavior, since it defaults to on

ref bug 1117594

Change-Id: Ic13e8604f12d3d5be4ec132a1bc04ae7624ec85d
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Implement simple AccessPolicy Resource

Implement a simple AccessPolicy resource, which can be used
to restrict in-instance users to specific resources when they
call the DescribeStackResource API action

Fixes bug 1115758

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Idc98531388e535ce16308fd5aab5ceecda1de682

commit_message:
Allow running test in uninstalled source tree.

It was pointed out that we missed the use-case that running tests
in a fresh tree checkout should work - and we missed that by
reaching too far into the setup module interface. Shame on us.

Change-Id: Ic0056a3113b308f063d927484e1e4a44c9316a2d

LocalhostMatchmaker will use whatever

MatchMakerLocalhost and LocalhostExchange

impl_zmq._get_matchmaker now passes arguments to

Change-Id: I8daa2c0668f1d717eb95ab56009612b8b60f0a15
"}, {'created': '2013-02-10 14:45:00.000000000', 'message': "Support testing args for LocalhostMatchMaker.

MatchMakerLocalhost and LocalhostExchange

Change-Id: I8daa2c0668f1d717eb95ab56009612b8b60f0a15
"}]
commit_message:
Support testing args for LocalhostMatchMaker.

The matchmaker should return the correct
direct topics used by the RPC driver. The
LocalhostMatchMaker was always returning
'localhost', even though our tests might
use '127.0.0.1' instead. Now, the
LocalhostMatchmaker will use whatever
value it is told should be considered local.

MatchMakerLocalhost and LocalhostExchange
now take an optional host parameter.

impl_zmq._get_matchmaker now passes arguments to
the selected matchmaker module.

The test_zmq now initializes the matchmaker, using
the host '127.0.0.1'

Change-Id: I8daa2c0668f1d717eb95ab56009612b8b60f0a15

people using templates with IAM resources."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-02-08 02:14:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
heat templates : Remove IAM Policy sections

Some templates have Policies specified for the User
resource in the AWS IAM Policy format, which we do
not yet support, and will confuse users now we have
OS::Heat::AccessPolicy implemented

ref bug 1115758

Change-Id: I6958b02fe6518ea43729ebc18818524ae7e4921e
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Can we please add an example of how to use this?'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-02-07 12:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-07 12:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21329/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/925 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21329/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/925 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-02-07 20:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This looks good, but I agree an example would be helpful. Do we write tests for test code? :-)'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-08 19:17:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Agree, some docstring on usage would be appreciated.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-09 18:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with dims, doug and eric ... the docs are lame ("Deal with code around mock") and the usage is non-obvious

The pattern in quantum is:

  with mock.patch.object(db, 'register_models') as mock_register:
      mock_register.return_value = False
      db.configure_db()

and we'd replace that with:

  self.mock = self.useFixture(mockpatch.PatchObject(db, 'register_models')).mock
  self.mock.return_value = False
  db.configure_db()

I'm not entirely clear why this is a win - what are we trying to solve here? The code indentation that results from using a context manager?

Definitely need more docs with usage examples, some tests and some verbiage on why this is actually useful'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-02-09 21:58:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Fair- I'll write more docs.

See this:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21428/

For a better example of usage. More boilerplate gets added when we add addCleanup calls.

This isn't about replacing context manager with blocks - it's about replacing long-lived mocks that are created in setUp calls.

But you're right - clearly that's not obvious from the patch (I forget that the fixtures library and the patterns from it have not become pervasive everywhere yet.)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-09 22:19:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ah, ok - that clears it up for me. It definitely improves the quantum test code and they're pretty straightforward to use if you look at those examples.

I'm fine with docs and tests for this being added later"}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-02-11 02:22:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

+1 to docs and tests for this being added later'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-11 02:23:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-11 02:29:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

- http://logs.openstack.org/21329/2/gate/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/784 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21329/2/gate/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/969 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-11 02:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

Quantum uses a pattern all over their test base, which can be
collapsed down into a simple re-usable fixture.

commit_message:
Create tools/install_prereqs.sh

* Factor system package prereq installs out to tools/install_prereqs.sh
* Set minimum time between runs with PREREQ_RERUN_HOURS
  default = 2 hours
* Create export_proxy_variables
* Force an update with install_prereqs.sh -f or by setting
  FORCE_PREREQ=true

Fixed an issue with exit/return in tools/install_prereqs.sh

Change-Id: I9a62090ad2f900b9b150cacb9cb02b326cb46972

commit_message:
Improvements to API validation logic.

Do not automatically map generic exceptions like AttributeError to
http errors (instead they should be handled closer to where they occur
so that they can be "intelligently" converted to the appropriate
error).

Fix up some expected error codes in the unit tests.
Improve some of the validation messages.
Remove all use of locals() in attributes.py

Fixes: bug #1076813
Change-Id: Iabf8808a840e927307bbcae4cd41790af3d79a9e

commit_message:
xenapi: Cleanup detach_volume code

Refactors `detach_volume` so that it uses the same code to detach that
detaching all volumes uses.

Change-Id: Idb7acb136367d8ad512d4b14c775c69404f6f6b0

commit_message:
Allow connecting to self-signed quantum endpoints

Introduce a new option 'quantum_api_insecure', matching the existing
'glance_api_insecure'. It skips the SSL validation in quantumclient.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I275517179929710bedcef5086a040b9396c0e932

commit_message:
Flavor Extra Specs should require admin privileges

The previous fix added admin check in policy.json,
but code still can't recorginize the detailed actions.

This fix edited "authorize" function for flavor_extra_specs,
to make sure it will check the admin privileges in policy.json.

Also, together with the code, this fix edit old test case with admin privileges,
and added new non-admin privileges test case.

Fixes bug 1094142

Change-Id: Ia286aedb4846383ad51bd54b0984dd1feddfbf81

"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-05 00:51:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It's really unclear to me that we want this as an external plug point with a contract. I think the general approach is to not do that unless the team is really confident in the extension point.

I don't think libvirt internal filter layer counts as that. If there is another filter type you'd like included in upstream, please submit that."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-06 12:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Sean,

Not really sure that I follow your comment - Ed did post the description of this initially to openstack.dev and got approval from Vish for the approach.  

Given that the use case here is to filter traffic from specific instances (for example to allow only certain instances access to a license key server) its hard to see where else in the code you could do this. 

Any such filters are likely to be quite service provider specific, so hard to see the filters themselves being a good candidate for the core product.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-06 12:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think think this is the right way to go about this. If the config parameter was merely a list of libvirt nwfilter names, then I can see the value in the new config parameter.

This proposed config parameter though, requires the user to create new python classes.  This is just inventing a 2nd way to do something that is already possible. If people are going to be required to write code to create custom filters, then they can just use the existing "firewall_driver" config parameter to plug in their custom code. So I don't really see any need for this new config parameter.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-06 13:40:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

What would help people wishing to subclass is to re-factor the existing libvirt firewall.py driver a little bit. eg move the list of default separate (easily custommizable) method

  def get_base_filter_list(instance):
        if pipelib.is_vpn_image(instance['image_ref']):
            base_filter = 'nova-vpn'
        elif allow_dhcp:
            base_filter = 'nova-base'
        else:
            base_filter = 'nova-nodhcp'
        return [base_filter]

Then people only need subclass the driver, this is base class & then add in their own extra filters"}, {'account_id': 5209, 'date': '2013-02-07 17:03:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-07 17:16:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for changing this - I think this approach is much nicer.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-07 18:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-22 18:14:41.000000000', 'message': 'Change to support custom nw filters.

This change adds a mechanism to provide additional nw filters per
instance which can be dynamically added using nova.conf.  Each
custom filter must provide three functions:
get_filter() returns the xml definition of the nw filter
get_filter_name() returns the string name of the filter
apply_filter(instance) returns true/false indicating whether the
    filter should be applied to the given instance

The implementation of the custom filters can be defined as needed
as long as the three above required functions are provided.

The filters can then be added by specifying them in a list using
nova.conf.  For example...

custom_nwfilters = nova.virt.libvirt.my_filter1

Change-Id: Ida94148fcb870830ae675839ab4f900ad798d9bb
Fixes: bug #1103086
'}, {'created': '2013-01-24 22:30:07.000000000', 'message': 'Change to support custom nw filters.

instance which can be dynamically added using nova.conf.  Each
custom filter must provide three functions:

apply_filter(instance) returns true/false indicating whether the
    filter should be applied to the given instance

The implementation of the custom filters can be defined as needed
as long as the three above required functions are provided.

The filters can then be added by specifying them in a list using
nova.conf.  For example...

custom_nwfilters = nova.virt.libvirt.my_filter1

Also added test_custom_nwfilter to test_libvirt.py to
exercise this functionality and to provide an example of
its usage.

commit_message:
Change to support custom nw filters.

This change is a refactoring of NWFilterFirewall to
create a distinct function to define base nw filters.
The new function is called get_base_filter_list.  This
provides a convenient way to subclass NWFilterFirewall
and redefine get_base_filter_list to add your own custom
base filters.

Change-Id: Ida94148fcb870830ae675839ab4f900ad798d9bb
Fixes: bug #1103086

commit_message:
Convert to use tempest attr implementation 2/2

Convert from nose attr decorator to use the tempest attr
decorator which calls both the nose and testtools attr
implementations.

Tests marked as smoke will be renamed when running under both
nosetests and testr but otherwise there is is no visible change. Eg.

tempest.tests.identity.admin.test_users.UsersTestXML.test_create_user

looks like:

tempest.tests.identity.admin.test_users.UsersTestXML.test_create_user[smoke]

Patch is broken into two completely separate parts to make it
easier to avoid merge conflicts with other changesets.
They do not need to be applied atomically and are not in any way dependent
on each other.

Change-Id: I0dbae905c1a2499f2b58a4ed062289dc27a48ef4

commit_message:
Remove setuptools_git from setup_requires.

Having it in setup_requires is actually wrong for the case where setup
is run from a tarball. Having it in tox.ini ensures it's clear it's a need
of automation, not actually of other things.

Change-Id: Ie236556b7608831ff880df0a77ecba187055d889

Comments on patch set 3 have not been addressed."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

With security groups being added to Quantum we have duplicate functionality between Quantum & Nova. We need to pass some kind of information back to Nova to inform it that Quantum has applied security groups, so that Nova VIF filters can then intelligently skip their own security group setup.

Currently Quantum provides the 'vif_type' info to Nova. My recommendation is that we extend this to also provide a boolean "has_security_group=0|1" flag. eg in quantum/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_quantum_plugin.py

    def _extend_port_dict_binding(self, context, port):
        if self._check_view_auth(context, port, self.binding_view):
            port[portbindings.VIF_TYPE] = portbindings.VIF_TYPE_OVS
            port[portbindings.HAS_SECURITY_GROUP] = ...setting...
        return port'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It surely isn't that hard to include the functionality in this initial patch. We're only talking adding a single key to a dict we're already passing back to Nova."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This patch includes minor refactoring based on experience from supporting OVS version.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

I tested the code and it works almost well (except below).

Non-functional question: when port-id is 0df71299-0086-45b8-954b-3e057e17dcd8, chain name is quantum-openvswi-i71299-0086. First 3 chars are stripped. In LB secgroup, a prefix of port-id is used. It would be better to apply the same rule. It makes it easy to debug I believe.

When testing I did the following two changes
- Disable Nova libvirt nwfilter to comment out
  designer.set_vif_host_backend_filter_config LibvirtBridgeDriver.get_config()
  (it is Nova/Quantum limitation at the moment and the other 
- Set firewall_driver to Hybrid driver in ovs plugin config (default value is NoopDriver now)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

During tests, I found the following bug:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/29721/

I am not sure it is specific to OVS implementation, perhaps no. When multiple security groups are associated with a port, security group membership management does not seem to work."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (3 inline comments)

Now we have no dependency on other patches and can go.

Nova side patch of improving vif pluging has been merged, so iptables OVS security group implementation now works without adhoc modification in nova.

I wrote what configurations are required in nova and quantum conf on Launchpad BP whiteboard.

To make OVS secgroup work with LibvirtGenericVIFDriver, 
https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1112912 needs to be addressed, but it is not a blocker of the patch.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Patch set 19 just addressed my comments on patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

You need to add the OVS plugin to the security group schema migration.  You only need to add the OVS plugin here:
https://github.com/openstack/quantum/blob/master/quantum/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/3cb5d900c5de_security_groups.py#L32"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

big concern is:
why don't we implement it via open flow?
 I remember we introduce the LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver on nova side because we cannot support the nova's SG feature by pure ovs bridge. Since we are implement the SG features here, why do we still use it?"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: (1 inline comment)

In my mind, LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver on nova side is a temporary method for quantum to work with nova's SG and anti-spoofing feature.
Our first implementation should be able to remove that dirver, and make that driver deprecated. Deployment depends on both Linux bridge and OVS bridge has performance cost, also make system failure-prone due to more components.

But I am ok too with implementing it later."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

just one minor comment'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-10 07:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Implements quantum security groups support on OVS plugin

implements bp quantum-security-groups-iptables-ovs
- Adding [SECURITYGROUP] firewall_driver to the conf
- Adding NoopFirewallDriver
- Adding OVSHybridIptablesFirewallDriver
- Refactoring security group code to support OVS plugin

Change-Id: I7aabc296265afc47d938121543ace57cce6cc521

subject: generate ChangeLog with openstack.common.setup
messages:
[{'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-01-18 13:47:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

All the other openstack components contain a ChangeLog file in the tarballs on tarballs.openstack.org with the same git format. This would make swift adopt the same format and make it much easier for distributors to figure out what has changed between versions since we could apply the same method as for the other projects.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-18 14:06:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/1/check/gate-swift-docs/1203 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/1346 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/1/check/gate-swift-python26/1451 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/1/check/gate-swift-python27/1453 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/27349 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/1599 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-01-21 23:43:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

While I like the idea behind an auto-generated changelog, it only works if you can strictly control all of the commit messages. And that only seems to work if there is only one dev on the project.

CHANGELOG files are the way to communicate to users the important changes in a release. This file needs to be hand-curated so that the important information from commit messages and docs is included and the unimportant information is not included. The full history is still available, if needed, in the VCS logs.

I do not want to see us lose our handcrafted CHANGELOG file."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-22 00:08:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

+1 to the -1, in that I also like lovingly handcrafted change logs.

To me, change log = documentation of changes for users of your project and commit messages = that and documentation of changes for other coders on your project.

This makes a 26,143 line ChangeLog not grouped at all and full of useless information like Merge this and Merge that and lists of changed files you could easily get from a git log yourself if you need it, instead of the nice 566 line CHANGELOG that has the changes listed in easy to read format grouped by version.

That, and my usual complaints against copied openstack.common code."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-01-22 07:33:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Not to dogpile too much, but I prefer the hand-crafted Changelog as well.  The git history itself should suffice if one wants excruciating detail of each commit."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-01-22 08:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As packagers, we generate our own .changes file and that's what users see. Especially for development versions, we build a lot more packages in between the released versions of swift. We currently have infrastructure scripts to generate our .changes file from the ChangeLog (from tarballs.openstack.org) in all the other openstack packages.

Keeping this information only in git makes it a lot harder for us, because we can't include git repositories in our tarballs so we would have to clone the git repository in a different place than we do our builds and get the info from there. Also, this would only be required for swift.

So how about instead of "losing" the handcrafted CHANGELOG file we rename it to NEWS which is quite common in other open source projects as well for this type of information. I'm actually fine with leaving it like it is (named CHANGELOG), BUT adding the git-log generated ChangeLog file, too.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-24 11:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I +1 the idea of renaming the current ChangeLog as NEWS and have ChangeLog have all the vcs change logs, seems common among most OpenSource projects (or at least the GNU ones).'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-01-30 13:08:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-30 13:41:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/2/check/gate-swift-docs/1281 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/2/check/gate-swift-pep8/1424 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/2/check/gate-swift-python26/1528 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/2/check/gate-swift-python27/1531 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/29025 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/3683 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-30 14:48:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Shouldn't NEWS be in MANIFEST.in?

And I still find copied code distasteful (yes, I realize this isn't your fault). But at least it's less now."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-01-30 14:54:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/3/check/gate-swift-docs/1282 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/3/check/gate-swift-pep8/1425 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/3/check/gate-swift-python26/1529 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/3/check/gate-swift-python27/1532 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/29045 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20024/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/3713 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:33:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Cool, everything seems fine to me except the copied openstack.common code. I do realize you've minimized this as best you can and I appreciate that.

I'm going to stay at no score because I'm torn. I hate copied code for no good reason, but the only alternative I see at this moment is depending on all of https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator which is completely insane. It's been years now that this copy-code thing was going to be fixed..."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-01-31 21:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So you are generating a .changes file, based on the VCS logs, for your packaging. But since you don't have the VCS data when you are building a tarball, you want to duplicate the entire project history in a text file that is updated with every build?

What do you do with other projects (ie not OpenStack projects)? Is this something that is common to all distros (ie how does it help RHEL/CentOS, Ubuntu, etc)?

Also, note that there are references in previous release announcements to the CHANGELOG file and those will be broken now. That may or may not be a big deal."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-31 22:55:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not a fan of the git generated changelog (I just ran it from nova to see what they look like), nor am I a fan of having to bring in the common stuff just for that.  Is there a specific problem we are trying to solve here, other than "Make it like Nova?"'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-01 02:27:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

After thinking about this more this morning, I do not think this should be included in swift.

Code to manage a file for distros where that file isn't even in the source tree should not be included in swift."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-02-02 13:47:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Chuck: This isn't about "making it like nova", AFAICS all the other openstack projects use the same convention. Right now, we have to use a different build process ONLY for swift.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-10 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-10 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
generate ChangeLog with openstack.common.setup

only the required functions from openstack.common.setup are used in
order to keep the sphinx documentation and AUTHORS file unchanged

move the old CHANGELOG to NEWS

Change-Id: Ic60447c509b11a057e83b8fa91aa689a8e8a88c5

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-20 10:47:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/18469/1/check/gate-nova-docs/10167 : SUCCESS

"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-12-20 16:22:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

please run unit tests before submit.

Also, don't include the blueprint url in the commit message, just do:

blueprint attach-cdrom-when-run-system

It will link automatically."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-20 16:34:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Nice work on this patch. I've added Nikola as he is working on the block device patch:

 https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/improve-block-device-handling

I think we need to rework the way block device mapping is handled. Basically in the api layer we want to be passing down the image id for the root drive as well so that all of the devices are passed in. This is part of the cleanup in the above blueprint, so it is important that you guys collaborate on this. I think this patch needs a couple of changes.

1) since image_id can be used for the root device as well, we need a way to describe where the block device should be attached (ide vs. virtio for example). We could overload virtual_name for this, but it might be better to have another field.

2) we need to consider the case where we would like to boot off of the cdrom. I'm not quite sure the best way to implement this, but perhaps we need a new flag in the bdm describing which device is the boot device. Note that this isn't.

I also think that this patch needs a few features to secure it.

a) image id probably shouldn't be limited to iso. This is a user editable property in glance so I'm not sure it does anything anyway.

b) we need a maximum size on the image so users aren't abusing free drives.

c) we need a maximum number of attached cd-roms as well. I'm thinking 1 is plenty."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-20 16:34:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-12-20 18:17:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

To expand on what Vish is saying - what we are trying to do here is in fact: make it possible to attach an image as a device (as vish pointed out there is no reason you would not be able to do this with any other format other that iso). Currently nova does this for you when you boot from an image but it is not possible to do it for another device. 

My feeling is that we should keep inner workings of nova as generic as possible to avoid the situation that we have today (and are trying to clean up) that we have driver code dealing with ephemeral devices and cdroms and whatnot. The user-facing (API) part on the other hand is where we should build  convenient options like 'attach a CD'.

My proposal would be to split this patch into 'attach images as devices to instances' that will contain a more generalized code that does not assume anything (and is possibly defensive as per Vish's advice, most of the work is done on this anyway) and then with this functionality, we should massage how bdm's are handled in the API layer into an interface that is acceptable keeping in mind that we want to have all our devices (and root too) in block_device_mapping from now on. (of course if you need more info on this - ping me or post on the dev mailing list.)

Also a few small nits inline."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-12-21 11:20:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Some additional comments about the tests.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-21 11:24:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2012-12-30 14:02:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-30 14:02:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. I uploaded new patch 29, please see my reply for the comments in patch 28.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-23 13:15:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have been thinking about how this interacts with the block device mapping code, and can't help coming to the conclusion that this design is flawed, and will negatively impact on our ability todo future work in this area without having backwards compatibility pains.

The current way to boot nova instances with a block device mapping is

  --block-device-mapping /dev/vdf=404d2b8e-a174-4d4c-9bfb-6091dc480a01:::0

This causes the guest to have a disk device /dev/vdf backed by the cinder volume 404d2b8e-a174-4d4c-9bfb-6091dc480a01.

What if I wanted the guest to have a CDROM device backed by the cinder volume instead ? There's no way to express this in Nova currently.
What if I don't care about device name & just want Nova to auto-allocate one ? There's no way to express this in Nova curently.


It is already possible to get Nova to configure a CDROM device for the primary root image of a VM, by setting the 'format' property against the image to 'iso'. This is already flawed because Nova is associating the type of device with the filesystem format of the image. It is perfectly acceptable to have a CDROM device with an ext4 filesystem, or a plain disk with a iso filesystem. There's no way to express this in Nova currently.

Now on to your proposal

  --block_device_mapping cdrom1=a650060c-09f9-44b4-9eec-196d36a3b7ea:optical mytest-1

This causes the guest to have an extra cdrom device (user can't choose name) backed by a glance image a650060c-09f9-44b4-9eec-196d36a3b7ea. This magic is done by looking for the 'optical' flag in the block device mapping. There are a number of flaws with this syntax IMHO

 - It is silently changing the meaning of the UUID to refer to a glance image, instead of cinder volume, which has huge scope for confusing users
 - The user is forced to accept auto allocation of device name - they have no way to control what device name is used, unlike when using cinder volumes

Your additions to the block device mapping have pretty much completely different semanticsf to the block device mapping data. I think this is a serious design flaw.

Looking at the bigger picture, what this clearly says is that nova disk image configuration is not sufficiently flexible. For *any* disk, we need to be able to

 - Choose between different types of guest device -  harddisk, cdrom, or floppy, mmc (flash)
 - Choose between either glance image or cinder volume
 - Choose a disk name, or let Nova auto-allocate

These three variables should be completely independent of each other.

I think we need a clear design on how to achieve this in general, not merely hack up something which is only going to work in one limited use case, and will cause problems for our more general solution. As such I don't think this changeset is suitable to consider merging."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-01-23 13:22:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

David,

I agree with Dan on this. and we had discussed and agreed on a similar design to what he describes, on the upstream list.

I am currently working on a patch to rework block_device_mapping related to blueprint Improve Block Device Handling targeted for grizzly-3, however I could put up a WIP at this point if it might help us push this along, if you think this could be something that you would be willing to consider).

Cheers,

Nikola'}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-01-23 13:52:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

ndipanov, 

Please provide me more detail info about your patch, and what's your consideration on CDROM device support in your blueprint."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-23 17:43:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

Daniel,

I mostly agree with your comments. IMO the disk name is really about choosing an ordering, since the name in the guest is arbitrary. The name is really a holdover from when nova was trying to mimic ec2. I guess auto-allocate would mean just use the ordering of the block device mapping passed in. We have to keep compatibility in mind. Ultimately it seems like we need to have guest_type, src_type, target_type It sounds like we have a few separate patches:

1. allow users to specify guest_type in bdm
(aligned withChoose between different types of guest device -  harddisk, cdrom, or floppy, mmc (flash))
The first version of this should probably just be hd + cdrom. This would allow us to attach volumes as cdroms but not images.

2. allow users to specify images as src_type in addition to volume and snapshot
(aligned with Choose between either glance image or cinder volume)
This could be done by adding image_id to the table and allowing one of image_id, snapshot_id, volume_id to be passed in. Honestly it seems like it would be better the code to accept (id, type) instead of exposing three fields externally, but that is probably an incompatible api change. It should be possible to specify the image_id of the root disk using this syntax as well.

There are two concerns here:
a) exposing the additional functionality via the api (requires a new extension)
b) we need to be careful about users using too much space. Rather than force a maximum size, we should probably just subtract the size of any images that are in bdm from the flavor ephemeral size (first) and the root disk size (second) so that they get the same total space no matter how many images they use

4. allow users to specify src_type = blank
(not mentioned)
Users should be able to create ephemeral disks using bdms as well.

5. allow users to change the size of local storage options (optional)
(not mentioned)
Right now we resize the disks based on a flavor. Why not allow them to specify the size of the target. for example if you had a flavor that was 20 Gb root and 100 Gb local, you could specify a 50 gb root drive a 50 gb ephemeral drive and attach 20 gb cd rom

5. allow users to specify target_type (optional)
(not mentioned)
src_type tells us where the disk bits come from. Currently we do some magic to determine where the  bits will live while the guest is active.
volume -> self
snapshot -> new volume
image -> local
blank -> local
We could continue to have a magic mapping like this or we could expose to the user the ability to specify where the bits should be. This involves nova having more conversion options, but it could be valuable to specify if it isn't too complex.

6 Nova autoallocates disk names
 (aligned with Choose a disk name, or let Nova auto-allocate)
nova can already autoallocate on attach so we can use the same idea to pick disk names if they are not specified. I think it makes sense to continue to use the same syntax as much as possible /dev/vdx for example. I think the problem here is that cdroms are attached on a different bus than the other disks which leads to confusion. I'm not super opposed to using something like cdrom0-1-2 here but we should discuss a if there is something better.

So as far as I can tell this patch should be split. I think 2-5 should be covered by ndipainov's blueprint and this patch should only allow attaching volumes and snapshots (current functionality) as cd-roms in addition to hard disk. We also need a competent plan for 6 but I think if we minimize this patch to 1 and discuss 6 further we can come up with something reasonable."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-01-24 05:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

Vish,

This should be my lesson learn, the design is complained after I deliver 29 patches.
So I want to confirm that again to make sure we are all on the same page.
For this patch, I just focus on CDROM support.
And I need do the following changes:
1. Add new "guest_type" to indicate the device type. In my scenario, it should be "cdrom".
2. Attach volume instead image.

If I miss anything, please correct me.

Daniel, do you have any comments about this?'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-24 12:31:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

As mentioned on the mailing list, I would like to see a detailed design for how the block device mapping will be changed, with example 'nova boot' usage for all the scenarios we need to consider. IMHO one of the biggest problem with review of this patch series has been the non-existant design details in the blueprint."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-01-24 12:53:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

Hi David,

I would ask you to look at my patches (especially interface changes) I posted on the mailing list - if you missed it here they are:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20339/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20338/

and also look at Vish's comments on one of them.

After our discussions on the dev list I was under the impression that we had an understanding of the approach we should take E.g. we should be reworking how block devices are done to make it as general as possible.

The reason behind it is that they are in a less than ideal shape right now (they do not have any validations, device names are not used consistently to name only a few issues). This is the reason why people were a bit reserved about your patches (at least that is my feeling) - because you are trying to bolt on functionality on top of existing code that people feel is broken and needs to be fixed first. 

Daniel even openly questioned the approach in one of the recent comments.

Since I am assigned to the improve-block-device-mapping blueprint, if you have any questions about my patches - feel free to send me an email directly or on the list or ping me on freenode. Maybe you could base your work on the code I did, or even come up with something better.

Whatever we agree on - I think the general feeling is - Block Device Mapping needs to be fixed before a feature like CDs can go in.

I am sorry if this was not clear enough."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-01-24 15:19:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

ndipanov,

That's fine, don't worry about that, I am just thinking you guys would better give me the feedback as early as possible. After all this change were already take a long time.
Anyway, I will give u my comments on your patches if I have. Let's keep in touch to improve the bdm function."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-01 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

commit_message:
Add support for attach CD-ROM when run new VM

Extend block_device_mapping to support attach CD-ROM device with an
image.
Here is an example for how to use this enhancement:
nova boot --image $(glance index | grep RHEL6.3 | awk '{print $1}')
--flavor 1 --block_device_mapping
cdrom1=a650060c-09f9-44b4-9eec-196d36a3b7ea:optical mytest-1

blueprint attach-cdrom-when-run-system

DocImpact
Add new attribute in nova.conf to limit the image size that can be
attached and new type of block device mapping when boot new vm.

Change-Id: I6d0627c172ebe848314747195f69df4cf4b417ce

commit_message:
Change Nova client to support the attach CD-ROM when run new VM

Support extend the block_device_mapping to attach CD-ROM device with an
image, the nova boot command line will like this:
nova boot --image $(glance index | grep RHEL6.3 | awk '{print $1}')
--flavor 1 --block_device_mapping
cdrom1=a650060c-09f9-44b4-9eec-196d36a3b7ea:optical mytest-1

 * cdrom1: the cdrom device name
 * image id: the image id
 * optical: device type, if it is 'optical', we will attach a CD-ROM

blueprint attach-cdrom-when-run-system

DocImpact

This commit depends on the final design on
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18469/

Change-Id: Ibd97a8034bea17db695bd561e364e065a73ca733

commit_message:
Add support for network adapter hotplug.

    This patch makes it possible to add/del instance
    interface other than booting time.
    Implement bp:network-adapter-hotplug

Change-Id: Ibee003a9ec6cc9b3fd275417caccd0c67f6c871f

commit_message:
Timezones can change - display the current tz offset

As noted in the reviews for the backport (20467), the initial patch
for bug 1103003 didn't account for timezones changing over time.

Change-Id: Iceab7deb803669c56aa21252561f650f8c4a601d

A crude way to reproduce the problem and verify a fix is to comment out the "permissions" line in openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/containers/panel.py to enable the     second panel group.

commit_message:
Fixing sidebar layout in IE.

This problem is only reproducible when more than one panel group is
present in a dashboard (e.g., when Object Store is enabled in the
Project dashboard).  A crude way to reproduce the problem and verify
a fix is to comment out the "permissions" line in
openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/containers/panel.py to enable
the second panel group.

The fix required was to remove an unnecessary float:left in
horizon.less that caused problems in IE's layout engine.  The
float:left had no effect on layout in Chrome, Firefox or
Safari(Windows version) in or out.

Fixes: bug #1078735
Change-Id: Idb0f8673d68ba686e1d7440fd2396e9a29b024ef

commit_message:
management_url not set by authenticate method

Fixes Bug 1109243.
If management_url not set, raise UnAuthorized exception,
otherwise url chaining methods fail and cause NoneType
exceptions.

Change-Id: I19e87a5dcfcf93b4fa1d423bd99de352679fa16d

commit_message:
Change the first letter of routers tab header and html title from
lowercase to uppercase.

Routers tab header and html title of both routers index page and
create page missing the first uppercase letter, so it needs to be
changed into uppercase to keep with consistency other tabs.

Change-Id: I83b33e061f2b1aae33e255def854cc1b0c44371e
Fixes: bug #1112589

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-08 16:31:44.000000000', 'message': 'Handle nested xtrace states (Quantum edition)

The lib/quantum_* directories include plugin files that also
contains the $XTRACE bits at entry and exit.  The nested XTRACE handling overwrote
the value from lib/quantum.  So...make the nested files use their own
XTRACE variables.

Change-Id: Ib5e643371666b21402eef2ec58bfb1dfb7e1ccc4
'}]
commit_message:
Handle nested xtrace states (Quantum edition)

The lib/quantum_* directories include plugin files that also
contains the $XTRACE bits at entry and exit.  The nested XTRACE handling overwrote
the value from lib/quantum.  So...make the nested files use their own
XTRACE variables.

Change-Id: Ib5e643371666b21402eef2ec58bfb1dfb7e1ccc4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-09 11:51:04.000000000', 'message': 'Convert to use tempest attr implementation 1/2

Convert from nose attr decorator to use the tempest attr
decorator which calls both the nose and testtools attr
implementations.

Tests marked as smoke will be renamed when running under both
nosetests and testr but otherwise there is is no visible change. Eg.

tempest.tests.identity.admin.test_users.UsersTestXML.test_create_user

looks like:

tempest.tests.identity.admin.test_users.UsersTestXML.test_create_user[smoke]

Patch is broken into two completely separate parts to make it
easier to avoid merge conflicts with other changesets.
They do not need to be applied atomically and are not in any way dependent
on each other.

Change-Id: I310fced910820bacab07b6936f8b0a0a2a7990fa
'}]
commit_message:
Convert to use tempest attr implementation 1/2

Convert from nose attr decorator to use the tempest attr
decorator which calls both the nose and testtools attr
implementations.

Tests marked as smoke will be renamed when running under both
nosetests and testr but otherwise there is is no visible change. Eg.

tempest.tests.identity.admin.test_users.UsersTestXML.test_create_user

looks like:

tempest.tests.identity.admin.test_users.UsersTestXML.test_create_user[smoke]

Patch is broken into two completely separate parts to make it
easier to avoid merge conflicts with other changesets.
They do not need to be applied atomically and are not in any way dependent
on each other.

Change-Id: I310fced910820bacab07b6936f8b0a0a2a7990fa

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-07 18:45:20.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce support for 802.1qbg and 802.1qbh to Nova VIF model

Define the nova network VIF model properties for supporting
802.1qbg / 802.1qbh networking in hypervisor drivers. Also
wire up support to the libvirt driver for these new modes

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I91039790900170bfd698ea484d5f8a22445806ae
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Introduce support for 802.1qbg and 802.1qbh to Nova VIF model

Define the nova network VIF model properties for supporting
802.1qbg / 802.1qbh networking in hypervisor drivers. Also
wire up support to the libvirt driver for these new modes

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I91039790900170bfd698ea484d5f8a22445806ae
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

I don't propose to change this because this code disappears in the next commit in the series, thus removing the pylint warning again"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-01-11 20:06:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Hi

It looks like this patch didn't compatible with iptables implementation on quantum. 
The implementation also needs hybrid driver for enabling iptables."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-01-13 16:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

I summarizes the relationship among VIF driver, Quantum/Nova security group and libvirt nwfilter. When we use Open vSwitch, we seems to need to pass information about whether linux bridge is required or not. It depends on if quantum security group is implemented based on iptables or not.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Gro8rFJ8eYGx5u7BsHbv6WU4tq9v8chqAQSKwWzGUok/edit#slide=id.p'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-14 09:41:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Yes, Quantum needs to tell Nova whether it wants the extra bridge created & what naming it wants for that bridge. It should also tell Nova whether it has applied security group filtering or not.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-14 13:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-14 14:27:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-07 18:45:18.000000000', 'message': 'Merge LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver into LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver VIF driver and the
LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver VIF driver both support OpenVswitch
based guest configs. The difference is that the hybrid driver
does not connect the VM directly to the OVS bridge. Instead it
connects the guest to a private Linux bridge, connected to the
OVS bridge via a veth pair. This allows iptables firewall rules
to be applied to the guest VIF. The hybrid driver should always
be used unless the admin has disabled Nova firewalls using the
NoopFirewallDriver impl.

Rather than require the host admin to figure this out themselves,
merge the two classes together and automatically choose the right
impl based on whether NoopFirewallDriver is in use.

When Quantum gains support for firewalling, it will need to be
able to inform Nova whether it has got a filtering applied to
the VIFs, and thus let Nova intelligently skip its own attempt
at filtering.

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver class is kept around as
a trivial subclass of LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver for backwards
compatibility. It will be removed in the Hxxx release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I93294409a75aaa15d297471ab3e600c3c124bcde
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2013-01-22 15:18:20.000000000', 'message': "Merge LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver VIF driver and the
LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver VIF driver both support OpenVswitch
based guest configs. The difference is that the hybrid driver
does not connect the VM directly to the OVS bridge. Instead it
connects the guest to a private Linux bridge, connected to the
OVS bridge via a veth pair. This allows iptables firewall rules
to be applied to the guest VIF. The hybrid driver should always
be used unless the admin has disabled Nova firewalls using the
NoopFirewallDriver impl. Rather than require the admin to figure
this out themselves, pick the right impl automatically based
on the configured firewall driver.

When Quantum gains support for firewalling, it will need to be
able to inform Nova whether it has got a filtering applied to
the VIFs, and thus let Nova intelligently skip its own attempt
at filtering.

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required. In combination with a check against the firewall
driver, a dedicated driver for OVS hybrid setup is no longer
required.

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver class functionality is
merged into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility
with the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver
class is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver stub
will be deleted in the Hxxxxx release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I93294409a75aaa15d297471ab3e600c3c124bcde
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2013-01-22 15:22:27.000000000', 'message': "Merge LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

the VIFs, and thus let Nova intelligently skip its own attempt
at filtering.

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required. In combination with a check against the firewall
driver, a dedicated driver for OVS hybrid setup is no longer
required.

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver class functionality is
merged into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility
with the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver
class is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver stub
will be deleted in the Hxxxxx release.

commit_message:
Merge LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver VIF driver and the
LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver VIF driver both support OpenVswitch
based guest configs. The difference is that the hybrid driver
does not connect the VM directly to the OVS bridge. Instead it
connects the guest to a private Linux bridge, connected to the
OVS bridge via a veth pair. This allows iptables firewall rules
to be applied to the guest VIF. The hybrid driver should always
be used unless the admin has disabled Nova firewalls using the
NoopFirewallDriver impl. Rather than require the admin to figure
this out themselves, pick the right impl automatically based
on the configured firewall driver.

When Quantum gains support for firewalling, it will need to be
able to inform Nova whether it has got a filtering applied to
the VIFs, and thus let Nova intelligently skip its own attempt
at filtering.

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required. In combination with a check against the firewall
driver, a dedicated driver for OVS hybrid setup is no longer
required.

The LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver class functionality is
merged into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility
with the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver
class is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver stub
will be deleted after the Havana release.

Bug: 1050433
Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I93294409a75aaa15d297471ab3e600c3c124bcde
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
fix VM power state to be NOSTATE when instance not found

* nova/compute/manager.py (_sync_power_states): Revert what looks
like an inadvertent change that was part of commit 95e77703.
Also log the condition.

Fixes bug: 1085771
Change-Id: Ic6eeb9207323f05b93f0b613bd1bddd681ad8ce5

[{'created': '2013-02-05 21:24:10.000000000', 'message': 'Configurable list of OS API

Introduces the ability to configure in stackrc
the list OS API extensions via NOVA_API_EXT_LIST

commit_message:
Configurable list of OS API

Introduces the ability to configure in stackrc
the list OS API extensions via NOVA_API_EXT_LIST
Example: NOVA_API_EXT_LIST=Config_drive,Services

Fixes: LP bug #1116652
Change-Id: I2f9835a92e382cd1868963531111701b6295fa35

commit_message:
Fixes "is not", "not in" syntax usage.

Replaced "not ... is" to "is not"
Replaced "not ... in" to "not in"
Removed a redundant parenthesis

Change-Id: I9564ab1207ccdcb32d7c2bb9e8f29658b2232ff9

[{'created': '2013-02-08 02:30:46.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify libvirt snapshot code path

The "cold" snapshot code path was unnecessarily complex. We were
traversing 3 layers of abstraction to reach 3 lines of code. I've
completely eliminated snapshot.py by moving all "cold" snapshot
functions into imagebackend.py and adjusting the libvirt driver
accordingly. This is the first pass of several I intend to make
against imagebackend.py, as it is far too difficult to read given
how basic the basic level of functionality it is intended to
provide.

Change-Id: Idfacffb7210ae61193ee4f2360d4b38f330a177c

Change-Id: Idfacffb7210ae61193ee4f2360d4b38f330a177c

commit_message:
Simplify libvirt snapshot code path

The "cold" snapshot code path was unnecessarily complex. We were
traversing 3 layers of abstraction to reach 3 lines of code. I've
completely eliminated snapshot.py by moving all "cold" snapshot
functions into imagebackend.py and adjusting the libvirt driver
accordingly. This is the first pass of several I intend to make
against imagebackend.py, as it is far too difficult to read given
how basic the basic level of functionality it is intended to
provide.

Change-Id: Idfacffb7210ae61193ee4f2360d4b38f330a177c

commit_message:
Sync latest db and importutils from oslo

Changes include:

  7c0e25a Use importutils.try_import() for MySQLdb
  33b12d3 Implement importutils.try_import.
  cf705c5 Make project pyflakes clean.

Change-Id: I448f5208919d06ca0af54d2057b8f5e042862cd6

Agreed, this needs a unit test"}, {'account_id': 6728, 'date': '2013-02-07 18:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Kevin, Joe,

Thank you for looking at the change.  Can I get some clarification as to what test you feel should be added?  I looked in the existing test cases and looks like the current floating IP add/remove functionality is already been tested. 

thanks,
Ming'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-02-07 19:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The test should make sure NAT is setup before binding (as per your bug)'}, {'account_id': 6728, 'date': '2013-02-07 21:23:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Joe,

I think what you mean is a unit test to verify the order of the methods, not the logic in those methods, correct?  I haven't done much python. The only way I can think of verifying calling order is something like the following:

    def test_add_floating_ip_nat_before_bind(self):
        natted = False;
        def fakeNat(*args, **kwargs):
            global natted
            natted = True
        
        def fakeBind(*args, **kwargs):
            global natted
            self.assertTrue(natted);
        
        self.stubs.Set(self.network.driver, 'ensure_floating_forward', fakeNat)
        self.stubs.Set(self.network.driver, 'bind_floating_ip', fakeBind)
        self.network.l3driver.add_floating_ip('fakefloat',
                                              'fakefixed',
                                              'fakeiface',
                                              'fakenet')

Is there a better/ accepted way or does the above work for you?

Thanks,
Ming"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-07 21:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The basic thing we're looking for is this:  There is a bug (1100435 in the tracker).  You should have a test which detects this bug and fails.  Then your code should demonstrably cause that test to pass.

The reason for having a unit test like this is to prevent regressions, i.e., accidentally re-introducing the bug.

As to how to construct this test, the basic idea you show in your email is close to workable; however, don't use "global".  You may want to look into the mocking resources available through the "mox" package; I believe it's possible to specify the exact expected order through the way you set up the mocks'}, {'account_id': 6728, 'date': '2013-02-08 00:32:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Kevin,

I read the Mox documentation and it says that if the methods are recorded in the order they are expected to be called, then Mox will verify things in that order automatically.  However, this does not seem to be true.  I modified the test case to the following, which passed:

    def test_add_floating_ip_nat_before_bind(self):
        self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.network.driver, 'ensure_floating_forward')
        self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.network.driver, 'bind_floating_ip')
        
        self.network.driver.ensure_floating_forward(mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg())
        self.network.driver.bind_floating_ip(mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg())
        self.mox.ReplayAll()
        
        self.network.l3driver.add_floating_ip('fakefloat',
                                              'fakefixed',
                                              'fakeiface',
                                              'fakenet')

But reversing the recording order for the nat and bind calls didn't cause it to fail.  Any ideas or pointers?

thanks,
Ming"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-08 16:02:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

No, I'm afraid I don't have any insights on this; I would have expected mox's support for that sort of testing to work :(  Since it doesn't, and since I'm really not all that familiar with mox, I'll suggest going back to using your own custom-built functions.  To avoid using global, do something like:

    nat_called = [False]

    def add_nat():
        nat_called[0] = True

    def bind():
        self.assertTrue(nat_called[0])

Note the use of a list for nat_called; a dictionary would also work fine.  You can't modify nat_called from within the functions, but you can modify its *value*, so using mutable types like lists or sequences will allow you to avoid using global."}, {'account_id': 6728, 'date': '2013-02-08 18:21:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-08 19:24:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-08 19:54:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

You need to rework the commit message. The summary line doesn't describe what the commit does. Take a look at:

http://wiki.openstack.org/GitCommitMessages

for examples of the proper formatting and content of a commit message."}, {'account_id': 4184, 'date': '2013-01-31 20:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

some minor problems.'}, {'account_id': 1836, 'date': '2013-02-01 09:44:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 10:36:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20464/4/check/gate-tempest-pep8/1859 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20464/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/368 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20464/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/162 : FAILURE (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/20464/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/4173 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20464/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/117 : FAILURE (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-01 10:37:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1795, 'date': '2013-02-01 18:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-01 18:56:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So the -1 here is only because of the commit message. It still needs some cleanup. You should reword it so it doesn't point to the non-existent 'which' blueprint, and also probably fix the blueprint name so that hudson will be able to pick it up. (drop the period) But, you might want to hold off on that for a bit.

I also have some concerns about whether using http from glanceclient common is distinct enough from just testing glanceclient (like we do currently) for tempest. I'm not sure if we should use tempest's RestClient or another tempest specific http client for glance, or if using glanceclient's http lib is enough. If someone with more knowledge about this could chime in...

Either way I think writing a client class for the API is the right way to do it, instead of baking the request formatting and headers into the tests like you did here. I have a WIP up for this at: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19963/ . It doesn't currently work because of issues with image upload, but I'll rework it ASAP depending on what the consensus is on which http client to use. (Using glance client's would be easier) Once that's done I'll update the review so you can rebase the tests on top of it."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-09 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-09 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Add framework support for Glance v1.0 API Tests

This is the first commit for this blueprint which
is to get approval for the changes in the framework
for glance tests.

Includes:
 * Changes to tempest/service/image/service.py
   To define a new REST Client based on glanceclient.common.http
   This client will be used as the default clients in all Glance API Tests
 * A new directory tempest/tests/image/api_v1
   This will host all Glance v1 API Tests
 * A new base test class for v1 API Tests tempest/tests/image/api_v1/base.py
 * A new glance API test test_glance_create_images.py.

blueprint: add-glance-api-1.0-tests
Change-Id: Ia1fafd6a3c1f19961f4d9feceabdd1ee84704350

commit_message:
Test Multipath Configuration

This is a test patch to see if we can get Jenkins builds of
devstack to work with multipath enabled.   This patch
adds an /etc/multipath.conf that blacklists the /dev/sda device.

Change-Id: Iad64ae9c638e80e3d1913576ac567a9b1773cd08

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-06 02:36:13.000000000', 'message': "Update nova/compute/api to handle instance as dict

When nova.dp.api returns primitives instead of sqlalchemy objects
instance objects will be dictionaries, which cannot be added to sets
('dict' is an unhashable type)

Partially implements bp db-api-cleanup

Change-Id: I3683d1c54ae627d9cabfd569a7fd304c47c5d5b7

commit_message:
Update nova/compute/api to handle instance as dict

When nova.dp.api returns primitives instead of sqlalchemy objects
instance objects will be dictionaries, which cannot be added to sets
('dict' is an unhashable type)

Partially implements bp db-api-cleanup

Change-Id: I3683d1c54ae627d9cabfd569a7fd304c47c5d5b7

commit_message:
Use joined version of db.api calls

Replace db.instance_get_active_by_window with
db.instance_get_active_by_window_joined

Remove db.instance_get_active_by_window as it is now unused

When moving over to nova.db.api not returning sqlalchemy
objects non-joined db calls (lazy loaded) won't work.

Partially implements bp db-api-cleanup

Change-Id: Iec647792a049d53862a45f95accd7f46e483aa17

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-21 12:15:59.000000000', 'message': "ensure zeros are written out when clearing volumes

Note O_DIRECT is _not_ used at the end of devices to
avoid issues with odd sized blocks etc. so instead
we arrange to have dd issue an fdatasync()
to ensure the data is persisted, lest it be discarded
from the write cache when the device is unprovisioned.

* nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py (clear_logical_volume): Add 'conv=fdatasync'
to the dd option list if O_DIRECT isn't used when clearing.

Fixes bug: 1100363
Change-Id: I76789557754ebaeb6d52bb34548a2ef17808fbf6
"}]
commit_message:
ensure zeros are written out when clearing volumes

Note O_DIRECT is _not_ used at the end of devices to
avoid issues with odd sized blocks etc. so instead
we arrange to have dd issue an fdatasync()
to ensure the data is persisted, lest it be discarded
from the write cache when the device is unprovisioned.

* nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py (clear_logical_volume): Add 'conv=fdatasync'
to the dd option list if O_DIRECT isn't used when clearing.

Fixes bug: 1100363
Change-Id: I76789557754ebaeb6d52bb34548a2ef17808fbf6

commit_message:
allow disabling file injection completely

With the libvirt_injection_partition config set to -2,
file injection is avoided completely.

This can be required if you want to make user specified files
available from the metadata server (and config drive is not enabled),
then you would want to avoid injection completely for performance reasons,
but also to avoid boot failure if the injection itself failed.

Flags: DocImpact
Change-Id: I604f4189114515c70c58cf183622542c4633e44a

The libvirt disk mapping refactor change introduced
a bug in libvirt.driver.get_guest_config where we were
attempting to perform instance_update using a non-existent
key in the disk_mapping.

Given that we already parsed out the root_device_name and stored
it in a variable, and then verify that it's set in an if

we've already parsed.

Fixes bug: 1118829
