revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-07 18:45:15.000000000', 'message': "Merge LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver into LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver VIF driver and the
LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver VIF driver both support OpenVswitch
based guest configs. The only difference is that the former
uses libvirt's modern <network type='bridge'> with vport
profile specified, while the latter uses <network type='ethernet'>
and does all openvswitch setup itself. The reason for the latter
is to support running against libvirt versions older than 0.9.11

Rather than require the host admin to figure this out themselves,
merge the two classes together and automatically choose the right
impl based on the libvirt version we're running against

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver class is kept around as
a trivial subclass of LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver for backwards
compatibility. It will be removed in the Hxxx release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I292c2fd7aa0c32b1c91d737152ed8e54ea2cf6ac
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2013-01-07 22:24:29.000000000', 'message': "Merge LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver into LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver

profile specified, while the latter uses <network type='ethernet'>
and does all openvswitch setup itself. The reason for the latter
is to support running against libvirt versions older than 0.9.11

Rather than require the host admin to figure this out themselves,
merge the two classes together and automatically choose the right
impl based on the libvirt version we're running against

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver class is kept around as
a trivial subclass of LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver for backwards
compatibility. It will be removed in the Hxxx release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I292c2fd7aa0c32b1c91d737152ed8e54ea2cf6ac
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

"}, {'created': '2013-01-22 15:18:21.000000000', 'message': "Merge LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver class into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver VIF driver and the
LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver VIF driver both support OpenVswitch
based guest configs. The only difference is that the former
uses libvirt's modern <network type='bridge'> with vport
profile specified, while the latter uses <network type='ethernet'>
and does all openvswitch setup itself. The reason for the latter
is to support running against libvirt versions older than 0.9.11
Rather than require the host admin to figure this out themselves,
the right behaviour can be choosen automatically based on the
libvirt connection's version number.

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required. In combination with a check against the libvirt version
number, a dedicated driver for OVS bridge setup is no longer
required.

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver class functionality is
merged into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility
with the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver
class is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver stub
will be deleted in the Hxxxxx release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I292c2fd7aa0c32b1c91d737152ed8e54ea2cf6ac
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Merge Libvirt....VirtualPortDriver class into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver VIF driver and the
LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver VIF driver both support OpenVswitch
based guest configs. The only difference is that the former
uses libvirt's modern <network type='bridge'> with vport
profile specified, while the latter uses <network type='ethernet'>
and does all openvswitch setup itself. The reason for the latter
is to support running against libvirt versions older than 0.9.11
Rather than require the host admin to figure this out themselves,
the right behaviour can be choosen automatically based on the
libvirt connection's version number.

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required. In combination with a check against the libvirt version
number, a dedicated driver for OVS bridge setup is no longer
required.

The LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver class functionality is
merged into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility
with the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver
class is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver stub
will be deleted after the Havana release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I292c2fd7aa0c32b1c91d737152ed8e54ea2cf6ac
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Cells: Add cells support to hypervisors extension

This removes the DB calls from the extension and moves them into
HostAPI().  The cells version of HostAPI() proxies them to the
appropriate cell or cells.

Change-Id: I17ff10e62d2f10b85a557edcc1509ca3b0d15a29

subject: Cells: Add cells support to instance_usage_audit_log api extension

'}, {'created': '2013-01-11 22:55:12.000000000', 'message': 'Cells: Add cells support to instance_usage_audit_log api extension

This extension normally gets the audit task entries from the local DB,
but with cells this should be grabbed from every cell.

commit_message:
Cells: Add cells support to instance_usage_audit_log api extension

Adds task_log_get_all() call to HostAPI() so that we can use the local
DB when cells is disabled or proxy via cells if cells is enabled.

Adds task_log_get_all() call to cells.

Change-Id: I9e78c17fcf70f98903d0a26c1de3e2581b8977ad

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-28 03:17:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add REST API to show availability_zone of instance.

Implement one workitem for bp:show-availability-zone

Show the availability_zone of an instance. When create instance if
"availability_zone" doesn't specified, the "availability_zone" will be None.
But actually the instance is in a zone which its host is in. So I think show
both of them will be fine.

Change-Id: I2d742ee2d291b514bf783fa79293785cca8ea2a5
'}, {'created': '2012-11-28 04:48:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add REST API to show availability_zone of instance.

commit_message:
Add REST API to show availability_zone of instance.

Implement one workitem for bp:show-availability-zone

This show the availability zone and availability zone of its host in
API: GET /servers/details, GET /server/{uuid}.

When create instance if "availability_zone" doesn't specified, the
"availability_zone" of the instance will be None.  But actually the instance
is in a zone which its host is in. So I think show both of them will be fine.

Change-Id: I2d742ee2d291b514bf783fa79293785cca8ea2a5

commit_message:
Move security_groups refreshes to conductor

This moves the last bit of compute-initiated db accesses found during
test runs to conductor. The quantum API was hitting the database directly
while calling back to compute's API to trigger the refresh. This just
makes the quantum API ask conductor to do that in a similar way to the
usage notifications patch recently merged.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I44de7e1e12aec291b8319d45ec5975ad05b8e676

[{'created': '2013-02-06 21:07:17.000000000', 'message': "Allow disabling of long-lived SSH connections.

Currently, SSHPool connections are kept alive indefinitely.  This can
be good for many cases, but sometimes it is not desirable.  For
example, this causes unit tests which use SSH to not complete because
of the open connections.  This patch allows users to revert back
to paramiko's regular timeout policy.

Change-Id: Ifa96508b38d90610390c9ec3d48a7de75d02f08b
"}]
commit_message:
Allow disabling of long-lived SSH connections.

Currently, SSHPool connections are kept alive indefinitely.  This can
be good for many cases, but sometimes it is not desirable.  For
example, this causes unit tests which use SSH to not complete because
of the open connections.  This patch allows users to revert back
to paramiko's regular timeout policy.

Change-Id: Ifa96508b38d90610390c9ec3d48a7de75d02f08b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-07 09:13:55.000000000', 'message': "Move create_cloned_volume() to LVMVolumeDriver.

The implementation of create_cloned_volume() that was in driver.py
relied on functions that aren't declared there, such as
_create_volume(), _copy_volume(), and _sizestr().  Moved the function
to LVMVolumeDriver in lvm.py, where those functions exist.

Change-Id: I5ab77a119b3af0a152a3b5e0c2ff6a5ce196ad0f
Fixes: bug #1112485
"}]
commit_message:
Move create_cloned_volume() to LVMVolumeDriver.

The implementation of create_cloned_volume() that was in driver.py
relied on functions that aren't declared there, such as
_create_volume(), _copy_volume(), and _sizestr().  Moved the function
to LVMVolumeDriver in lvm.py, where those functions exist.

Change-Id: I5ab77a119b3af0a152a3b5e0c2ff6a5ce196ad0f
Fixes: bug #1112485

commit_message:
Add create_cloned_volume support to 3PAR

This patch adds support to do create_cloned_volume for the 3PAR
iSCSI driver.   It's semi-dependent on a patch that is outstanding
to prevent a user from deleting a volume while the copy is ongoing.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20737/

Change-Id: Id46cb6fa4a8d27ea924be0c8bfa619baa007329f

commit_message:
XenAPINFS: Copy volume to glance

related to blueprint xenapinfs-glance-integration

This patch enables to upload XenAPINFS backed cinder volumes to glance
by using the nova glance plugin.

Change-Id: Ie41aa6871fec691556b82501ce3bfdf50898471d

"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-23 00:29:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

as this is going to be behind keystone, I'd actually move to put this into lib/keystone"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-01-25 18:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

Good progress'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-01-25 21:22:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Disagree on putting this under keystone.  LDAP is a stand alone service.   Keystone consumes LDAP, but it is possible that we will use LDAP for DNS in the future.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-01-25 21:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-01-25 22:00:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Interesting stuff...

Please structure this similarly to the other projects in lib/, it should be in its own file (lib/ldap).  The .ldif files should go in files/ or files/ldap/ if you prefer.

I saw a comment regarding making it a part of keystone; I'd prefer to not do that as it looks like you are using the packaged openldap server so it is a system service.  If configured to use ldap keystone should test for it being available but I'd think that is all."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-28 15:01:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

if this isn't going under keystone, even though it's the only service that uses it, the it at least needs to look like the rest of the services.

be lib/ldap, have install, configure, etc functions called from the other functions.

files installed via files/apts/ldap

The system service argument about what we might do in the future doesn't really hold for me though. Quantum starts all kinds of system services, depending on plugin. ryu integration is probably a much closer analogy here, because at this time the only direct ldap consumer is keystone.

It can always be refactored later if we start consuming ldap in multiple services like we do the database."}, {'account_id': 6460, 'date': '2013-01-28 21:26:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-28 21:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20249/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/28527 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20249/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres/967 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/20249/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/3100 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-01-29 23:42:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (7 inline comments)

Good progress, I've noted some minor formatting things."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-30 11:16:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

in addition to dtroyer's comments, a couple other on indenting.

At a conceptual level I still think we should call install_ldap in lib/keystone, not in stack.sh until the service is used by another core project.

Also, how will one trigger keystone being backed with ldap? The way as written if someone enables ldap as a system servce, it seems that keystone converts to ldap under the covers, but all the same database setup is required as well?

Given that devstack is also living documentation, it would be good to expose what the best practice would be here."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-01-30 14:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sean,  Yes, it is intentional that LDAP triggers the Keystone config, and still requires the Database.  You cannot run Keystone without a Database, even if you use LDAP for the Identity store, as LDAP does not store Policy, Service Catalog nor the Tokens.

LDAP should be an optional component, and not installed by default, but if it is is indicated that it is enabled, the above logic should trigger it.  It is much like postgres or qpid;  they are not installed by default, but used if they are indicated on the command line.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:51:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

right, though it is a little different. In the qpid or pg case they are implementations of a feature (database or queue) that you can't function without. ldap is a keystone backend implementation detail, like the quantum plugins.

So it seems like KEYSTONE_BACKEND=ldap (or something) should be the stackrc and that triggers this to run."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-01-30 16:07:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We're adding KEYSTONE_TOKEN_BACKEND, I suppose adding KEYSTONE_IDENTITY_BACKEND to lib/keystone would complete the trifecta."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-01-31 20:58:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Dean: don't forget KEYSTONE_POLICY_BACKEND and KEYSTONE_TRUSTS_BACKEND, both new for grizzly (although we'll only have sql drivers)"}, {'account_id': 6460, 'date': '2013-02-01 00:37:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 01:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20249/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/29402 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/20249/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/4110 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-01 19:46:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

please add in the deb/rpm dependencies for python-ldap.  Keystone does not yet install them by default, as LDAP is considered optional."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-02-01 21:34:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

it looks like files/ldap/manager.ldif shouldn't be here?  it's generated in lib/ldap.

'}, {'created': '2013-01-28 21:26:55.000000000', 'message': 'Work In progress to add optional silent install and config of ldap to devstack

I restructured the code to be more devstack compliant as suggested.  ldif files are now in files/ldap and the main script is in lib.  I hooked this into stack.sh and updated keystone with new inisets to add ldap properties to keystone.conf
Change-Id: I1404cc5c754f878e32a2d10254840d092211e6e6
'}, {'created': '2013-02-01 00:37:56.000000000', 'message': 'Work In progress to add optional silent install and config of ldap to devstack

I cleaned up formatting of the code, added new cache files, and addressed
all comments. I also fixed a bug where ldapadd would halt devstack by
returning an error code if the ldap was previously configured. I also added
KEYSTONE_IDENTITY_BACKEND to control the driver selection independent of the
ldap install option.
Change-Id: I1404cc5c754f878e32a2d10254840d092211e6e6

Add optional silent install and config of ldap to devstack

lsb_release is not installed by default on Fedora (or at least
it's not on my F17 box), so we should avoid using it, simple
alternative is just to read /etc/fedora-release instead

Change-Id: I341c151e8560fb971b11d27578934940aeeca1a7
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat scripts : Avoid using lsb_release in tools/openstack

lsb_release is not installed by default on Fedora (or at least
it's not on my F17 box), so we should avoid using it, simple
alternative is just to read /etc/fedora-release instead

Change-Id: I341c151e8560fb971b11d27578934940aeeca1a7
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-02-07 00:23:45.000000000', 'message': 'Change forward_bridge_interface to MultiStrOpt

The config option specifically mentions it can be set multiple times
but it was accidentally set to a ListOpt instead of a MultiStrOpt.

Change-Id: Ibc4280c4bbdd10655192fb8bb5a810125555eb6d
'}]
commit_message:
Change forward_bridge_interface to MultiStrOpt

The config option specifically mentions it can be set multiple times
but it was accidentally set to a ListOpt instead of a MultiStrOpt.

Change-Id: Ibc4280c4bbdd10655192fb8bb5a810125555eb6d

commit_message:
Sync latest install_venv_common from oslo.

This commit sync the latest install_venv_common from oslo which
fixes an issue with importing from cinder.openstack.common. This
is needed to run tools/install_venv.py in a non-devstack environment.

Change-Id: I56529ceab605e1f480bd8260e7cf30acb29346bf

commit_message:
Quantum Floating IP support

blueprint quantum-floating-ip

This commit allows OpenStack dashboard users to use Quantum floating
IP feature directly using Quantum API rather than Nova Proxy.
By this users can associates a floating IP per virtual NIC.

blueprint nova-net-quantum-abstraction

This commit defines an abstract class in api/network.py.
This class provides common interfaces related to network features
duplicated in Nova and Quantum. A concrete class to handle operations
should be defined in api/nova.py or api/quantum.py.

Change-Id: I780356a9f41e72e32ce1877d390ac7f99e96899c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 15:00:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add size validations for /tokens.

Updates /tokens controller so that it explicitly checks the max
size of userId, username, tenantId, tenantname, token, and password
before continuing with a request.

Previously, when used with the SQL keystone backend an unauthenticated
user could send in *really* large requests which would ultimately
log large SQL exceptions and could thus fill up keystone logs on the
disk.

Change-Id: Ic7f9291b6020f2579ec55431358af16eb2ebb66f
'}]
commit_message:
Add size validations for /tokens.

Updates /tokens controller so that it explicitly checks the max
size of userId, username, tenantId, tenantname, token, and password
before continuing with a request.

Previously, when used with the SQL keystone backend an unauthenticated
user could send in *really* large requests which would ultimately
log large SQL exceptions and could thus fill up keystone logs on the
disk.

Change-Id: Ic7f9291b6020f2579ec55431358af16eb2ebb66f

'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2013-02-06 19:50:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

well, what prevents you from setting DEBUG/TEMPLATE_DEBUG in local_settings?

Currently, both settings are in both files, settings.py and local/local_settings.py.example. I'd appreciate a cleanup anyways. So, if you'd move setting DEBUG/TEMPLATE_DEBUG, please also remove from local_settings.py.example"}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-02-06 20:33:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The settings.py default is DEBUG=False. That's good, 'cuz if you don't set it in your local_settings you're secure.

Setting it in local_settings is how you *should* set DEBUG=True. The setting can rightly exist in both places. It's an override.

However, if you look at the settings.py file in master, the check for "if DEBUG:" comes *before* the local settings file is imported. So DEBUG will *always* equal False when that code block is reached.

This patch fixes that.'}, {'account_id': 5733, 'date': '2013-02-07 00:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Would this interfere with any logging config done in local_settings.py?'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-02-07 01:37:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Nope. In Python the logging.basicConfig method only has effect on the global root logger if no other logging configuration has been set on it. Basically this patch is just making sure that the logging config specified in local_settings.py works for log levels below WARNING (the global default).

This is a bugfix 'cuz this got moved in a previous patch, not a new thing. Try it the way it is in master and try it moving it here. You'll see what's wrong in master immediately. I'm restoring a previous behavior."}, {'account_id': 5733, 'date': '2013-02-07 01:45:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Gabriel. Should have googled that - I didn't expect the answer to be so straightforward :)."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2013-02-07 07:59:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

OK; agreed.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2013-02-07 08:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-07 09:24:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-06 00:05:17.000000000', 'message': 'Re-enable client logging.

The log level setting got moved before the local conf import,
thereby making it impossible to actually set the log level to
debug. This moves it back to the correct ordering.

Change-Id: I7b6c17350add058215c8dd3e3dd7351df64a544a
'}]
commit_message:
Re-enable client logging.

The log level setting got moved before the local conf import,
thereby making it impossible to actually set the log level to
debug. This moves it back to the correct ordering.

commit_message:
Allow for specifying nfs mount options

Fixes bug 1113042

Adds a new config option:
    nfs_mount_options=None (Default)

When not None, anything set here will be passed as -o <options> to
the mount command. The default behavior is to do exactly as we are
doing today and relying on the OS/kernel defaults.

Change-Id: I6bd27f9d0e8848a9ba98318ba7288e43ee6b4cb9
Flags: DocImpact

commit_message:
Don't require importing paramiko for error.

The _run_ssh function raises a paramiko exception, which requires
functions that use it to import the paramiko class. This should be
hidden away, and so I created a new exception in its place. Nobody
but the Storwize/SVC driver use it anyway, and I am updating that
driver in a separate patch.

Change-Id: Ibf353edc664765897a5fa7a08d126de4b8992863

Update to latest oslo version code.

Removes the need for the versioninfo file, as now everything can be done via
pkg_resources.

commit_message:
XenAPINFS: Copy image from glance

related to blueprint xenapinfs-glance-integration

This change is using the glance xenapi plugin to copy a glance image to
a xenapinfs backed volume. It slightly differs from the reference
implementation, as this implementation is composed of three steps:
- create volume
- overwrite the created volume with the one downloaded from glance
- resize the volume
As opposed to fill the bytes from glance to the created image. This
approach works more effective with XenServer type semi ovf tgz -ed vhds.

Change-Id: I2345f6bb355aa285eee0455380c580e4724f004e

commit_message:
Allow tools/install_venv_common.py to be run from within the source directory.

(Copy latest update from oslo)

Not doing this raised exceptions when it tried importing modules
that didn't exist in the path.

Fixes LP# 1112484

Change-Id: I2be7bde0bf873a22318617b987a76b209caef22a

commit_message:
Bad translation from network types to nvp transport types

Bug 1117769

'Flat' and 'Vlan' where not being converted into 'bridge'
This change cannot have unit tests because the fake nvp api
client does not validate such constraints at the moment

Change-Id: I2b918265cb8becf6f023abc7937b92b3058d9446

commit_message:
Sync latest install_venv_common from oslo.

This commit syncs the latest install_venv_common from oslo which
fixes an issue with importing from tempest.openstack.common. This
is needed to run tools/install_venv.py in a non-devstack environment.

[{'created': '2013-02-07 00:29:27.000000000', 'message': "Use yaml.safe_load: full yaml.load isn't needed

The only reason to use yaml.load instead of safe_load is if one wants to
load serialized objects. Heat's use case is purely to load basic data
structures such as maps/lists/strings. Fixes bug #1117820

Change-Id: I4f6cf2ed4e15405f8b296ccaec737a3779c9867d
"}]
commit_message:
Use yaml.safe_load: full yaml.load isn't needed

The only reason to use yaml.load instead of safe_load is if one wants to
load serialized objects. Heat's use case is purely to load basic data
structures such as maps/lists/strings. Fixes bug #1117820

Change-Id: I4f6cf2ed4e15405f8b296ccaec737a3779c9867d

Based on an earlier #-infra discussion with Clark (I've added him to the review just now to confirm), translation changes in the projects are also pushed back up to Transifex... though we were talking about the possibility of stopping that and only taking translations through Transifex in the future (sending only the regenerated pot files back to Transifex at that point). Basically the https://github.com/openstack-infra/config/blob/master/modules/openstack_project/files/jenkins_job_builder/config/translation-jobs.yaml#L1 template gets called right now which eventually runs https://github.com/openstack-infra/config/blob/master/modules/jenkins/files/slave_scripts/upstream_translation_update.sh#L38 to shove any modified po files back up (as best I can tell)."}, {'account_id': 5545, 'date': '2013-01-23 22:16:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Update en_US message translations.

Fixes bug 1101587.

* nova/locale/en_US/LC_MESSAGES/nova.po: This "translation" was
woefully outdated, causing KeyError exceptions under a number of
circumstances for users of this particular locale when format
strings wound up containing incorrect substitution variables. This
change attempts to sync up the msgstr entries to match msgid given
this is the source language for the pot file. I did not see any
obvious instances where en_US should differ from C locale for these.

Change-Id: I81d1729fee17653b089f3c47db20f3fc073ab363

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-04 23:26:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add volume_glance_metadata to volume.api.get

The dict(rv.iteritems()) agains the volume object from
volume.api.get does NOT set the volume_glance_metadata k/v.

This is used to show bootable in the show and list api calls,
the result was that list properly reflected the bootable status
of a volume, however show would always describe the flag as False.

So we simply check if the rv includes the glance_metadata and if
so go ahead and create the entry in the volume dict.

Fixes bug: 1115629

Change-Id: Ia0be08f3d2c85b7fe8390fca264803c96cdce7f7
'}]
commit_message:
Add volume_glance_metadata to volume.api.get

The dict(rv.iteritems()) agains the volume object from
volume.api.get does NOT set the volume_glance_metadata k/v.

This is used to show bootable in the show and list api calls,
the result was that list properly reflected the bootable status
of a volume, however show would always describe the flag as False.

So we simply check if the rv includes the glance_metadata and if
so go ahead and create the entry in the volume dict.

Fixes bug: 1115629

Change-Id: Ia0be08f3d2c85b7fe8390fca264803c96cdce7f7

commit_message:
Show the summary or details of all availability zones of a region

Adding "availability-zone-list" sub-command allow user list all
availability zones and its status in a region.
* summary list for normal user: list availability zones summary whitin a
flat view.
* details list for administrator user: list availability zones details
within a tree view, include zones, hosts and components.

Implement one workitem for bp:show-availability-zone

Change-Id: Id87fe470c7e0f6fbfb9465551f63717724b5fc18

messages:

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-30 12:03:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I feel like this approach with flags is confusing. It might be better to have a unified flag that's SECOND_HOST or something. Some way in which we have a single flag which we can rally around when devstack is run on node 2 - n.

Would be interested in dtroyer's views"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:30:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

I don't think this patch is needed; multi-node configurations require a different localrc on the compute nodes.  Specifically, they do not have a database enabled on compute nodes and in that case the test just before each of the new tests here will fail.

FWIW, the compute node I used to use back at RCB had the following differences from the master node:

 MYSQL_HOST=<master-ip>
 RABBIT_HOST=<master-ip>
 GLANCE_HOSTPORT=<master-ip>:9292
 ENABLED_SERVICES=n-cpu,n-net,n-api,g-api,c-vol

The lack of mysql, rabbit, etc are how the scripts know to not initialize the data stores."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-07 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-07 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

Change-Id: I997ffd7b3b12d4c5c11041347ca95e70f97b5e52
'}]
commit_message:
This patch allows multiple compute nodes to be used.

In order to work on scheduler and instance migration it is necessary to
start multiple compute nodes.  The patch creates 2 new flags that allow one
to control the n-net network registration and the database re-creation when
starting more than a single node.

Change-Id: I997ffd7b3b12d4c5c11041347ca95e70f97b5e52

The existing wait function is correct, when it refuses the 'rebooting' status. You can use that function.

You can use the images loaded from the s3 storage as the other run_instance test at the moment.

(The next possible refactor in the run_instance test cases is to work like the server action test.)

You can change the existing simple instance start stop test, to do a reboot as well, and skip it based on the bug (you can create it) about the 'rebooting' status.

The images used in the test_ec2_instance_run.py will be shared resource in the future, but for now you should implement instance related test cases in the same file.

At the moment, I would recommend to modify the existing (test_run_stop_terminate_instance) test case to implement the bp.

commit_message:
Horizon escapes special characters in openrc.sh

Adding the safe filter makes it possible to have tenant names with
special charaters rendered into the openrc.sh file without escaping
those characters.

Added a new unittest for templates

Bug 1100042

Change-Id: I2ba152311cf83486729e384cad7c082836a62032

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 15:05:00.000000000', 'message': 'lxc: Clean up namespace mounts

5f697f64e5c445ba1b62c82d9167fd6b9c7256d2 introduced a regression
when using lxc containers with qcow2 and qemu-nbd.

When removing the rootfs from the host namespace, it would
terminate the qemu-nbd process as well. This would cause
the kernel too oops under Ubuntu 13.04. Since the underlying
device thtat the libvirt_lxc process disapears.

To get around this we just clean up the host namespace if the
instance is powered-on. When the instance terminates it will
teardown the whole container.

This fixes LP: #1115786

Change-Id: I98bec2338cb455dbd277295ab36767149e05634c
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-02-05 16:12:43.000000000', 'message': 'lxc: Clean up namespace mounts

commit_message:
lxc: Clean up namespace mounts

5f697f64e5c445ba1b62c82d9167fd6b9c7256d2 introduced a regression
when using lxc containers with qcow2 and qemu-nbd.

When removing the rootfs from the host namespace, it would
terminate the qemu-nbd process as well. This would cause
the kernel too oops under Ubuntu 13.04. Since the underlying
device thtat the libvirt_lxc process disapears.

To get around this we just clean up the host namespace if the
instance is powered-on. When the instance terminates it will
teardown the whole container.

This fixes LP: #1115786

Change-Id: I98bec2338cb455dbd277295ab36767149e05634c
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

(1 inline comment)

That framework was a recent addition, and we're trying to ensure that all of the migrations are tested with actual data in the database going forward."}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-01-31 21:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

There will be a lot of such situation where we need to add and then drop UC, so I added generic method for such things:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20935/'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2013-02-01 20:55:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

Dan and other reviewers, please suggest if it's a good practice to delete the duplicate keys in the migration script."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-02 12:03:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

agree with @dan, we need to have prerun and check functions in test_migrations run with sample data.

I'm not comfortable factoring out that kind of testing to something generic, we need to see how it works on real data in a real database."}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-02-04 06:22:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I think we should modify the migration's upgrade method where we create a new "key_pairs" table with the Unique constraint, and  discard the duplicate keypairs (keeping the newest of the duplicates). Please let me know if this is ok or any other approach has to be taken?'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-02-04 06:40:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Sean and Dan,

I am not sure that it is better to test multiple time one common action (dropping UC).  Because, there could be mistake every time in tests. Also it is very hard to make each time 100% code coverage. 

I think it is better to apply every effort to make 100% code coverage for generic method. Generic method could be tested on real table in real database with real data.

+ I should make same operation with multiple tables. And It will spend a lot of time to make tests for all these tables.

@Tushar, 
Probably you should just raise exception and add Log message, that you couldn't create `UC` on `columns` in `table`. Then DB admin could remove duplicate entries by hand and then rerun db sync."}, {'account_id': 1633, 'date': '2013-02-07 05:50:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Abandoned

Abandoning since Rohan Kanade is submitting another patch addressing the above issues.'}]

commit_message:
Return 409 on creating/importing same name keypair

1. Removed the DB look up on creating and importing a keypair.
2. Added unique constraint on user_id and name columns of key_pairs
table.

Fixes LP: #1086333.

Change-Id: I1c4fa91ecf358d4bc01739a53195a74d911f46af

Hi Joe,

I'm struggling to see how to do this, can you expand on what you had in mind please ?

For example would it be enough to parse the values of monkey_patch_modules and somehow check that there is a valid class and method (any pointers on where else this is done would be good)

I guessing that building a test case that stubs out the specific defaults would be tying the test too closely to the current value.

Thanks,
Phil"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-02-01 20:45:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

For example would it be enough to parse the values of monkey_patch_modules and somehow check that there is a valid class and method (any pointers on where else this is done would be good)

I was thinking of something that checks to see if the default value is a valid path and class by using __import__ (http://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html)

parent = _import__('some.class',globals(),locals(),['mymodule'],-1)
try:
    getattr(parent, 'mymodule')
except: AttributeError"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-04 14:20:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-04 15:53:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Default value of monkey_patch_modules is broken

The default value of monkey_patch_modules has not kept up with
the move of notifier to openstack.common

Without this change setting 'monkey_patch=True' in nova.conf
will cause runtime errors unless the monkey_patch_modules
is also specified pointing to the correct notifier

Change-Id: Ib22faa7404b09791799338de2edfe0ddcd662d5f

commit_message:
Verbose logging on error

* Create rest logger instance only once.
* If the token does not seams special it is omitted.
* The log level setting in tempest.conf has limitations in
  configuring log level, so it is removed for now.
* No extra logging on error in any different log level.

Bug: #1089846

Change-Id: Ibd664520e81e072ea1040c47d0aeef4980903118

commit_message:
Don't show traceback from REST API calls

stop tracebacks from into nova-api.log
when say cinderclient raises an exception.

Fix for bug 1098048

Change-Id: I24ed62c3af18bcdbba354e3bfc2922deb25eeca1

commit_message:
Allow password-field autocomplete to be configured in settings.

This allows users to use strong passwords stored in browser password
managers, without resorting to workarounds like disabling autocomplete
everywhere.

Change-Id: I5f5e8cd332a5462bbbdc5c26bbfff2f3665016ea

test/functional/swift_test_client.py:90
test/functional/swift_test_client.py:304

I'm not a big fan of trivial changes such as this one, especially when they inspire people to submit a bunch more similar changes. However, I'll take this one, provided that it fixes all uses of "not X in Y", so that there aren't more such small reviews in my future.

Also, please put "Fixes bug 1110150" in the commit message somewhere so that the associated bug can be automatically closed.

Pdraig,
  Thank you for raising in the commit message that there is functional change here. I suspect otherwise it would have gone un-noticed.
  I suspect that this change is OK, and that the number of users affected might even be zero.  However, this essentially is essentially a config change that results in a change of behavior exposed to the end user (instance user).  The most likely case is where a user now ha access to an admin pass that they requested, where they previously did not, so it seems unlikely to result in broken-ness to the user.

  We just need to be very careful about such things.  Once openstack gains large acceptance, changes like this could result in perfectly good and widely distributed images breaking.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-06 19:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
separate libvirt injection and configdrive config variables

This is mostly a refactoring so that if config drive is required,
variable lookup only needed for the injection case, is avoided.

There is a functional change here to make 'admin_pass' consistent
with the other variables in that the libvirt_inject_password flag
now does _not_ control whether the admin password is placed
in the config drive.

Change-Id: Ib79971aa050e56e5aa72fdd69aadd7539b2bd315

Added some more tests. The memory filter itself is also tested in its own filter tests, why I feel that it is well covered.

The change introduced here simply makes use of existing code to test for available host memory. Thinking one step ahead, it could easily be extended to cover the full range of active filters so that scheduling and migrations would allow vm placements using the same rules.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-23 05:21:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is an improvement over what we had, so it's nice in that regard but I question whether policy such as never over-committing memory should be static. While over subscription does incur risk, some administrators may be willing to take that on for the increased instance density. Also, the danger varies based on the hypervisor in question.

Anyhow, as long as free_ram_mb measures the total physical memory, minus what has been allocated to VMs (I didn't trace the code all the way through), I'm a fan of this change."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-01-24 17:13:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Add support for memory overcommit in live-migration

Override the live-migration memory check in FilterScheduler and
make it use RamFilter for checking available memory on target
host.

Resolves bug 1068258.

Change-Id: I3002b8330e595ce71e2718b2091d3b0b99747707

commit_message:
Adds original copyright notice to refactored files

Fixes bug: #1116586

The Hyper-V driver contributed for Folsom contains some refactored code
from the Diablo release contributed by Cloud.com.

Although the copyright notice remained in the "driver.py" file, it has
erroneously not been added to the new "vmops.py" and "vmutils.py" files
that contained some refactored code from the original contribution.

Change-Id: I71cf1df30c0b2ef5ae3df38f3c6f0311b7b4b3d9

'}, {'created': '2013-01-14 21:35:07.000000000', 'message': "Cells: Add support for compute HostAPI()

This will allow the hosts API extension to work. Calls to get service
information from the DB are proxied via cells.

When using the host extension, the 'id' and 'host' fields for
service/compute will be modified to have the cell prepended to it.  One
can do a 'show' on a 'path!to!cell@id' to see details for a particular
host in the 'path!to!cell' cell, for instance.

commit_message:
Cells: Add support for compute HostAPI()

This will allow the hosts API extension to work. Calls to get service
information from the DB are proxied via cells.

When using the host extension, the 'id' and 'host' fields for
service/compute will be modified to have the cell prepended to it.  One
can do a 'show' on a 'path!to!cell@id' to see details for a particular
host in the 'path!to!cell' cell, for instance.

Implements bp/nova-compute-cells

Change-Id: I8137fa64d2578acfc3d2457c231de2b0d69b96d8

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-06 07:34:04.000000000', 'message': "Removes use of nose.tools.raises

Removes uses of nose.tools.raises and replaces it with
assertRaises. This makes it consistent with how expected
exceptions are handled in other tempest tests and is part of the
process of removing dependencies on nose.

For the files that were altered use of attr(type='negative') were
also removed. These are not used as the tests already handle the
expected failures by catching the exception (formerly by using
@nose.tools.raises decorators). These need to removed eventually
as the nose.plugins.atttrib.attr decorators are replaced by the
testtools attr decorators which will remove the final
dependencies on nose (but nosetests will still be able to be
used, it just won't be required).

Change-Id: Id8a86da283fd16dd5a907be28d442c23c17cb35c
"}, {'created': '2013-02-06 10:18:23.000000000', 'message': "Removes use of nose.tools.raises

commit_message:
Removes use of nose.tools.raises

Removes uses of nose.tools.raises and replaces it with
assertRaises. This makes it consistent with how expected
exceptions are handled in other tempest tests and is part of the
process of removing dependencies on nose.

For the files that were altered use of attr(type='negative') were
also removed. These are not used as the tests already handle the
expected failures by catching the exception (formerly by using
@nose.tools.raises decorators). These need to removed eventually
as the nose.plugins.atttrib.attr decorators are replaced by the
testtools attr decorators which will remove the final
dependencies on nose (but nosetests will still be able to be
used, it just won't be required).

Change-Id: Id8a86da283fd16dd5a907be28d442c23c17cb35c

commit_message:
heat api : Add policy.json authorization to CFN API

Adds a basic policy.json to authorize all actions for the CFN API -
this will deny access to the in-instance users defined in stack
templates (which are assigned the heat_stack_user role) to all API
actions apart from DescribeStackResource, which is used for metadata
updates

ref bug 1115758

Change-Id: I1431c1f23593fffd0f911f71ef9c186a43e5063a
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat common : context should split roles from X-Roles

The auth_token code joins roles with a comma delimiter and stores
the result in the X-Roles header, so we need to split X-Roles back
into a list for the context (otherwise the oslo policy code breaks)

Change-Id: I32bd1d6355b6fe0e16e729f35b1d0b5c61346a70
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 00:55:35.000000000', 'message': "Copy glance_image_metadata when cloning volumes.

When cloning a volume we were not capturing/copying
the glance_image_metadata from the source volume.

This change implements a copy_image_metadata_from_vol_to_vol.
So now we can clone bootable volumes without going back to glance
or messing with them otherwise, they're just ready to be booted.

Fixes bug: 1115634

Change-Id: I859bb2550267c6a5142e85ec89f1c7ff885588ac
"}]
commit_message:
Copy glance_image_metadata when cloning volumes.

When cloning a volume we were not capturing/copying
the glance_image_metadata from the source volume.

This change implements a copy_image_metadata_from_vol_to_vol.
So now we can clone bootable volumes without going back to glance
or messing with them otherwise, they're just ready to be booted.

Fixes bug: 1115634

Change-Id: I859bb2550267c6a5142e85ec89f1c7ff885588ac

commit_message:
Adds reset-task-status mgmt api instance action

When reset-task-status is called the instance's task status is set to NONE.

Partially implements: blueprint reset-task-status-mgmt-api

Change-Id: I3150b53c3feb586d4bcfa8a2f5807ecd53c89e26

Looks good, but the comments made by stevebaker in patchset 3 have not been addressed, the removal of the redundant service_type='volume'. Would be good to clean this up if possible, but otherwise looks OK to me.

I also think this probably has problems with the token auth logic (we shouldn't be passing the heat service user/password to another service when doing token auth, ref swift and heat_keystoneclient which I think are doing it right), but this probably also needs fixing for nova and quantum clients, so I guess I'll raise a new bug and we can fix them all together."}, {'account_id': 3098, 'date': '2013-02-04 23:28:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-04 23:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

commit_message:
Updated to latest oslo-version code.

In support of tag-based versioning, update to latest oslo-version.
This changes from using versioninfo files to using PKG_INFO.

Change-Id: Ia7d212d531305997153204dfffa44beed4bad0d3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-21 17:58:51.000000000', 'message': "Allow disk driver to be chosen per image

This allows for an image in glance to be annotated with a
property describing the desired disk / cdrom bus type.

eg

  # glance image-update \
           --property disk_bus=ide \
           --property cdrom_bus=ide \
           f16-x86_64-openstack-sda

Valid bus values vary per the libvirt_type setting:

 qemu/kvm: 'virtio', 'scsi', 'ide', 'virtio'
 xen: 'xen', 'ide'
 uml: 'uml'

DocImpact
Blueprint: libvirt-custom-hardware
Change-Id: Ibc20b843ceccf374eae246384a3f246cc1c52a28
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2013-01-25 19:18:41.000000000', 'message': "Allow disk driver to be chosen per image

commit_message:
Allow disk driver to be chosen per image

This allows for an image in glance to be annotated with a
property describing the required disk / cdrom bus type.

eg

  # glance image-update \
           --property disk_bus=ide \
           --property cdrom_bus=ide \
           f16-x86_64-openstack-sda

Valid bus values vary per the libvirt_type setting:

 qemu/kvm: 'virtio', 'scsi', 'ide', 'usb'
 xen: 'xen', 'ide'
 uml: 'uml'

Requesting an unsupported disk bus will cause the guest
instance to fail to launch.

DocImpact
Blueprint: libvirt-custom-hardware
Change-Id: Ibc20b843ceccf374eae246384a3f246cc1c52a28
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

subject: Refactor code for setting up libvirt disk mappings

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-21 17:58:51.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor code for setting up libvirt disk mappings

Currently the libvirt disk bus is fixed at the time the driver
is started. The get_guest_storage_config and _create_image
methods thus use some variables initialized in the libvirt
driver constructor to determine disk bus / dev name mappings.

It will shortly become possible to configure a different disk
bus per instance, which invalidates the current assumptions
in the code. A further complication is that the _create_image
and get_guest_storage_config methods needs to duplicate each
others logic for determining disk mapping.

To simplify the current code and make it more make flexible
introduce a new get_guest_disk_mapping method. This method
is responsible for examining the instance type and block
device info dicts and figuring out the complete list of
disks that will be attached to the guest & their optimal
disk bus + dev name values. This info is returned in a dict
and then passed to _create_image and get_guest_storage_config

Thus the logic for determining disk dev names is now isolated
in one single place.

Many, many test cases are added to try to thoroughly validate
the disk mapping code, since there are a huge set of possible
configurations the user may request, making it easy to break
the code accidentally.

Blueprint: libvirt-custom-hardware
Change-Id: I645e69fcc7088674f063f619b2acbbee94d7ba61
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-01-25 19:18:42.000000000', 'message': "Refactor code for setting up libvirt disk mappings

Currently the libvirt disk bus is fixed at the time the driver
is started. The get_guest_storage_config and _create_image
methods thus use some variables initialized in the libvirt
driver constructor to determine disk bus / dev name mappings.

It will shortly become possible to configure a different disk
bus per instance, which invalidates the current assumptions
in the code. A further complication is that the _create_image
and get_guest_storage_config methods needs to duplicate each
others logic for determining disk mapping.

To simplify the current code and make it more make flexible
introduce a new 'blockinfo.py' module in libvirt, and with
it a 'get_disk_mapping' method & associated helper APIs. This
method is responsible for examining the instance type and
block device info dicts and figuring out the complete list of
disks that will be attached to the guest & their optimal
disk bus + dev name values. This info is returned in a dict
and then passed to _create_image and get_guest_storage_config

Thus the logic for determining disk dev names is now isolated
in one single place, separate from the main driver code, so
it has no need to rely on state in the driver object.

Many, many test cases are added to try to thoroughly validate
the disk mapping code, since there are a huge set of possible
configurations the user may request, making it easy to break
the code accidentally.

Blueprint: libvirt-custom-hardware
Change-Id: I645e69fcc7088674f063f619b2acbbee94d7ba61
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

disks that will be attached to the guest & their optimal
disk bus + dev name values. This info is returned in a dict
and then passed to _create_image and get_guest_storage_config

Thus the logic for determining disk dev names is now isolated
in one single place, separate from the main driver code, so
it has no need to rely on state in the driver object.

Many, many test cases are added to try to thoroughly validate
the disk mapping code, since there are a huge set of possible
configurations the user may request, making it easy to break
the code accidentally.

Blueprint: libvirt-custom-hardware
Change-Id: I645e69fcc7088674f063f619b2acbbee94d7ba61
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Refactor code for setting up libvirt disk mappings

Currently the libvirt disk bus is fixed at the time the driver
is started. The get_guest_storage_config and _create_image
methods thus use some variables initialized in the libvirt
driver constructor to determine disk bus / dev name mappings.

It will shortly become possible to configure a different disk
bus per instance, which invalidates the current assumptions
in the code. A further complication is that the _create_image
and get_guest_storage_config methods needs to duplicate each
others logic for determining disk mapping.

To simplify the current code and make it more make flexible
introduce a new 'blockinfo.py' module in libvirt, and with
it a 'get_disk_mapping' method & associated helper APIs. This
method is responsible for examining the instance type and
block device info dicts and figuring out the complete list of
disks that will be attached to the guest & their optimal
disk bus + dev name values. This info is returned in a dict
and then passed to _create_image and get_guest_storage_config

Thus the logic for determining disk dev names is now isolated
in one single place, separate from the main driver code, so
it has no need to rely on state in the driver object.

Many, many test cases are added to try to thoroughly validate
the disk mapping code, since there are a huge set of possible
configurations the user may request, making it easy to break
the code accidentally.

Blueprint: libvirt-custom-hardware
Change-Id: I645e69fcc7088674f063f619b2acbbee94d7ba61
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Register root_helper in test_debug_commands and test_dhcp_agent

root_helper variable currently must be introduced with a call
to register_root_helper, not with a simple assignment.

Change-Id: I3e72379925a994acfb6defb24820ab63eab43957
Fixes: bug #1117240

commit_message:
heat tests : fix StackControllerTest name duplication

StackControllerTest appears twice in the run_tests.sh output,
since it's used for both the CFN and ReST API tests, so rename
the CFN testcase to make run_tests output less confusing

Change-Id: Iedf2e21ecd0b511eb93a11c2cf593dbfc1bcaca9
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-06 14:51:54.000000000', 'message': "Update to requests >= 1.0.0

The requests module dropped all configuration with the 1.0.0 release.
There's no danger_mode and no 'verbose'' mode. The former
shouldn't be necessary anymore and the latter can be done by setting
a different log handler for the request.logging root logger.

Change-Id: Ic0e1038e2a9ebb8f6e146c12b27793951c0f1e4e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Update to requests >= 1.0.0

The requests module dropped all configuration with the 1.0.0 release.
There's no danger_mode and no 'verbose'' mode. The former
shouldn't be necessary anymore and the latter can be done by setting
a different log handler for the request.logging root logger.

Change-Id: Ic0e1038e2a9ebb8f6e146c12b27793951c0f1e4e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Pin requests module more strictly.

requests.request() does not accept the keyword argument 'config'
(used on keystoneclient/client.py:339) after version 1.0.0.

Fixes bug #1116740

Change-Id: I0a778849ff44a76a2647aa46057fdb35401fae5f

Thanks for bearing with me.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-01-02 23:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The commit message appears to mis-state the patch effect. The warning is only emitted if a caller passes check_for_lock=True  to an RPC method, even when debugging is turned on. AFAICT, after this patch lands, there will be no new warnings in the logs, because it defaults to False... This seems counter-intuitive to me, but at least it should be clearly stated in the commit message. Perhaps add something like: "RPC calls can emit a warning if called with check_for_lock=True and debugging is turned on".'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-01-03 05:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-01-03 05:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Pls, Add that test. I still have some doubts about this implementation"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-01-09 21:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Mark -- I have just spent an hour trying to get openstack.common.local.store to work for me, and I'm just not smart enough.

The problem is that I want a persistant thread local value, and local.store is using weakref which means when the users of the list drop out of scope the list goes away. That's not what I want in this case. Worse, when the value has dropped out of scope hasattr() still returns True, but you get handed back None. Yet when you test for None with "is None", it returns False.

I'll upload my attempt now in case you can see something obviously wrong.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-01-09 21:28:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-09 21:31:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Emit a warning if RPC calls made with lock.

This patch will log a warning every time a RPC call is made while
a lock is held if the caller has requested it. This should help us
track down performance problems such as the security group refresh
problem recently found in nova.

RPC calls can emit a warning if called with check_for_lock=True
and debugging is turned on.

Sneaks up on bug 1063222.

Change-Id: Ice94093efb3cb95dd58b31d6ba817c7d505c15af

commit_message:
Be explicit about set_default() parameters

We probably only want to support people using set_defaults() for a
limited set of config options, so explicitly list those as parameters
to the method. This is what we do for rpc and log options too.

Change-Id: I3bfc5355e82eec17480b9547662e847dc0d74138

commit_message:
Remove duplicate DB options

sql_dbpool_enable and sql_connection_trace are declared twice.

Looks like this was a merge conflict when sql_dbpool_enable changed
from int to bool.

Change-Id: I553c5beea916e0ee296648342324fd53167c073a

commit_message:
Eliminate gratuitous DB difference vs Nova

Looks like this was an abritrary cleanup done as part of the import. It
conflicts with a more recent change in Nova.

We can move to using try_import() once we've killed the Nova copy
of this code.

Change-Id: I5c67d3fbd846a262feb724e26b14447a76561ae6

"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

Yes, i agree with mark.'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Of course, I have used update.py :)

Could we discuss the tests, please?

Copying of Oslo tests helps to reach the following goals.

1. Verify that copied and _updated_ code is still correct by itself. Code is modified by script that can occasionally make mistakes.

2. Verify that copied code works properly in the new environment. We have a bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1116290: a module was copied without its dependency. Unit test can detect such problems.

3. See the proper test coverage for Quantum. Oslo code that lacks unit tests in Quantum decreases coverage. That's unacceptable."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Why do we need the common unit tests?
It is possible to run these?'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Please use the update.sh script in Oslo to update the openstack.common code.  The script will properly update the modules in use by Quantum.  Additionally, we do not copy the Oslo test cases into the Quantum source tree as the copied code is already tested in Oslo.  This will make things easier down the road as Oslo moves modules from incubation into full python libraries.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

None of the other projects include tests for openstack.common and this is a known issue when reading the coverage reports.  Changes like this would have to be made on coordinated basis with Oslo and all OpenStack projects.  Alternatively, we can configure coverage to exclude the openstack.common files in its reporting.'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-02-06 09:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Synchronize code from oslo

Use commit bd5d9f08ecc3c1fade6dce809ee9edef1c226e54 created on
Jan 16 2013.

* Add processutils to quantum since impl_zmq depends on them.
* Add fixture to quantum since tests depend on it.
* Add unit tests for oslo code.

Implements: blueprint quantum-copy-oslo-tests
Fixes: bug #1116290

Change-Id: I3312f76bae6e31e22611f0c8809d686829e8eede

commit_message:
Add initial code to support policy.json implementation

We don't currently support a policy.json file like
other openstack services, so this code (mostly copied
from glance, then modified a bit) will allow us to
add policy-based authorization to out APIs fairly
easily

Change-Id: I5ad9f55b3d0979e2526953bdce8b8227852e4b72
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
add data injection on migrations

bring over the data injection from migrations from nova, which allows
us to inject sample data at every migration in the walk_versions, and
run a check after the migration to make sure that things look as we
expected.

Change-Id: I8b1d36f1363c12768dea228a3ecfafc1b919f083

commit_message:
Add security management to instance.

Since the novaclient support add/remove security groups to/on
instances, this is implemented in horizon now.

A new action is added to the instance table and it trigger a
model form to update security groups associated with the instance.

Implements blueprint add-security-group-to-instance

Change-Id: I51e7b7d119e6516d3ad9108b20a1e595c56dd216

[{'created': '2013-02-06 00:02:30.000000000', 'message': 'Correct parsing of volume metadata

Volume metadata supplied via the command line is incorrectly parsed,
converting each character into a key with None as the corresponding
value.  This bug fix corrects the parsing and also includes regression
tests when metadata is provided when creating a volume.

Change-Id: I8c093df59ea4de2e2a1b7cf3ac7c4624c159fb66
Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes
'}]
commit_message:
Correct parsing of volume metadata

Volume metadata supplied via the command line is incorrectly parsed,
converting each character into a key with None as the corresponding
value.  This bug fix corrects the parsing and also includes regression
tests when metadata is provided when creating a volume.

Change-Id: I8c093df59ea4de2e2a1b7cf3ac7c4624c159fb66
Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes

[{'created': '2013-01-29 16:07:57.000000000', 'message': "Remove Swift location/password from messages.

Updates several exceptions and log messages in the Swift backend
so that they don't include Swift location URI's which may contain
passwords when used in Swift single tenant mode.

Fixes LP Bug #1098962

Signed-off-by: Jamie Strandboge <jamie.strandboge@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <Dave.Walker@canonical.com>

Change-Id: Ia97a95ce6ed5d98a76515eea8817e309bcf0889a
"}]
commit_message:
Remove Swift location/password from messages.

Updates several exceptions and log messages in the Swift backend
so that they don't include Swift location URI's which may contain
passwords when used in Swift single tenant mode.

Fixes LP Bug #1098962

Signed-off-by: Jamie Strandboge <jamie.strandboge@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <Dave.Walker@canonical.com>

Change-Id: Ia97a95ce6ed5d98a76515eea8817e309bcf0889a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-23 22:55:58.000000000', 'message': 'Random lookups for MatchMakerRing

The matchmaker has been performing
lookups round-robin, client-side.

A better behavior is to do random
lookups. The old round-robin behavior is being
renamed to MatchMakerRoundRobinRing.

Also renames the existing test, adds
tests to confirm or deny randomness in
results.

Change-Id: I778420080a4aa86a19de110edb374ddd945941cd
'}]
commit_message:
Random lookups for MatchMakerRing

The matchmaker has been performing
lookups round-robin, client-side.

A better behavior is to do random
lookups. The old round-robin behavior is being
renamed to MatchMakerRoundRobinRing.

Also renames the existing test, adds
tests to confirm or deny randomness in
results.

Change-Id: I778420080a4aa86a19de110edb374ddd945941cd

commit_message:
Archiver utility

Supply an archiver to cleanup database rows
associated with deleted and scrubbed images

Made the core code database structure agnostic so that it could be
considered for oslo

Fixes Bug #1092188

Change-Id: Icb018ddaf8250fa4732e95aadc4ac12914031f27

The List Containers documentation mentions that container lists are
returned in sorted order, but the order in the example was not in
sorted order.

This patch fixes the example so output is sorted.

Also minor sentence rewording based on feedback from
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-object-storage/1.0/content/s_listcontainers.html#comment-420417779

Change-Id: Ia2ac91761e9b063fcfad38a2e35cbca08c5201e1
'}]
commit_message:
Sort container list by name

The List Containers documentation mentions that container lists are
returned in sorted order, but the order in the example was not in
sorted order.

This patch fixes the example so output is sorted.

Also minor sentence rewording based on feedback from
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-object-storage/1.0/content/s_listcontainers.html#comment-420417779

Change-Id: Ia2ac91761e9b063fcfad38a2e35cbca08c5201e1

I'm not certain I like the idea of a fundamental novaclient command like this being considered an extensionwhich is, afaiu, what contrib is for"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-01-22 02:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

What about a 'core' folder then (and not 'contrib'), piling up functions in shell.py doesn't seem so great either."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-01-22 16:27:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

That would make sense, but let's be careful about a proliferation of files in a directory, too :)  I'd say all related commands should be grouped together in a single file (e.g., image.py would contain all image-* commands).  "contrib" would be perfect for commands dealing with API extensions, such as the host or service extensions.  Finally, I have the vision of using entrypoints, to make adding new extensions easier; I imagine that's part of your intention too, but it's worth stating explicitly'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-01-22 18:21:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I thought nova client already had entrypoint support no? My goal was really just to start moving code into smaller files, which say allows me to remove said file if I know that api is more 'experimental', thus users at yahoo will not be as confused when said 'experimental' cli action doesn't work out so well. Boot of course won't be one of these (if boot doesn't work, we should all go home)."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-06 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-06 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Move the boot action to a contrib file so that boot code is isolated

Instead of making shell.py a large file, a more modular approach is
more manageable and provides more flexibility in removing or adding
certain 'core' commands as desired. Since nova client already supports
extension finding via the contrib/ directory, start moving the boot
action to said directory.

This involves:

1. Moving some code to utils that is shared between different functions
2. Moving the boot logic to the new boot module file and making sure it
   still passes tests and such

Change-Id: If9e50fdb17ed931476b0578b0dec246e45fb9d05

Hi,
There is a problem when getting back the extension list via the client.
I have the following when it is JSON (OVS plugin):
{u'extensions': [{u'updated': u'2012-07-20T10:00:00-00:00', u'name': u'Quantum L3 Router', u'links': [], u'namespace': u'http://docs.openstack.org/ext/quantum/router/api/v1.0', u'alias': u'router', u'description': u'Router abstraction for basic L3 forwarding between L2 Quantum networks and access to external networks via a NAT gateway.'}, {u'updated': u'2012-11-14T10:00:00-00:00', u'name': u'Port Binding', u'links': [], u'namespace': u'http://docs.openstack.org/ext/binding/api/v1.0', u'alias': u'binding', u'description': u'Expose port bindings of a virtual port to external application'}, {u'updated': u'2012-09-07T10:00:00-00:00', u'name': u'Provider Network', u'links': [], u'namespace': u'http://docs.openstack.org/ext/provider/api/v1.0', u'alias': u'provider', u'description': u'Expose mapping of virtual networks to physical networks'}]}
Whe using XML I get the following:
{'extensions': {'extension': {'updated': '2012-09-07T10:00:00-00:00', 'name': 'Provider Network', 'links': [], 'namespace': 'http://docs.openstack.org/ext/provider/api/v1.0', 'alias': 'provider', 'description': 'Expose mapping of virtual networks to physical networks'}}}
ERROR
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (15 inline comments)

The code is already in a very good shape thanks to the great work Yong and Gary have done.

I've verified collection marshalling/unmarshalling and null value setting work in a satisfactory way.

Just a few things attracted my attention:
- the introduction of Quantum XML types. 
   * Is this going in the direction of XML schemas? 
   * Do we really need to specify the type for each element (it seems the answer is no as I can submit requests without types and everything works fine)?
  * Is it normal that quantum:type, if specified in request body, seem to be completely ignored?

- The type declaration is missing from collections if the collection is populated. This seems slightly inconsistent.

- Should we have a configuration parameter for choosing the default format? (I'm not suggesting we should - I just would like to hear your opinion)"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (3 inline comments)

Yong,
thanks for your prompt reply.

It seems you're saying that if a list has elements, the facts that is a list is inferred from the presence of child elements, whereas you have to explicitly specify it's a list or dict when they're empty. I understand this logic, but I want to think a little bit more about whether this would make sense for a user. I think you've already analyzed the other Openstack APIs. What's their approach?

Another question I did not formulated correctly was about using quantum:type in request body. I've tried submitting several requests for a subnet playing with ip_version field.

I tried quantum:type='int' and everything was fine.
I then tried quantum:type='float' and it worked (I assumed because the validator converts to int anything which can be converted to int)
I then tried quantum:type='.krgjfj,gsfk' and was expecting an error... but then everything still worked fine. 

Can you tell me what's the logic here?"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Nachi,

my question was not really about serialization/deserialization. I've seen how it's done in nova, and I agree with your view of it.
Btw, the current approach you favour is the nova one, or this one?
I do not exclude that in the future our API might become more complex and require customization of serializer/deserializers.

My question was more about how to represent empty lists in XML.

for instance if you have a network with no subnets this patch currently does:

<subnets quantum:type='list"/>

but one might think of doing just:

<subnets/>

and let the API infer that this element is supposed to a list, and by being empty it means is an empty list.

another option would be:

<subnets xsi:nil="True"/>

But here the problem is that there won't be JSON equivalence because this would map to "subnets": null instead of "subnets": []

Finally one could say we should do:

<subnets quantum:empty="True"/>

As I haven't thought about XML for a long time, I would route the question to Yong, which has been actively developing XML support.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Hi Salvatore

In nova, they are implementing custom XMLDictSerializer/DeSerializer for each resources. The xml format looks pretty for users but burdan for developers.
Sometimes generic conversion from Json to XML looks not looks pretty, but we should choose strategy here.
I'm +1 for current way. Because user of the XML will use some program, and they are converting the XML to the internal objects. so consistant way to convert XML helps their coding."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Hi Salvatore

I think I got your point now.
IMO, <subnets/> is enough if we have schema.
( xml schema as example 
http://www.datypic.com/books/defxmlschema/chapter10.html )
(Zhongyue Luo looks working generation on WADL,
so we may generate this schema automatically also.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20465/)

Nova has atom schemas
https://github.com/openstack/nova/tree/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas

If we are not going to express the schema, I'm +1 to
<subnets  quantum:type='list"/>
because <subnets> could be dict.

My preference will be change whether I'm a user or developer. If I'm a user, I prefer nova way. 
However, we have json now, so Return On Investment of forces on XML feature looks not high. ( especially for me )
I agree with you we should remain XML customization way for each resources types.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (14 inline comments)

* Is this going in the direction of XML schemas?
It is a good question, I have no answer for it now.
   * Do we really need to specify the type for each element
If we are using Json format, json (dump and load) will keep the value and type. So if we need to pass all the test cases used in json format, we have to keep the value and type in XML format too.
  * Is it normal that quantum:type, if specified in request body, seem to be completely ignored? The type declaration is missing from collections if the collection is populated. This seems slightly inconsistent.

for <datakey/>, datakey can be empty list, empty dict or empty string. but for <datakeys><datakey/></datakeys>, we can tell datakeys is a list. So when the list is populated, we can have no quantum:type, but for empty list, we will have to use one.

Should we have a configuration parameter for choosing the default format? (I'm not suggesting we should - I just would like to hear your opinion)?

Format is for client to access API, if we cannot find the format information form client's request, we can resort to json, this is default format."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Explicit typing is needed for consumers of the XML quantum API.
Makes sense.

Typing is unnecessary on requests.
Makes sense.

Consumers will need quantum specific parsers for understanding XML, unless we provide some form of schema in the future.
That is acceptable.

We are in a need of typing explicitly composite entries such as lists or dicts because otherwise XML would give us no way to distinguish between empty and null.
Make sense.

I am ok to merge, also because the client issue turned out to be a non-issue.
If there's anything else that might need to addressed here, we can post bugs.

No need to hold up Yong for more time. I think he is probably considering sending some contract killers at my place to take me out at this stage."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Adds xml support for quantum v2 API.

Fixes bug 1007998.
blueprint quantum-v2-api-xml

Author: gongysh <gongysh@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I5f5407e767f8203f980b77075109845bc1553ed9
