Looks good to me'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-05 11:13:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

As a patch to make compute call out to conductor for bw_usage_get_by_uuids() instead of going to the DB, this looks good

It does feel convoluted, though

But have you considered another approach where compute just asks conductor to send notifications?

Also, unrelated but looking at _poll_bandwidth_usage() could we just do this:

   bw_counters = self.driver.get_all_bw_counters(instances)

and ship bw_counters off to conductor to do the rest?

-1 as a "it'd be nice to hear some more rationale" but I suspect you've thought this through and I'll quickly change to +2 :)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-05 14:56:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Probably because I've got a little bit of tunnel vision, and the pattern of passing around a conductor api to things that will need to do database accesses is developing into a relatively common practice. Since notifications themselves are not direct to the database, it probably seemed like adding them to conductor at that level would be a departure from what we've been doing thus far.

That said, it would probably be less convoluted to read (code-wise) even if the actual pattern of RPC messages would make a little less sense."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-05 15:05:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

It's actually the pattern of RPC messages I'm thinking about

i.e. compute asks conductor for current bw_usage, sends conductor an update to those and then later asks conductor again for current bw_usage in order to send a notification

versus

compute regularly sends conductor data for conductor to update bw_usage and whenever compute thinks a notification should be sent, it just asks conductor to send it"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-05 15:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I was actually referring to it looking like:

compute -> conductor -> notifier

instead of:

compute -> conductor
compute -> notifier

But anyway, I will change it :)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-05 19:01:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-05 19:31:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I likes, nitpick and question inline"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-05 19:37:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-31 02:49:59.000000000', 'message': 'Use conductor for notifications when necessary

This started out as a patch to replace the direct db call to
bw_usage_get_by_uuids() in nova-compute with a call out to the
conductor. This rippled into a larger change, given how deeply
in the stack that call is made.

Thus, this patch ends up making the sending of notifications go via
the conductor API. In an effort to avoid taking the RPC hit to
contact the conductor service, the local API is used in some places.
This results in an access pattern of:

- compute/manager -> uses configured conductor
- compute/utils -> uses configured conductor
- conductor/manager -> uses self (duh)
- compute/api -> uses local conductor (direct to db)
- scheduler/manager -> uses local conductor
- scheduler/driver -> uses local conductor

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I09f2652d4903f4d6036c6e3d74db063952341856

commit_message:
Refactor instance usage notifications for compute manager

This patch makes compute manager call notify_usage_exists() via the
conductor instead of directly, avoiding the direct database access
required to fetch bandwidth information. I initially just added
a notify_bw_usage() method to conductor, which just handled the
bandwidth part (which is the database hit). However, the metadata
payload part may be depended upon by custom stuff for periodic
notifications, so copying all that stuff as well made it a bunch
of duplicated stuff. Thus, I decided to just make it a direct proxy
for the compute_utils method.

Note that this is a bit of a departure from the previous pattern of
just proxying db interfaces in conductor, but I think the simplicity
gain is worth it.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I09f2652d4903f4d6036c6e3d74db063952341856

commit_message:
Use policy_file parameter in quantum.policy

quantum.policy depends on configuration parameter `policy_file'
that is defined in quantum.common.context.

Tests from tests/unit/test_policy.py fail without this import.

Fixes: bug #1116263
Change-Id: Iba4792acb0fb6b34b4ebc99fec7bc729cdb306da

commit_message:
Allow tools/install_venv_common.py to be run from within the source directory.

(Copy latest update from oslo)

Not doing this raised exceptions when it tried importing modules
that didn't exist in the path.

Fixes LP# 1116269

Change-Id: I3e2ed3ac96b51ec89def911054720d11bbcd9407

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-06 02:39:39.000000000', 'message': 'Cisco plugin cleanup follow up commit

A commit was made by Alex Xu (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20073) a day before the Cisco plugin
cleanup that led to some deleted files creeping back into the Cisco plugin. This commit backs out
the deleted files again.

Blueprint cisco-plugin-cleanup

Change-Id: Ibad452dc0497dad452a33d6f41c1785231cd5d5b
'}]
commit_message:
Cisco plugin cleanup follow up commit

A commit was made by Alex Xu (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20073) a day before the Cisco plugin
cleanup that led to some deleted files creeping back into the Cisco plugin. This commit backs out
the deleted files again.

Blueprint cisco-plugin-cleanup

Change-Id: Ibad452dc0497dad452a33d6f41c1785231cd5d5b

commit_message:
sync database connect changes from nova

bring over the changes from nova that let opportunistic testing
work on pg as well as mysql. Preparitory for data injection changes.

Change-Id: I368f8645cf1be477c25b0fbd1d35cff8859b615a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-25 19:18:40.000000000', 'message': 'Move libvirt volume driver tests to separate test case

The libvirt volume code is in a separate module from the
main libvirt driver code, so it makes sense for the test
suite to be separated too, to make it easy to quickly
run just the volume tests. This has the added advantage
of reducing the size of the enourmous test_libvirt.py
file which is becoming unwieldly.

Change-Id: I7c6134992055694798c4ec3217483bc3a41d89eb
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-01-29 13:19:38.000000000', 'message': 'Move libvirt volume driver tests to separate test case

commit_message:
Move libvirt volume driver tests to separate test case

The libvirt volume code is in a separate module from the
main libvirt driver code, so it makes sense for the test
suite to be separated too, to make it easy to quickly
run just the volume tests. This has the added advantage
of reducing the size of the enourmous test_libvirt.py
file which is becoming unwieldly.

Change-Id: I7c6134992055694798c4ec3217483bc3a41d89eb
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-01-25 19:18:38.000000000', 'message': "Move libvirt NFS volume driver impl into volume.py

For inexplicable reasons the NFS volume driver was put into a
different file than all the other libvirt volume driver impls.
The NFS code isn't so large & complex that it needs to be in
a different place than everything else. Move the code into
the main volume.py file.

To avoid breaking existing deployments, the original class
bad to be a trivial subclass of the new module. Any use of it
will trigger a deprecation warning. This allows time for users
to update their 'libvirt_volume_drivers' config (in the unlikely
event they have altered from the default setting).

Change-Id: I26d957e4ee33938b45dc1cad0fe32a2968520a4a

commit_message:
Move libvirt NFS volume driver impl into volume.py

For inexplicable reasons the NFS volume driver was put into a
different file than all the other libvirt volume driver impls.
The NFS code isn't so large & complex that it needs to be in
a different place than everything else. Move the code into
the main volume.py file.

To avoid breaking existing deployments, the original class
has to be a trivial subclass of the new module. Any use of it
will trigger a deprecation warning. This allows time for users
to update their 'libvirt_volume_drivers' config (in the unlikely
event they have altered from the default setting).

Change-Id: I26d957e4ee33938b45dc1cad0fe32a2968520a4a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Added Postgres CI opportunistic test case

Added test case and support functions for CI opportunistic testing
using a PostgreSQL database, as part of our postgresql as a first
class citizen effort.

rebased again on top of test migration with data framework

clean up debug, and ensure pg will fail to connect gracefully

fix previous migration test which was inserting a key by id, which
postgresql doesn't like, as it doesn't adjust the autoincrement
counter.

added driver to connection string for mysql

Updated comment to expose how to do this on pg easily

Fixes:
bug 1084567

Change-Id: If0bfe5cf748f6d5724d17082be6d18b6f96f6ee4

@Chmouel: could you have run into eventual consistency or the cached container_info ttl (60s by default)?'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-20 17:15:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

it doesn't seem like it, is it working for you @darryl on what kind of setup?"}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-01-21 03:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

WFM.  Are you sure your proxy.conf pipeline and quota middleware config are correct?

redbo@saio:~/swift$ swift post -m quota-bytes:50 quota_test
redbo@saio:~/swift$ truncate -s 100 some_file
redbo@saio:~/swift$ swift upload quota_test some_file
Object PUT failed: http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/AUTH_test/quota_test/some_file 413 Request Entity Too Large   Upload exceeds quota.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-01-21 03:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

redbo@saio:~/swift$ swift post -m quota-bytes:50 quota_test

redbo@saio:~/swift$ swift upload quota_test some_file

Object PUT failed: http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/AUTH_test/quota_test/some_file 413 Request Entity Too Large   Upload exceeds quota.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-21 09:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

(1 inline comment)

You right I had a messed up proxy-server config. One comment on setting the memcache key.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-22 20:07:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-01-24 02:12:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-01 06:37:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Mike, can you comment how this is better/different than http://www.zmanda.com/blogs/?p=1043 (code: https://github.com/AlexYangYu/StackLab-swift/tree/dev-quota ) ?

I see that yours is more container-based and his more account-based, yours only account-admin defined and his also having an overall cluster-admin definition with multiple levels of definition. Yours seems to reuse existing cache values and his separate cache values. Etc.

Mostly, I'm wondering if collaboration can happen here to satisfy both group's desires."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-01 06:41:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Also, see http://wiki.openstack.org/SwiftQuotas https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/903350 and https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/storage-quotas'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-02-01 07:08:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

FWIW: There is as well:

https://github.com/cschwede/swquota

I have started an implementation a couple of weeks ago (before knowing about all the other ones) and it's mostly the same as alex quota middleware."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-02-01 09:05:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sure!

This one's fundamentally a user feature, to set limits when using formpost or if you delegate access to a container for another user with acls or whatever.

The others are fundamentally cluster administration features, to limit the size of accounts (something I don't think we (RAX) has much interest in?).

I guess they could be crammed into one middleware so you have only one thing called "quotas", but they are targeting different people.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-02 00:42:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Unless there's a lot of duplicated code, I'd be happy with two middlewares unambiguously named something like container_quotas and account_quotas (or whatever).

They both seem useful, but for different use-cases."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-02-04 07:18:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-04 08:32:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

[{'created': '2013-01-15 23:52:56.000000000', 'message': 'Basic container quotas

Add a new middleware implementing some basic container quotas.

Quotas are subject to several limitations: eventual consistency, the timeliness
of the cached container_info (60 second ttl by default), and its unable to
reject chunked transfer uploads that exceed the quota (though once the quota
is exceeded, new chunked transfers will be refused).

However, they get most of the way to container quotas fairly inexpensively.

Quotas are set by adding meta values to the container, and are validated when
set:

  X-Container-Meta-Quota-Bytes: Maximum size of the container, in bytes.
  X-Container-Meta-Quota-Count: Maximum object count of the container.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I77cfbf6dc231a2e522bd67328e4c082424a93eee

commit_message:
Basic container quotas

Add a new middleware implementing some basic container quotas.

Quotas are subject to several limitations: eventual consistency, the timeliness
of the cached container_info (60 second ttl by default), and its unable to
reject chunked transfer uploads that exceed the quota (though once the quota
is exceeded, new chunked transfers will be refused).

However, they get most of the way to container quotas fairly inexpensively.

Quotas are set by adding meta values to the container, and are validated when
set:

  X-Container-Meta-Quota-Bytes: Maximum size of the container, in bytes.
  X-Container-Meta-Quota-Count: Maximum object count of the container.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I77cfbf6dc231a2e522bd67328e4c082424a93eee

messages:
[{'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2013-01-22 15:02:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

As modals are written in JS, obtaining information about objects is more difficult because it depends on the way that information is displayed. This is, ordering and/or naming matters.

This fix doesn't work for those tables that don't have a Name column placed in the second cell counting from left to right, and a clear example of this can be seen on Admin > Volumes panel where the table has the Name field in the 4th column.

Horizon is extendable, so I can't figure out how to do if the user chooses another way to call things and/or decides not to assign a name.

I thought of two ways to solve this
1- Setting and standard and forcing the user to put a name in the second column.
2- Search for a name and, if exists, display it (highly deficient)

The most important challenge with this bug is to keep scalability, and it's not a trivial thing.

I'd love to hear your suggestions.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-22 15:23:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

There is another issue, when using the table actions: if I select one (or more) checkboxes on the instances page and click "Terminate", I see " Confirm Terminate Instances "" ". The double-quotes around nothing shouldn't be there IMO. If we decide to only handle single row actions for now, that's fine, but then we probably shouldn't display the double quotes at all when 'name' is empty.'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2013-01-25 12:42:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2013-01-25 12:50:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

Current version works with more than one object and appends the list of names to the body instead of the title for a more comfortable reading.

As the previous set, it won't work if the table is ordered in other way.

I'm currently working to add support for this, checking for a column containing the string 'Name'. Is no 'Name' column is provided, the dialog will behave as usual - without displaying any name -.

Every suggestion is welcome and really appreciated"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-25 13:08:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Confirmation dialogs lists selected objects name

Notifies the user the name of the objects
the operation is going to affect.

Volume deletion, images deletion and
instances termination are some of the operations
that will display this information in
confirmation dialog.

Fallback mode: tables with no field containing
'Name' string won't list selected objects.

Change-Id: I7a200a69e3318de3206920bb4594c58a60499cde
Implements: Add selected objects name to confirmation dialogs
Fixes: bug #1055217

commit_message:
Change "select all" checkbox behaviour while checkboxes is
checked/unchecked.

While all checkboxes in one table is checked, the 'select all'
checkbox will be selected automatically. The 'select all' checkbox
will be deselected while any checkbox in the table is unchecked.

Fixes bug 1108136.

Change-Id: Ieacdcd83e84622e854648254b9bfa0269c157862

commit_message:
Added hacking.py support to pep8 portion of tox

Usage: tox hacking
Once we have the source compliant we can merge this with the pep8 task.

There is a known problem with stevedore's dynamic module loading.

Change-Id: Ibfff87d85ecc81b1ce6dd994a135ab30b75d4d1e

API extension to merely format the metadata and return it, leaving

commit_message:
Refactor server password metadata to avoid direct db usage

This refactors the set_password() method in the server_password
API extension to merely format the metadata and return it, leaving
the job of updating the database to the caller. In the API extension
case, the update can be done immediately against the database as
before. In the case of the metadata API handler and the xenapi virt
driver making the call, conductor can be used to update the instance's
system_metadata, thereby avoiding a direct database access.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I0563feaa97d768a96f950c148b1dbf51c356c4ac

The current login form allows the browser to automatically complete the authentication credentials based on saved values. This presents a security risk as described in bug 1116168.

commit_message:
Implements the autocomplete attribute on the login form

The current login form allows the browser to automatically complete the authentication credentials based on saved values. This presents a security risk as described in bug 1116168.

This commit adds the autocomplete attribute to the form tag for the login page to prevent this behaviour.

Change-Id: I1b218b2db787c1581134f9bd80904c161d20b4c3
Fixes: bug #1116168

commit_message:
Fix footer count update

Commit 4632aa58ae9d1874f559031f592e2873c0fb4f64 broke the update
due to an incorrect selector.

Also adds a qunit regression test for footer count update.

Fixes bug #1114667.

Change-Id: Iee9a8743957e86985fcab70f7716e244e214b43e

commit_message:
Remove image_type column from images/snaps tables

Removes the column from the projects dashboard, but
leaves it in the admin dashboard, since there is no
split between images/snapshots there.

Part of blueprint organised-images-display.

Change-Id: Ia94798a4b0cc13a9b37831bf638e429dd29c3993

commit_message:
Disable allocate IP button if the current number of floating IP is equal
or larger than the amount allowed by the quota.

Fix bug 1109098.

Change-Id: I0841da494252618aef8b20c7c67429fddd0278f4

commit_message:
Update 3PAR driver

Added support for get_volume_stats()
Add sanity checks for:
    Ensure the CPG lives in the Domain that's configured.
    On 3PAR systems, the create volume from snapshot has to be
    the same size. The driver now checks to make sure that they
    are the same size.
    Now using volume and snapshot id's instead of the names.
    Checking for optional fields before using them(i.e. description).
    Added a new method get_ports() to gather the active array ports.
    Fixed inline comments, added a space between the comment and # sign

Change-Id: Ie2aed38c6349bb5ee8bbea4d0928cd606427a26f

commit_message:
Allow tools/install_venv_common.py to be run from within the
source directory.

Not doing this raised exceptions when it tried importing modules
that didn't exist in the path.

Change-Id: I10e02cd9ce6beb8fdf822dd397688450ac6981a1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-04 15:16:41.000000000', 'message': "Fix import for install_venv.py

On systems that don't use devstack the nova directory
doesn't automatically get added to the python path. This
breaks tools/install_venv_common.py which imports from
nova.openstack.common. This fixes the issue by manually
adding the nova root directory to the python path before
tools/install_venv_common.py is imported.

Change-Id: I8a3df02a51c2c777d8f47cb8bc72d0644ae47095
"}]
commit_message:
Fix import for install_venv.py

On systems that don't use devstack the nova directory
doesn't automatically get added to the python path. This
breaks tools/install_venv_common.py which imports from
nova.openstack.common. This fixes the issue by manually
adding the nova root directory to the python path before
tools/install_venv_common.py is imported.

Change-Id: I8a3df02a51c2c777d8f47cb8bc72d0644ae47095

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 18:58:19.000000000', 'message': 'Be smarter when figuring out broadcast address

In most cases, broadcast is set when IP is set, but sometimes
it can be ommitted. In those cases we should figure it out based
on CIDR, and not assume it. This pulls in python ipcalc module.

Change-Id: Ia8c07898ddf0eb19f5d552a304d8f38915fc3560
Fixes: bug #1090621

commit_message:
Be smarter when figuring out broadcast address

In most cases, broadcast is set when IP is set, but sometimes
it can be ommitted. In those cases we should figure it out based
on CIDR, and not assume it.

Change-Id: Ia8c07898ddf0eb19f5d552a304d8f38915fc3560
Fixes: bug #1090621

commit_message:
Pin docutils to 0.9.1.

Docutils 0.10 breaks manpage generation in sphinx 1.1.3. A fix to
sphinx has been merged, but not yet released (scheduled for dec
24-31). In the mean time, we should pin docutils to 0.9.1.

(Also add myself to Authors to allow merge tests to pass)

Fixes bug 1091333.

Change-Id: I0157c6d662ae8ceecb1440d245cfa06def1101db

'nova coverage-report' returns an error because nova server returns

commit_message:
Fix default format of 'nova coverage-report'

'nova coverage-report' returns an error because nova server returns
error if the format is HTML and combine is False.
And 'nova coverage-start' and 'nova coverage-report' do it now.

After applying this patch, we can avoid this problem and text format
report is created when we use 'nova coverage-report'

Fixes bug 1110972

Change-Id: Ib3d05453de638157152a50ea814e44e6cbc19348

I agree with Dolph. Keystone is used by many services. Without requesting any feedback from anyone we keep on adding features which affect others. It should be a separate blueprint and let others comment on it.

1)I believe swift relies or projectName/projectId being unique.

2) In v2, users just need to know userid,password and tennantId or tenantName to get token

3) In v3, in some cases, users need to know  username,password,private domain, scoped tenant name, scoped tenant's domain name. It is difficult to explain all these features to end user. commit_message:
Use real capabilites for all volume type instead of fake ones

Replace fake capabilities requirements in all volume type extra
spec with real capabilites that Cinder/iSCSI driver would report.

Previous fix in I0e226c14df95097cfdf653f0a13a45b8acff39da isn't
complete, this change should cover all.

fix bug: 1098017

Change-Id: Ie59b11de5e8673e0414b08c5570a14f5cf69a246

commit_message:
Fix provider_location column add for PSQL

Migration 006 (commit 690cae58e6bbac5758ea2f7b60774c797d28fba5)
didn't work properly for postgres,
this patch corrects the upgrade by ensuring the execute
is performed and the value is initialized to None.

Since we haven't released a milestone etc with this migration in the
code it should be safe to just fix it here and submit.

Change-Id: I10a09aed3470c35c8ebbe22f29aa511592167c35

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 10:23:27.000000000', 'message': 'Fix inability to delete volumes in error state for NetApp driver

While using NetApp 7-mode storage box to create volumes, if the volume
is not created on the storage box (possibly due to wrong/missing
options in cinder.conf file), the volume goes in error state, and when
one tries to delete the volume, an exception was raised which made
the volume go in error_deleting state, which is unrecoverable. This
commit quiesces that exception, resulting in successful removal of the
volume entry from the volume table.

Fixes bug 1090169

Change-Id: I0a25b71ad03e7f7acf58df3952e074ff164b82ff
'}, {'created': '2013-02-05 11:09:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix inability to delete volumes in error state for NetApp driver

While using NetApp 7-mode storage box to create volumes, if the volume
is not created on the storage box (possibly due to wrong/missing
options in cinder.conf file), the volume goes in error state, and when
one tries to delete the volume, an exception was raised which made
the volume go in error_deleting state, which is unrecoverable. This
commit quiesces that exception, resulting in successful removal of the
volume entry from the volume table.

Fixes bug 1090167

Change-Id: I0a25b71ad03e7f7acf58df3952e074ff164b82ff
'}]
commit_message:
Fix inability to delete volumes in error state for NetApp driver

While using NetApp 7-mode storage box to create volumes, if the volume
is not created on the storage box (possibly due to wrong/missing
options in cinder.conf file), the volume goes in error state, and when
one tries to delete the volume, an exception was raised which made
the volume go in error_deleting state, which is unrecoverable. This
commit quiesces that exception, resulting in successful removal of the
volume entry from the volume table.

Fixes bug 1090167

Change-Id: I0a25b71ad03e7f7acf58df3952e074ff164b82ff

commit_message:
Use the same Keystone client instance for pollster

This provides a Keystone client instance for all pollsters running on the
central agent.

Blueprint: pollster-global-keystone-auth

Change-Id: I83d8157683410d2eaa093c35d4071f7ed0e22ebd
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

Config object supports masking values when writing out if the secret
flag is set on the option definition.  This change flags all
oslo-incubator options containing a password.

Change-Id: I78451c4fdfdb3d6e28a7bd5f35d1c4c9a1b2be99
'}]
commit_message:
Mark password config options with secret

Config object supports masking values when writing out if the secret
flag is set on the option definition.  This change flags all
oslo-incubator options containing a password.

Change-Id: I78451c4fdfdb3d6e28a7bd5f35d1c4c9a1b2be99

subject: Bump version requirements for requests
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-02-05 16:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-05 16:17:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I believe we're holding requests<1.0 due to incompatibilities between 1.0 and the version python-novaclient is written against.  I believe there's a pending patch that upgrades to using requests 1.0, but that entails quite a bit more patching than just updating the version restriction in pip-requires.  Can you justify why this patch will work without modifying novaclient code to comply with the 1.0 API?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-05 16:20:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20119"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2013-02-05 16:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Because other openstack projects are using 1.1 and can cause conflicts when installing them due to different versions of requests required.'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2013-02-05 16:24:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Bump version requirements for requests

Bump up version requirements for requests to standardize
on version 1.1 so it doesnt create conflict with other
openstack projects.

Change-Id: Ic584b976b306c104da06f38c6d79911c404210ed
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2013-01-31 19:53:31.000000000', 'message': 'Only unpack replies on caller.

Opening the messages is unnecessary
in ZmqProxy, given that the msg_id
is already in the (zmq-specific)
message envelope. Additionally,
by not opening the messages, we
save a bit of complexity.

This avoids having to deserialize and
reserialize messages in ZmqProxy,
a necessary improvement for trusted-messaging
and should also have a markable performance
benefit.

Also cleans up msg_id handling a bit.

Change-Id: I31f365b9e1040503206b1d8320a0266a8121c821

is already in the (zmq-specific)
message envelope. Additionally,
by not opening the messages, we
save a bit of complexity.

This avoids having to deserialize and
reserialize messages in ZmqProxy,
a necessary improvement for trusted-messaging

Change-Id: I31f365b9e1040503206b1d8320a0266a8121c821

commit_message:
Only unpack replies on caller.

Opening the messages is unnecessary
in ZmqProxy, given that the msg_id
is already in the (zmq-specific)
message envelope. Additionally,
by not opening the messages, we
save a bit of complexity.

This avoids having to deserialize and
reserialize messages in ZmqProxy,
a necessary improvement for trusted-messaging
and should also have a markable performance
benefit.

Also cleans up msg_id handling a bit.

Change-Id: I31f365b9e1040503206b1d8320a0266a8121c821

- http://logs.openstack.org/20624/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/560 : SUCCESS

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-01-28 17:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there an easy way to create a test case for this change?'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-28 17:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-28 18:12:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Doug: in python 2.x, bytes() and str() seem identical enough that I'm not sure how to detect the difference. There very well be a way, but I don't presently know it. Point being that in 2.x, if str() did not work, the tests as they are would have already failed.

In Python 3, they're unique enough that the old code would trigger an exception. That is, the tests as they are presently with the code at present, would fail. Very possibly, it would still fail after this patch, but for other reasons ;-)

This patch is a cleanup for clarity and readability. Also, I have a patch in the pipeline that will pass integers and the necessary cast to bytes will (hopefully) be more clear than a cast to str."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-29 15:59:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Hmm, would have +2ed but for some reason I can't

It's not a draft or WIP ... strange"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-29 16:14:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Use bytes instead of str

Clarifies that str is the wrong datatype
for passing messages over ZeroMQ. This
distinction will be more important with
the eventual migration to Python 3.0,
but (I hope) this also helps clarify WHY
typecasting is performed before sending messages.

Change-Id: I4dd4661a5730a24ba7b514520b0429b721b05e9c

options containing a password.

commit_message:
Mark password config options with secret

Config object supports masking values when writing out if the secret
flag is set on the option definition.  This change flags all cinder
options containing a password.

Change-Id: Ia0b203417774797c1fe1eaf2946453c9b2509b98

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-05 15:00:43.000000000', 'message': 'Add size validations for /tokens.

Updates /tokens controller so that it explicitly checks the max
size of userId, username, tenantId, tenantname, token, and password
before continuing with a request.

Previously, when used with the SQL keystone backend an unauthenticated
user could send in *really* large requests which would ultimately
log large SQL exceptions and could thus fill up keystone logs on the
disk.

Change-Id: I0904d307bf79a3bf851ac052c11101f8380a12a7
'}]
commit_message:
Add size validations for /tokens.

Updates /tokens controller so that it explicitly checks the max
size of userId, username, tenantId, tenantname, token, and password
before continuing with a request.

Previously, when used with the SQL keystone backend an unauthenticated
user could send in *really* large requests which would ultimately
log large SQL exceptions and could thus fill up keystone logs on the
disk.

Change-Id: I0904d307bf79a3bf851ac052c11101f8380a12a7

commit_message:
Add size validations to token controller.

Updates token controller so that it explicitly checks the max
size of userId, username, tenantId, tenantname, token, and password
before continuing with a request.

Previously, when used with the SQL keystone backend an unauthenticated
user could send in *really* large requests which would ultimately log
large SQL exceptions and could thus fill up keystone logs on the
disk.

Change-Id: Ie7e3a958829f99f080e66582bdf558cded70248c

Why do you define a public method create_role_ref that is only invoked inside _create_ref, a private module method?
Could not the code have just been inserted in _create_ref?

Guessing role_ref captures the lengths of role_id and tenant-id so as  to not constrain the characters allowed for role, tenant and user-ids.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-05 16:09:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

malini-k-bhandaru		5:06 AM

"Why do you define a public method create_role_ref that is only invoked inside _create_ref, a private module method? Could not the code have just been inserted in _create_ref?"

Not a bad idea.  The LDAP code in general need some cleanup, and is not as understandable as I would like.   This is a bug fix, and I was trying to keep it as minimally invasive as possible, but I will keep your advice in mind when we tackle cleanup.


"Guessing role_ref captures the lengths of role_id and tenant-id so as to not constrain the characters allowed for role, tenant and user-ids."

You might be right. I did not originally write that code, but rather ported it over from an earlier version. I am not sure that I want to keep it this way long term.  However,  Building LDAP DNs is a messy business no matter how you do it.  It is a bizarre combination of array concatiation and key/value pair naming that makes it hard to do with out a helper object.  I might be building that in Havana.'}]

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
More robust mocking of nova conductor

Update the nova notifier test to use the fake RPC implementation
to avoid hangs more completely.

Also update the test to mock out the entire conductor API object
in the manager created by the test, instead of mocking individual
methods.

Change-Id: I741a609bd3ddfeb302d39b1c61a4b6896de2bf47
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

- http://logs.openstack.org/20684/4/check/gate-ceilometer-python27-folsom/566 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-02-04 10:23:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Doug, I added the new method to the PollsterBase class, however, I can't mark it as static or class method in the PollsterBase abstract class. 

The reason I want to keep this as class/static method is, the caller may want to know the counter names that the class support before creating an instance for it. Seems current abc (<3.2 version) does not support it. Hope this is acceptable."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-02-04 14:45:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It's safe to make that a regular method, instead of static. The plugins will all be instantiated before we start calling methods on them."}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-02-04 22:52:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Agree that it's safe now to make it a regular method, I just thought it will be better to make it static or class since it's an attribute of the class instead of instance. And in future, we may want to decide whether to create the pollster instance depending on requirement of pipeline (although it's not in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20794/ ).

Any idea."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-02-04 23:30:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The idea with all of the plugins is that it should be safe to instantiate them to ask them questions. That way we don't have import side-effects for plugins that need to create resources before they can decide if they should run or not, for example. This new method needs to be part of the API, and the abc library doesn't support abstract class methods, so let's just make it a regular abstract method to ensure that it is enforced as part of the API."}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-02-05 00:40:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

For "let's just make it a regular abstract method to ensure that it is enforced as part of the API". The latest patch already achieved this. With the definition in abc class, all subclass have to implement it.

The only missing part is, there is no guarantee that this method is implemented as static method. If  that's ok, then possibly we don't need to changes the patchset, since it already meet our requirement.'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:17:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I noticed a usage when reviewing jd's patch as in ceilometer/objectstore/swift.py that have both staticmethod and abstractmethod to decorator. Although the staticmethod decorator does not gurantee subclass will implement the function as static method, it does give a good hint.

Updated the patch accordingly."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

[{'created': '2013-02-04 22:10:05.000000000', 'message': 'Update V2 API documentation

This changeset adds a Sphinx extension for auto-generating
much of the documentation for a Pecan/WSME API from the
comments and docstrings in the source code. It also updates
the V2 API to include more documentation for API endpoints
and the data types used in the API, as well as sample data
for generating the JSON and XML examples in the output
documentation.

Change-Id: I1bde7805550aa86e9b64495b5c6034ec328479e5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

much of the documentation for a Pecan/WSME API from the
comments and docstrings in the source code. It also updates
the V2 API to include more documentation for API endpoints
and the data types used in the API, as well as sample data
for generating the JSON and XML examples in the output

Change-Id: I1bde7805550aa86e9b64495b5c6034ec328479e5

commit_message:
Update V2 API documentation

This changeset adds a Sphinx extension for auto-generating
much of the documentation for a Pecan/WSME API from the
comments and docstrings in the source code. It also updates
the V2 API to include more documentation for API endpoints
and the data types used in the API, as well as sample data
for generating the JSON and XML examples in the output
documentation.

Change-Id: I1bde7805550aa86e9b64495b5c6034ec328479e5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Mock more conductor API methods to unblock tests

We don't have a conductor to report back to about
action events, so mock out those methods.

Change-Id: If30d913d49bd6b7d08f25385c3a44afb275d0d04
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Define root_helper variable under the [AGENT] section

Fixes bug 1105523

The patch set adds 2 new functions:
1. register_root_helper - this enables all wanting to use
the root_helper variable. This is under the section AGENT.
2. get_root_helper - this is a helper function that returns the
root_helper. This should be used when the application used to
have the root_helper defined under the section DEFAULT. This
ensures backward compatability.

Change-Id: Iba72c4fc89ba5329ea045483287012f82b306250

commit_message:
Allow for specifying nfs mount options

Fixes bug 1113042

Adds a new config option:
    nfs_mount_options=None (Default)

When not None, anything set here will be passed as -o <options> to
the mount command. The default behavior is to do exactly as we are
doing today and relying on the OS/kernel defaults.

Change-Id: I935ae6f4d96c20904b7132fe8c6dfd3cbe089e51
Flags: DocImpact

commit_message:
Print useful message when keystoneclient is not installed

client.py now prints a useful message when trying to use Auth version
2.0 and keystoneclient is not installed.

Fixes bug 1102322

Change-Id: I6ed83610fd6e8c79c2dc5cf05db377a843cab1d5

[{'created': '2013-02-04 15:43:41.000000000', 'message': 'Mark password config options with secret

Config object supports masking values when writing out if the secret
flag is set on the option definition.  This change flags all
python-keystoneclient options containing a password.

commit_message:
Mark password config options with secret

Config object supports masking values when writing out if the secret
flag is set on the option definition.  This change flags all
python-keystoneclient options containing a password.

Change-Id: I1ffc9727ab66c7acc6d4cf8e5870bb32f5e68b67

commit_message:
Make it possible for openstack-CI to run tests

Per http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface we enable all
of the commands except build_sphinx because we do not have any sphinx
documentation as of yet. Includes babel support though there are no
properly internationalized strings just yet.

Change-Id: Iae6e6b3f9e605106f4575196fa5527d2187255df

[{'created': '2013-01-24 19:30:56.000000000', 'message': 'The root directory should be the loction of run_tests.sh, not before that.

If you checkout the keystone client code to a given directory with say
a name not keystone-client the code should still work, this means that
said code should still function when ran from run_tests.sh.

Change-Id: Iaf914fa86a63ac9ef9e9aac647f97967a60c04db
'}]
commit_message:
The root directory should be the loction of run_tests.sh, not before that.

If you checkout the keystone client code to a given directory with say
a name not keystone-client the code should still work, this means that
said code should still function when ran from run_tests.sh.

Change-Id: Iaf914fa86a63ac9ef9e9aac647f97967a60c04db

commit_message:
Add help about the id 'auto' for flavor-create

The id parameter of 'nova flavor-create' can be specified 'auto' now.
But the help document is not mentioned about that. This patch fixes it.

Fixes bug 1112154

Change-Id: I6df71746a0036c6b6d05467e28343fad2972c128

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Make cells_api fetch stashed instance_type info

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

commit_message:
Teach resource tracker about stashed instance types

This removes instance_type-related database queries from the
resource_tracker.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: Ia5dd407181fa733cc81d3ce03edc1c06c2aae762

subject: Fix up instance types in sys meta for resizes

(1 inline comment)

overall fine, but unstash just bugs me as a name, lets clear that up before taking this in."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-04 18:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Well, I was just about to go and make this change, and decided to argue it.

I think 'delete' evokes too much of a feeling that we're actually purging information from system_metadata about the instance_type. Since it takes a required list of prefixes, I think the implication is that it only deletes previously-stashed instance_type information, and isn't just a general-purpose delete function. Since it's the exact opposite of the stash function (which is properly-named, IMHO), I think "unstash" is a good name for it and certainly more finger-friendly than "delete_stashed_instance_type_info()".

Mind reconsidering?'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-04 20:35:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-04 20:48:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fix up instance types in sys meta for resizes

This adds code to the resize paths to update the system_metadata
with new (or reverted) flavor information so that resized instances
are consistent with normal ones.

It also stashes the new and old instance_type information in system_metadata
during resize, which allows us to avoid database lookups for type
information at finish, confirm, and revert time.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I7f74ef8131be7a60e3a844fdf00fdeb3683f1317

commit_message:
Compress logs before Jenkins can copy them.

Compress the various logs devstack gate collects before Jenkins can copy
them. This reduces the headroom necessary for all of the files on the
logs server by a significant amount. Also, to save even more space on
the logs server stop copying the screen logs as syslog appears to
capture all of this data.

Change-Id: I78f5bfc436c288d52aac2083ba8c24cff4a67648

[{'created': '2013-02-01 23:25:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fix incorrect device name being raised.

The issue here is that `device`, which is passed in, also being used as
an index variable in a for-loop, overwriting the original value of
`device`, meaning we raise with an incorrect value.

The solution is to use a different name for the for-loop version of
`device`.

commit_message:
Fix incorrect device name being raised.

`device` was being used as an index variable in a for-loop, overwriting
the value that was passed in, causing the in-use exception to point to
the wrong device.

The solution is to use a different variable name, in this case
`device_path` as the index variable.

Other cleanups include:

* Update to test to ensure exception message points to correct device

* Simplify for-loop by using set to collect letters, instead of a list
  which is later turned into a set

* Added blank lines to improve readability in particularly dense
  sections

* Made `req_letters` and `_get_unused_letters` singular because they, in
  fact, are.

Change-Id: Iad33f7ff0c109c6cea5df84d54c11cee750bf19d

commit_message:
VMware VC Compute Driver

blueprint vmware-compute-driver

Add VMwareVCDriver for VMware vCenter Server and Cluster support
DocImpact

Nova conf:
compute_driver=vmwareapi.VMwareVCDriver
vmwareapi_cluster_name=VMware cluster name

Change-Id: Ia8bd40a912971ceb20b0f8015a5fcc42e525828d

First one is that this puts *a lot* of db access back into compute nodes, so in this form it will definitely not get accepted at this moment.

Second is that I have to question the justification of such hacky decorator magic (reimplementing the getcallargs instead of getting the instance directly for kwargs is nothing short of hacky, unless I am missing why this cannot be safely retrieved from kwargs as I believe no other decorator applied changes this value). I believe this can be implemented in a much cleaner way.

Based on this it's a -1 from me, sorry about that."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-12 13:58:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@ndipanov

I'm aware that db access is being removed but am not up to date on exactly how that is being achieved.  I'll look into that and move it out.

To your second point, it should be as easy as pulling it from kwargs but unfortunately is not.  Sometimes instance is in args rather than kwargs, and there's no way to ensure that a caller puts it in kwargs.  So even if I fix all current uses it could break in the future, though maybe that's acceptable.  Lines 231-235 in compute/manager.py address this issue in the instance faults wrapper as well, but in that case it's the bottom most wrapper and can use the easier to implement and more magical method it uses.  I agree that what I've done is hacky and not a preferred way of doing things so I'm willing to move to the slightly more fragile method of requiring instance to be in kwargs."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-12-12 14:21:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Andrew,

Look for the no-db-compute blueprint and the patches it references. TL;DR is that there is a conductor service that handles db acces and you should RPC your data to it and let it do db for you.

As for the second point - I see your point about the wrap_instance_fault decorator, and I thinks it's hacky as well (isn't making an educated guess which one of the args/kwargs is the instance just as safe, since we could have a arg named other than simply 'instance'. It seems like an undocumented convention to call the arg isntance although one that is unlikely to be broken). 

Let's see what the other reviewers say on this. The decorator does seem well tested, and you obviously dug deep into possible edge cases."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-12 15:43:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-12-12 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Nice work'}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-01-31 06:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Andrew,

Just to clarify, in my last message, when I said 'Read through' I meant "I have read through the changes, but not thoroughly enough to vote"

The code looks really good. I think it is very cleverly implemented.

However I'm voting it down in its current state.

The reasons are:

 * It should have at least an option to turn the thing on and off (more on this below)
 * It needs tests for the compute API. To ensure that db.action_start is called correctly for each compute node method


Reasons an on/off switch option should be included:

 * The change will imbue a cost on the infrastructure of the openstack install.
 * The cost may be quite high. I guess that adding several  DB inserts for every reboot will likely double DB load compared to having it turned off.
 * I imagine a good amount of users will have it turned off most of the time. The main use case for turning it on will be for debugging.
 * One shouldn't have to pay the cost for something they don't want to use.'}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-01-31 06:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: No score

(1 inline comment)

Hi Andrew,

This message replaces my last message, which had wrong stuff in it :) because I confused nova/compute/api.py with nova/openstack/api/compute.py

----

Just to clarify, in my last last message, when I said 'Read through' I meant "I have read through the changes, but not thoroughly enough to vote"

The code looks really good. It is very cleverly implemented. Good job Andrew :)

The one comment in the code is just to help my own understanding.

I would like to see an on/off switch added.

I saw you were going to add it later. If it were to be added as part of this commit, I'd definitely give it a +1. In its current implementation, I have 'no score'.

Reasons an on/off switch option should be included:

* The change will imbue a cost on the infrastructure of the openstack install.
* The cost may be quite high. I guess that adding several DB inserts for every reboot will likely double DB load compared to having the feature turned off.
* I imagine a good amount of users will have it turned off usually. The main use case for turning it on will be for debugging.
* One shouldn't have to pay the cost for something they don't want to use.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-01-31 16:25:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

Hey matiu,

I greatly appreciate your feedback, but I have to disagree with you a little bit.

I don't think an on/off switch for the entire feature is going to work, because it is motivated by more than just being useful for debugging.  One of the things that this enables is the ability to not set an instance to ERROR anytime something goes wrong.  There are certain actions, like changing the admin password or some failures to resize, where the instance is not put into an unusable state but it's set to ERROR so that a user knows something has gone wrong.  In those cases it would be better to leave the instance as ACTIVE and let the user see the status of their action through this new mechanism.  If this is optional then we can't get away from setting an instance to ERROR, because this may not be turned on, or we complicate that logic to behave differently based on whether this is on or not.

If there are certain areas where performance becomes an issue and a toggle makes sense I would be happy to add it.  But I think that making the whole thing optional has some, IMO big, drawbacks so I hesitate to add that without knowing for sure that it will cause issues.  And looking in particular at reboot I see at least 4 other db inserts, one of which potentially goes over RPC to conductor, so I'm not yet worried about performance implications.  But it's something we'll definitely keep an eye on as this gets into real usage."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-01-31 21:17:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

I like the patch in general. Just a couple of questions about making the patch simpler"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-01-31 21:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback Johannes.  I added a followup question for you.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-01-31 22:08:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

Thanks for the answers. I'm still worried about one part..."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-01-31 22:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

I share your concern, but tried to explain what led to here.  There are other options though.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-01-31 23:56:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I'm a little wary of adding more decorators which is why I brought it up, but it's not really an issue of correctness or potential future bugs.

So I'd say 2 is my preference. I'm worried about bugs in the future and the existing implementation has the potential to catch people off guard.

Looking back at the previous comments, I agree it's a little hacky, but I'd prefer something that fails obviously versus something fails silently."}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-02-01 01:09:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (2 inline comments)

It should have the fix to support non-keyword instance passing.

I'm not so concerned any more about the DB load. The features that this patch enables in the future, especially making servers not be stuck in error state are very valuable. That will reduce the workload of a lot of openstack supporters.

It's a great job. Well done Andrew. Nearly there."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-02-01 17:53:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Johannes, I understand the concern about more decorators but in this case I think it's justified.  I've gone back to using a more robust mechanism for grabbing the instance, which should cause an easy to track down problem if a developer breaks it somehow.

matiu, thanks for you comments."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-02-01 17:54:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 18:24:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Record instance actions and events

Record when an action is initiated on an instance, and the underlying
events related to completing that action.

Actions will typically occur at the API level and should match what a
user intended to do with an instance.  Events will typically track what
happens behind the scenes and may include things that would be unclear
for a user if exposed, but should be beneficial to an admin/deployer.

Adds a new wrapper to the compute manager.  The wrapper will record when
an event begins and finishes from the point of view of the compute
manager.  It will also record errors if they occur.

Blueprint instance-actions

Change-Id: I801f3e796d091e146413f84c2ccfab95ad2e1af4

list_instances(self, defined=False) - to list all instances including defined'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-16 00:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

adding parameters to methods is breaks the interface just like adding a new method in most cases. I think the defined parameter can be removed. See my comment inline.  I still think you should be able to do a driver.check_can_live_migrate_destination and pass the instance to find out if you are on shared storage (followed by the cleanup command). Checking to see if the instance files exist before running the cleanup also seems unnecessary. Just run destroy again regardless. That should allow you to remove the other parameter you added.'}, {'account_id': 1782, 'date': '2012-08-16 16:25:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-16 16:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

Vish -- thanks for the quick turnaround. We have fixed list_instances (removed 'defined'). Regarding shared storage (on_disk) -- the original host would be typically down, so we just need to check whether instance files are there. In the context of live migration, the method which checks availability of files on a node is check_can_live_migrate_source (after a temp file is created on destination). We could consider using it, but the semantics is different, so it might be too confusing (we are not in live migration, and it is definitely not the source node). Please, advise whether adding an argument or a new method is preferable (or if you have other suggestions). 

To summarize, we introduce the following changes to current nova interfaces:
1. 'recreate' and 'host' parameters in rpcapi.rebuild_instance()  -- driver needs to know whether it is a regular rebuild or recreate and what is the target host in case of recreate
2. 'recreate' parameter in compute.manager.rebuild_instance()  -- driver needs to know whether it is a regular rebuild, when a new VM is deployed from a fresh image, or we just need to define the VM using existing instance files (on shared storage)
3. 'on_disk' parameter in driver.instace_exists() -- when recovering a VM located on shared storage, we need to check whether files associated with an instance exist on the target host
4. 'destroy_disks' parameter in driver.destroy() -- in init_host, when zombie VMs are removed, the instance files must not be removed if they are on shared storage and are in use by a new VM running elsewhere

In all the 4 cases above, we can either add parameter (like we did, which seems backwards compatible and less disruptive), or add new methods.

We have also moved 'evacuate' and tests from servers to admin_actions."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-16 23:17:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

1 and 2 seem fine.

3 and 4 seem like they know too much about the underlying driver. The zombie cleanup seems like it needs to know too much about what is going on in the driver. Really you are trying to do two things:

a) verify that the instance can be moved here. So perhaps you should explicitly call a method called can_create_here(instance) or something similar. This can be implemented in the driver as a check to see if the instance files are accessible.

b) cleanup data from zombie instances. I see the need for this parameter to destroy. I don't currently see a way around it. It could be done with a new method but this is ok. Perhaps another reviewer can come up with a better solution."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-08-17 15:59:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Work In Progress

This patch did not get a FFE for Folsom, so mark it as a WIP since it needs to wait for Grizzly to open.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-09-01 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

Is this patch set working? I'm gonna try to rebase it against stable/essex as my boss currently desperately wants it.

Is that worth the trouble and possible? 
Also I thought this was working already in stable/essex using migrate, which uses resize to get it on a new host? Resize in turn calls prep_resize of the scheduler, which will find a new host for the VM.
But after testing migrate myself, I noticed it doesn't work when the host is failed, which is exactly why this patch is needed right?"}, {'account_id': 5319, 'date': '2012-09-19 07:46:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I applied the patch to Essex release, its working really well. Had to change a lot though to make it work. Many function and method names were different, and changed it to use instance_uuid by default. RPC was also different.

Would it be useful if I upload the patch so others can easily apply it?

Some issues with this patch(original patch):
* instance = self.db.instance_get(context, vm) seems this won't work because it needs an id, and not the vm string used in libvirt.
I changed it to this:
filters = {'name': vm, 'deleted': False}
instance = self.db.instance_get_all_by_filters(context,                                                             filters)[0]

* Several times there is a log with locals() in it, for some reason those log messages won't turn up on the log at all."}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-09-19 14:50:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

[{'created': '2012-08-09 18:30:57.000000000', 'message': 'rebuild-for-ha

This implements blueprint rebuild-for-ha

Evacuation of VM from a failed host for HA.
New api supports recreate/rebuild modes. With shared storage,
VM is recreated on the target from disk.
Otherwise, rebuild from original image is performed.

Change-Id: I877b29928c922fa366fb85deb85ddfc72d97daf8
Co-authored-by: Oshrit Feder <oshritf@il.ibm.com>

'}, {'created': '2012-12-13 15:36:47.000000000', 'message': 'rebuild-for-ha core functionality

This implements blueprint rebuild-for-ha

Evacuation of VM from a failed host for HA.
New api supports recreate/rebuild modes. With shared storage,
VM is recreated on the target from disk.
Otherwise, rebuild from original image is performed.

* new evacuate method in compute.api
* new recreate flag in rpcapi.rebuild
* added functionality to clean evacuated instances on host init
* change in manager.rebuild to rebuild instance using existing disk

DocImpact

Change-Id: I877b29928c922fa366fb85deb85ddfc72d97daf8
Co-authored-by: Oshrit Feder <oshritf@il.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Adds evacuate method to compute.api

Added decorator to check whether the vm is suitable to be evacuated.
The decorator validates that vm host is down.
The new evacuate method calls rebuild with the recreate flag and
specified target host.

This implements blueprint rebuild-for-ha

DocImpact

Change-Id: I877b29928c922fa366fb85deb85ddfc72d97daf8
Co-authored-by: Oshrit Feder <oshritf@il.ibm.com>

subject: cruft reduction - compute admin guide
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-04 06:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/gate-openstack-cli-guide/check/295/cli/quick-start : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-02-04 16:23:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Always like cruft removal. Did the 64-bit support actually change or do you just think "everyone" knows those parts?'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2013-02-04 23:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

* There are no packages for 32-bit - so if you're going 32 you're immediately outside the realm of the guide (which is primarily package based) for install purposes.

* We're aiming for best practices, rather than all-crazy-cases, yes? In which case, due to: "the only feature-complete, production-supported host environment is 64-bit Linux" - this is the aim

* I guess my overarching motivation in this cruft cleaning is: hinting at every single obscure possibility clutters the guide. If we can reduce some of those corner cases, we can avoid some of our maintenance nightmare at the same time as hopefully giving readers a better deployment experience.

Thoughts very welcome!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I agree that for the install guides, we really want to focus on the common case.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:24:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/gate-openstack-cli-guide/gate/304/cli/quick-start : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-05 01:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Update to latest oslo-version code.

This pulls in the bugfix patch that handles the usecase wher a packager
running tests from a tarball.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-02 13:40:23.000000000', 'message': "if running full tempest, don't run smoke seperate

because of some of the ways we setup resources at the class level
for tempest the timing for:

    smoke + !smoke > all

This will be even more true with testr.

So instead of running smoke, then running all of not smoke, we
should just run full.

Change-Id: I8cf93dd2ce3c30cacdb564d6d0bb9a1a39067a35
"}, {'created': '2013-02-02 15:05:19.000000000', 'message': "if running full tempest, don't run smoke seperate

because of some of the ways we setup resources at the class level
for tempest the timing for:

    smoke + !smoke > all

This will be even more true with testr.

So instead of running smoke, then running all of not smoke, we
should just run full.

Change-Id: I8cf93dd2ce3c30cacdb564d6d0bb9a1a39067a35
"}]
commit_message:
if running full tempest, don't run smoke seperate

because of some of the ways we setup resources at the class level
for tempest the timing for:

    smoke + !smoke > all

This will be even more true with testr.

So instead of running smoke, then running all of not smoke, we
should just run full.

Change-Id: I8cf93dd2ce3c30cacdb564d6d0bb9a1a39067a35

commit_message:
Allow description fields to be translated in schema

The description fields for the schema elements were hard coded
english strings but are intended for end user consumption and
should be translation enabled.

bug 1115495
Change-Id: Ic3b16af75a41a186640762d0c7af787f1bf49ad0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-22 15:18:16.000000000', 'message': "Merge LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver class into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required, thus a dedicated driver for OVS is no longer required.

The LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver class functionality is merged into
LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility with
the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver class
is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver stub will be
deleted in the Hxxxxx release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: Iac79e0880b6fbcca0fd8cc26b59d23e579b947fa
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Merge LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver class into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The LibvirtGenericVIFDriver class can use the 'vif_type' mapping
field to determine whether an OVS network configuration is
required, thus a dedicated driver for OVS is no longer required.

The LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver class functionality is merged into
LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility with
the Folsom release, the existing LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver class
is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver stub will be
deleted after the Havana release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: Iac79e0880b6fbcca0fd8cc26b59d23e579b947fa
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-07 18:45:14.000000000', 'message': 'Merge QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver into LibvirtBridgeDriver

The QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver no longer has any quantum
specific code in it, so the original LibvirtBridgeDriver
can be used with Quantum directly. This has the advantage
that libvirt firewall filter parameters are correctly
configured.

For backwards compatibility make the QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver
class be a trivial subclass of LibvirtBridgeDriver. Log a warning
that it will be removed in the Hxxxx release series.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I19664f20e5137f495513999214f66279292bda58
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-01-07 22:24:27.000000000', 'message': 'Merge QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver into LibvirtBridgeDriver

specific code in it, so the original LibvirtBridgeDriver
can be used with Quantum directly. This has the advantage
that libvirt firewall filter parameters are correctly
configured.

For backwards compatibility make the QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver
class be a trivial subclass of LibvirtBridgeDriver. Log a warning
that it will be removed in the Hxxxx release series.

The only difference between the Quantum bridge driver and the
new generic VIF driver bridge support is the name of the bridge.
This is now provided via the VIF mapping parameter, so there is
no need for the dedicated Quantum VIF driver for bridging. This
This has the advantage that libvirt firewall filter parameters
are correctly configured.

The QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver class functionality is merged into
LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility with
the Folsom release, the existing QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver class
is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver stub will be
deleted in the Hxxxxx release.

commit_message:
Merge QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver into LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

The only difference between the Quantum bridge driver and the
new generic VIF driver bridge support is the name of the bridge.
This is now provided via the VIF mapping parameter, so there is
no need for the dedicated Quantum VIF driver for bridging. This
This has the advantage that libvirt firewall filter parameters
are correctly configured.

The QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver class functionality is merged into
LibvirtGenericVIFDriver. For backwards compatibility with
the Folsom release, the existing QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver class
is made to inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and directly
call the bridge specific setup APIs. This eases migration to
the new VIF impl during the Grizzly deployment lifecycle, with
an expectation that the QuantumLinuxBridgeVIFDriver stub will be
deleted after the Havana release.

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I19664f20e5137f495513999214f66279292bda58
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-02-04 20:01:12.000000000', 'message': "Fix imports for install_venv_common.py

On systems that don't use devstack the project directory
doesn't automatically get added to the python path. This
breaks tools/install_venv_common.py which imports from
openstack.common. This fixes the issue by manually adding
the tools/install_venv_common.py's parent directory to the
python path before tools/install_venv_common.py is imported.

Change-Id: Ic8528f460f96315149724312e24f4de7c42dfa32
"}]
commit_message:
Fix imports for install_venv_common.py

On systems that don't use devstack the project directory
doesn't automatically get added to the python path. This
breaks tools/install_venv_common.py which imports from
openstack.common. This fixes the issue by manually adding
the tools/install_venv_common.py's parent directory to the
python path before tools/install_venv_common.py is imported.

Change-Id: Ic8528f460f96315149724312e24f4de7c42dfa32

commit_message:
clean the unittest2.

We have used the testtools instead of unittest2. So when we run
tempest, if it require unittest2 packages. We should look into
why it need unittest2, and can we use testtools instead? Not just
add unittest2 in pip-require simply. And new test added into
tempest should use testtools other than unittest2.

Change-Id: Ica02779b16434f9d64b0bb655c44251301b94492

commit_message:
Make isolated volume tests have unique tenant

The isolated credential volume tests need to have unique tenant
names otherwise when the test_volume_types_extra_specs tests are
run in parallel they step on each other.

Change-Id: I7f6d81af97cd48522ea52477a3afe9564f717d89

commit_message:
lxc: virDomainGetVcpus is not supported by driver

virDomainGetVcpus is not supported by the libvirt lxc
driver, so it results in a nasty traceback. Trap the
error and return the number of vcpus.

Fixes LP: #1106960

Change-Id: I641b1ec2c40169e6ba3d7913542bbeda3587f0c4
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

subject: Support listing endpoints for an object.

Okay, so as a client, I make a request: GET http://my-swift-proxy/object_endpoint/a/c/o

I get back a JSON array with URLs like this:

    ["http://10.51.3.48:6002/sdf/228925/a/c/o",
     "http://10.51.3.151:6002/sdd/175893/a/c/o",
     "http://10.51.3.124:6002/sdn/99175/a/c/o"]

What in the heck am I, a Swift client, going to do with these URLs? Clients can't talk directly to the object servers; they're on a separate network or firewalled off or separated in some other way.

Either I'm misreading the code (entirely possible!), or this middleware only works if your Swift cluster exposes the backend servers to the world.'}, {'account_id': 4987, 'date': '2012-12-10 19:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Samuel - this is indeed intended for consumption by services that live in the same cluster. The original target is Hadoop integration as referenced in the blueprint: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-8545 , but I can easily imagine other uses.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-11 01:09:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This will need some docs for certain. Explaining why one might use it, and if it's really just for internal proxies and whatnot. For most things like this, it seems like just distributing the ring and doing direct ring lookups would be the usual course, avoiding the extra network-based lookups. But maybe I'm missing something since there are no docs as of yet."}, {'account_id': 4987, 'date': '2012-12-11 12:51:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4987, 'date': '2012-12-11 12:54:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2012-12-11 12:54:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Nit: Copyright should be 2012.

Nit: You can 'from swift.common.utils import json' instead of the other ImportError catch thing (we're slowly trying to eradicate that old way). 

Completely optional, just an idea: Make the url_prefix and conf value that way somebody could instead use some random string as a bit of "security through extreme obscurity" on this.

You shouldn't raise the swob HTTPxxx exceptions to outside your __call__ or it returns a 500 and a stacktrace to the client. You can instead just 'return HTTPMethodNotAllowed()(env, start_response)' for instance.

The use of start_response and return body seems a bit odd considering the other usage of swob. For the 400, you could 'return HTTPBadRequest("No account specified")(env, start_response)' for instance. And 'return Response(json.dumps(endpoints))(env, start_response)' for the other instance.

You'll have to add this to doc/source/misc.rst as well, to get the docs to be included the Sphinx build. Something like this: (and I have no idea how Gerrit might butcher this paste, but I'll try):

    diff --git a/doc/source/misc.rst b/doc/source/misc.rst
    index 0c0d607..1b1a3bc 100644
    --- a/doc/source/misc.rst
    +++ b/doc/source/misc.rst
    @@ -172,6 +172,13 @@ Proxy Logging
         :members:
         :show-inheritance:
     
    +List Endpoints
    +==============
    +
    +.. automodule:: swift.common.middleware.list_endpoints
    +    :members:
    +    :show-inheritance:
    +
     CORS Headers
     ============'}, {'account_id': 4987, 'date': '2012-12-12 10:09:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-12 10:51:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

In general, for Jenkins failures:

If it's in the tempest-devstack-gate job, it's almost certainly not anything to do with a change to Swift, as Swift's involvement is minimal. In that case, type "recheck" in a review message, and Jenkins will re-run the tests.

If it's in a job other than tempest-devstack-gate, then it's very likely to be something in the submitted change. Fix it and submit a new patch set.

In this case, it appears to be devstack, so typing "recheck" will kick Jenkins, like so:'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-12-21 18:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:
