'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-21 21:40:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

The response to a non-GET of /endpoints/a/c/o is missing its "Allow" header.

RFC 2161 section 10.4.6 says "The response MUST include an Allow header containing a list of valid methods for the requested resource."

If you do something like

   $  curl -v -XBREW -H "X-Auth-Token: blahblah" http://saio:8080/AUTH_test/ima/little/teapot

you'll see a header in the response that looks like "Allow: HEAD, GET, PUT, POST, COPY, OPTIONS, DELETE". This middleware's 405 response needs to include that header as well.

swift/proxy/server.py:220 may be useful as an example.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-29 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-29 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2013-02-04 19:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Eugene will no longer continue working on this change, so the new Change Request has been created for this feature. Please, take a look on it - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21015/ ,

P.S. list_endpoints now returns Allow: GET header in case of unsupported HTTP method.

Thank you.'}]

commit_message:
Support listing endpoints for an object.

Implements blueprint list-endpoints.

DocImpact: new middleware list_endpoints.

Change-Id: I6b1ba25b86d7e1b6cb20a8236ba7318547a2001a

commit_message:
Import Oslo's common rootwrap to Cinder

Import oslo-incubator's rootwrap, which contains all the new
features and bugfixes that were pushed to nova-rootwrap earlier
in this cycle, including logging support and path search.

Implements bp: cinder-common-rootwrap

Change-Id: I68cbb788a3dda58dc146933be190146607b48801

None is not needed

fixes bug 1106441

'}]
commit_message:
LibvirtBridgeDriver now LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

fixes bug 1106441

In Grizzly, inheritance is such that LibvirtGenericVIFDriver does
the same job as LibvirtBridgeDriver, and there are long term (H/I)
plans to retire libvirtBridgeDriver. This patch updates the config
reference.

Change-Id: Ie571b86f8559218f0c7a54f273b56a24c4543afd

- http://logs.openstack.org/18020/5/check/gate-ceilometer-python27-folsom/302 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-12-28 16:28:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(9 inline comments)

This design is going in a different direction than what I expected. It may just be that I don't understand, but I want to talk it through before approving these changes.

The main issue is I don't understand the way the pipeline manager organizes its mapping of pipelines around a tuple of counter names, instead of tracking which pipelines want data from each individual counter. I'm concerned that the current organization will not work properly for both of the cases we have when we ask the pollsters for counters. 

In the main use case, we will be asking pollsters for data at a regular interval (probably a separate interval per pipeline). The second case occurs when a resource is being deleted and we want to collect the last bit of data immediately before allowing the delete to continue. In that case, we are driven by the resource id, and the event may come at any time, not just the regular periodic interval.

For the periodic case, we want to collect data for only the appropriate counters for the given resources, so I think we will want to modify the main loop to work on resources and pipelines instead of resources and counters. We may end up with multiple pipelines with the same (or close) period, so we want to be able to publish the same counters without asking for the statistics repeatedly. That implies caching the counter values somewhere between the code that computes them and the pipeline publishing code, and maybe that's why PipelineManager.publish_counters() takes an iterator? It isn't clear, because that method seems to assume the counters coming in are somehow related to one another (they all go to common pipelines, for example).

For the event-driven case, we want to collect data for all counters that apply to the given resource and send each counter through all of the pipelines that are configured to receive that type of counter. We need a mapping between counter names and pipeline objects to make that efficient, but we could also just go through all of the pipelines and ask if it supports the given counter before calling the publish method."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-13 10:30:59.000000000', 'message': 'Muitiple publisher pipeline framework

With multiple publisher support, a meter data can be sent to multiple
conduit, like message bus, CW API etc.

Pipeline framework transfers the data from pollster and notification
handler to the publisher, through multiple pipelines.
Each pipeline is composed of 1 or more transformers and one or more
publishers. The transformer transformed the data, like summary, drop,
delta etc.

For bp: multi-publisher

Change-Id: Iff8b85d724eb6358d147b8a8431837934d913c88
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Multiple publisher pipeline framework

With multiple publisher support, a meter data can be sent to multiple
conduit, like message bus, CW API etc.

Pipeline framework transfers the data from pollster and notification
handler to the publisher, through multiple pipelines.
Each pipeline is composed of 1 or more transformers and one or more
publishers. The transformer transforms the data, like summary, drop,
delta etc.

For bp: multi-publisher

Change-Id: Iff8b85d724eb6358d147b8a8431837934d913c88
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Optimize floating ip list to make one db query

Currently the floating ip code will make 2 db queries for every
single associated floating ip when list is called. This adds
a couple of joins in the db layer to avoid having to make so many
calls. This dramatically improves floating-ip-list. On a simple one
node test the time dropped from 2.35 seconds down to 0.5 seconds
for a list with 10 associated floating ips.

Part of blueprint optimize-nova-network

Change-Id: I0571013393b2dbad42c15e690c7783d5ceecaeb2

commit_message:
Mark password config options with secret

Config object supports masking values when writing out if the secret
flag is set on the option definition.  This change flags all nova
options containing a password.

Change-Id: I538c93bac736c317822b5d78b53c4181b2009b49

commit_message:
Fix incorrect logs in network

These are negligible typo issues, so a bug isn't filed on LP.
We should log floating ip address and details of networks, rather than "|%s|"
or "|[<nova.db.sqlalchemy.models.Network object at 0x5227510>]|", so moving the
log of floating ip address to the correct location and converting the
sqlalchemy Network object to dict for logging.

Change-Id: I815bf01100d234401114bfd80fd9aa644d1a3447

commit_message:
Remove setuptools_git from setup_requires.

This is a mistake for the case where someone is using setup.py from a tarball.
We need it installed for sdist making only, which is why it's in test-requires.

Change-Id: Ib79cbe3e638c0772325872d4bb30be26c7b91391

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-30 11:46:11.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint quantum-quota-basic-tests quota tests

This change adds a new file containing 3 tests which perform a simple
quota check for each of network, subnet, and port. Each test loops
creating a [network,subnet,port] until either the max permitted number
of iterations is reached, or a quota exceeded exception is hit.
For the test to pass, the quota exceeded exception must be hit.
Note - the default port quota is 50 - however this is more than the
default private subnet will support for tempest tests, hence I have
modified tempest.conf.sample to change tenant_network_mask_bits to a
slightly larger value to enable the quota limit to be hit.

Change-Id: I19670e8675e713fc9bcdf70df980fba0ba420558
'}]
commit_message:
blueprint quantum-quota-basic-tests quota tests

This change adds a new file containing 3 tests which perform a simple
quota check for each of network, subnet, and port. Each test loops
creating a [network,subnet,port] until either the max permitted number
of iterations is reached, or a quota exceeded exception is hit.
For the test to pass, the quota exceeded exception must be hit.
Note - the default port quota is 50 - however this is more than the
default private subnet will support for tempest tests, hence I have
modified tempest.conf.sample to change tenant_network_mask_bits to a
slightly larger value to enable the quota limit to be hit.

Change-Id: I19670e8675e713fc9bcdf70df980fba0ba420558

commit_message:
Fixed documentation of the cinder shell command.

Updated README.rst and shell.rst to match changes
in the cinder command and novaclient README.rst.

Change-Id: Ifaa53d5c06e6d7d8e3d4d858672717954303bea7
Fixes: bug #1074125

commit_message:
Skip tests if cinder is not installed

The test_capacity_filter_passes_infinite and test_capacity_filter_passes_unknown
tests were failing when cinder is not installed. Skip the tests like the other
tests for test_host_filters.

Change-Id: I5ebfa2dca05b6e89a12e3153598bf4699da888de
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2013-02-03 18:29:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix the type of Model's deleted field.

The deleted field should be boolean type.
To work with postgresql well, the value of it should be a boolean
type, not 0/1.

Change-Id: I9e517a91aab4172f7ae8b609cd6f19f3ff9aa2c7
Fixes: Bug #1114485
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the type of Model's deleted field.

The deleted field should be boolean type.
To work with postgresql well, the value of it should be a boolean
type, not 0/1.

Change-Id: I9e517a91aab4172f7ae8b609cd6f19f3ff9aa2c7
Fixes: Bug #1114485

commit_message:
Fix incorrect logs in network manager

These are negligible typo issues, so a bug isn't filed on LP.
We should log floating ip address and details of networks, rather than "|%s|"
or "|[<nova.db.sqlalchemy.models.Network object at 0x5227510>]|", so moving the
log of floating ip address to the correct location and converting the
sqlalchemy Network object to dict for logging.

Change-Id: I59e0f4d9b7b3c89b13f1246fa101666b90c11373

commit_message:
Fixes duplicate "-s" option in run_tests.sh

The "-s" option in run_tests.sh is shared by
"--no-site-packages" and "--smoke".
Proposing "-n" for --no-site-packages.

Fixes: LP bug #1111748
Change-Id: I1784107994a0ddc50aa47608250092429f9a2764

[{'created': '2013-02-03 21:45:39.000000000', 'message': "Allow for not cloning from github.

Github is unusable for automated testing because it's down too often, causing
false negatives. It's also the default place you want to grab stuff from in
general. So allow things to override the base location from which they clone
globally.

A follow up patch should also figure out how to respect a pre-cloned/
pre-prepared set of local repos so that elements can be driven by things
like Zuul.

Change-Id: I2d9bdd98d58f55998bd0838e4d6966cb888de792
"}]
commit_message:
Allow for not cloning from github.

Github is unusable for automated testing because it's down too often, causing
false negatives. It's also the default place you want to grab stuff from in
general. So allow things to override the base location from which they clone
globally.

A follow up patch should also figure out how to respect a pre-cloned/
pre-prepared set of local repos so that elements can be driven by things
like Zuul.

Change-Id: I2d9bdd98d58f55998bd0838e4d6966cb888de792

Looks good to me ... some notes on my thoughts, let me know if I'm off on any of this:

1) This isn't actually required, but it is convenient, since it means that if you're running cinder-volume on the same node as nova-compute, it may prevent the same nfs export from being mounted twice.

2) I tried to think of a case that this could cause a problem with upgrades, but I couldn't think of one.  It seems safe."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-03 10:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Although merged, you are right on with this Russell, nothing was broken and both your points are correct.  I discovered the difference when running everything on a single node.

The main point of the change for me was operational.  It's much easier to correlate both ends (Cinder and Nova) if the mount points are identical. Basically, I was confused when I saw two different mounts and figured we could potentially save someone else from the same confusion with a simple change.

Thanks for the approvals."}]

commit_message:
Make NFS mount hashes consistent with Cinder

Cinder is using a different hash method for mount point uniqueness.
This change makes Nova's hash method identical.

Change-Id: I64e0200ae341fa90cf66b86fa3cb11ad02e773c6

Looks good to me.

I have one minor nit to pick: the variable named "unique_tiers_by_tier_len" caused me some confusion when I was reading the code; it wasn't clear to me that its contents are only for this particular partition, whereas the stuff in tier2children is for the entire ring. The comparison on line 694 had me scratching my head, wondering how there could ever be more candidate_tiers of length N than unique tiers of length N.

You might consider naming it something like "used_tiers_by_tier_len", as that makes it more clear (at least to me) that it only refers to the current partition. Either that, or sprinkle more comments in there.

If you want to do that, cool. If not, I'll submit a follow-on patch at some point in the future; I won't hold up this diff over a variable name.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-01-21 21:07:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-01-21 21:07:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

[{'created': '2013-01-15 16:40:19.000000000', 'message': "Optimize the ring builder's _reassign_parts() method.

Another ring builder optimization.  Profiling revealed hotspots in many
calls to min() and list.sort() in _reassign_parts().  That method didn't
get exercised in my last optimization pass because that pass targeted a
rebalance where nothing really moved around.

This time, I wrote a script which created a fresh ring, added a bunch of
devices, did the initial balance, deleted some devices, balanced, and
added some more back in.

Results from homebrew Python 2.7.3 on OS X 10.8.2 Macbook Pro
(bare-metal):

 BEFORE:
 Using part-power = 18, adding 600 devices, removing 100, then adding 300 more...
 NOT Profiling to 'initial_balance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 131.33s
 NOT Profiling to 'deleting_200_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 25.67s
 NOT Profiling to 'first_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 62.00s

 AFTER:
 Using part-power = 18, adding 600 devices, removing 100, then adding 300 more...
 NOT Profiling to 'initial_balance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 28.04s
 NOT Profiling to 'deleting_200_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 9.35s
 NOT Profiling to 'first_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 16.41s

The driver script I used is available here:
https://gist.github.com/adb982aec6f0709f1273

Change-Id: I17e270acb12b5e4d4bbb1e34d8867dea90678961

commit_message:
Optimize the ring builder's _reassign_parts() method.

Another ring builder optimization.  Profiling revealed hotspots in many
calls to min() and list.sort() in _reassign_parts().  That method didn't
get exercised in my last optimization pass because that pass targeted a
rebalance where nothing really moved around.

This time, I wrote a script which created a fresh ring, added a bunch of
devices, did the initial balance, deleted some devices, balanced, and
added some more back in.

Results from homebrew Python 2.7.3 on OS X 10.8.2 Macbook Pro
(bare-metal):

 BEFORE:
 Using part-power = 18, adding 600 devices, removing 100, then adding 300 more...
 NOT Profiling to 'initial_balance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 131.33s
 NOT Profiling to 'deleting_200_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 25.67s
 NOT Profiling to 'first_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 62.00s

 AFTER:
 Using part-power = 18, adding 600 devices, removing 100, then adding 300 more...
 NOT Profiling to 'initial_balance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 28.04s
 NOT Profiling to 'deleting_200_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 9.35s
 NOT Profiling to 'first_rebalance.prof'
   wall-time delta: 16.41s

The driver script I used is available here:
https://gist.github.com/adb982aec6f0709f1273

Change-Id: I17e270acb12b5e4d4bbb1e34d8867dea90678961

'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-31 17:17:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like the idea of cleaning up a small client like this with only one method. But, the problem with doing this is that console_output doesn't belong in the servers_client. Console_output is a self contained extension and not part of servers. I think that the console_output_client belongs in a separate client like we do with the other extension clients."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-31 17:26:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Console is belong to the server as the other server actions.

Console does not have a dedicated create,delete,get list ..., requests.

We normally have dedicated class for CRUD operations.'}, {'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

For me it looks good-enough for the servers-something related thing to be placed in ServersClient given the simplification/cleanup gained by this change.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:26:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think this is a grey area but will vote my approval. There is already not a one-to-one correspondence between the directories under services/compute and the tests and directories under tests/compute. In my view the distinction between what is and is not under the "contrib" directory in the nova source should not be the basis for tempest because some of these "contrib" things will probably be considered mandatory in future api revisions. 

It also seems silly that we need to spin up a new server to check the console rather than piggybacking on the create server test but that could wait for another submission.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:43:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Ok, seems reasonable, since it is a server action.

The only thing I'd like to see then is a check to see if the extension is enabled before the console_output calls are made. But, that would be outside the scope of this change; so as a follow-on patch"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-02 12:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.

While I agree with this in principal I think this is a bit of a big change for a stable release candidate."}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-11-27 21:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-11-27 21:28:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-27 22:19:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hmm, I agree the change is risky and I'd prefer it to not be merged so close to 2012.2.1 ... but it does look like a serious issue and the change doesn't look *that* terrifying

Rafi - maybe explaining why this is such a serious issue to you might change Chuck's mind"}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2012-11-28 05:05:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Without this fix in place, any suspended instances can never be acted upon short of deleting after a hypervisor reboot.  The user can never resume, since none of the VMs dependencies will be in place; nor can they issue a hard reboot.  Even an admin would likely have to clear the suspended state in libvirt and then issue a hard reboot via Nova, to be able to get everything the instance needs in place.

Needless to say, it's not uncommon to have a hypervisor reboot and each one of these situations currently results in a lot of manual work to resolve.

The only reason the patch looks as large is it does is because the compute calls into drive.resume had to be extended to provide network and block device info.  It's pretty minor overall."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2012-11-30 17:24:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

With 2012.2.1 released, can we get this approved/merged for 2012.2.2?  If not, is it because you'd like to see changes or would you prefer I abandon?"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-11-30 18:59:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I would prefer abandoned because this dont meet the guidlines in my opinion.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2012-11-30 23:27:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Which guideline is not being met?'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2012-12-03 23:31:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

I disagree with keeping a bug like this around in a stable release but I'm abandoning by request."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-19 22:30:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

We should re-examine this. This actually is a problem because security group rules don't get recreated on reboot. So basically doing a suspend / reboot host /resume means you could have an instance without security group rules."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-22 15:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Restored

Requested by Vish.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-22 15:55:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-22 15:56:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

[{'created': '2012-11-26 04:30:51.000000000', 'message': 'Allow VMs to be resumed after a hypervisor reboot

Fixes bug 1052696 (Folsom backport)

Update the compute manager to pass network_info and block_device_info
to the driver.resume() and update all virtualization drivers to accept
the new arguments.

For libvirt, change resume() to use _create_domain_and_network()
rather than _create_domain(). This eliminates the assumption that the
network and block device connections remained in place from the period
between the VM being suspended and resumed.  Instead, all the
networking and block connections will be rebuilt on resume (in case
they are missing) as is the case after a hypervisor reboot.

Change-Id: I6e19ec42f7e929678abce8f276c0a6e91f1fa8af
Cherry-Pick: 99b5e96795b8475f14d53bbc3845e7bace730963

commit_message:
Allow VMs to be resumed after a hypervisor reboot

Fixes bug 1052696 (Folsom backport)

Update the compute manager to pass network_info and block_device_info
to the driver.resume() and update all virtualization drivers to accept
the new arguments.

For libvirt, change resume() to use _create_domain_and_network()
rather than _create_domain(). This eliminates the assumption that the
network and block device connections remained in place from the period
between the VM being suspended and resumed.  Instead, all the
networking and block connections will be rebuilt on resume (in case
they are missing) as is the case after a hypervisor reboot.

Change-Id: I6e19ec42f7e929678abce8f276c0a6e91f1fa8af
Cherry-Pick: 99b5e96795b8475f14d53bbc3845e7bace730963

'}, {'created': '2013-01-31 21:16:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fix boto initialization

boto test skip(service considered enabled) mechanism based on global
variables, set by the generic_setup_package.
When the tesresources is introduced for handling initialization,
the skip logic frequently sees the default disabled values.

Every boto test cases depends on base class, which static (class)
attribute initialization done, before any setUpClass checking the global
variables.

This initialization is happens only once, and visible by all subclasses.

A possible next step (after this change), to have the
generic_setup_package to return, with a dict contains the conclusion
about the testing and configured variables, it will be visible for all
subclasses.

Change-Id: Idc0a1b1ce0e78f7837c3f3b3a2e0593750861fa7
'}]
commit_message:
Fix boto initialization

boto test skip(service considered enabled) mechanism based on global
variables, set by the generic_setup_package.
When the tesresources is introduced for handling initialization,
the skip logic frequently sees the default disabled values.

Every boto test cases depends on base class, which static (class)
attribute initialization done, before any setUpClass checking the global
variables.

This initialization is happens only once, and visible by all subclasses.

A possible next step (after this change), to have the
generic_setup_package to return, with a dict contains the conclusion
about the testing and configured variables, it will be visible for all
subclasses.

Change-Id: Idc0a1b1ce0e78f7837c3f3b3a2e0593750861fa7

commit_message:
Enhances consistency in 'Create Project' modal

Substitutes 'Add Project' (modal title) and
'Finish' (modal button) strings for
'Create Project' in order to improve consistency
as well as to make it clear the action
is being made.

Change-Id: I04204f35d9da53cd7827ca10dd41191352870f8b
Implements: String replacement
Fixes: bug #1107982

This patch reimplements the is_valid_ipv4() function is nova.utils.
Instead of open-coding the validity check, just make use of the netaddr
module, which is already used elsewhere in nova.utils.

commit_message:
Reimplement is_valid_ipv4().

This patch reimplements the is_valid_ipv4() function is nova.utils.
Instead of open-coding the validity check, just make use of the netaddr
module, which is already used elsewhere in nova.utils.

Also add a unit test for this code.

Part of indigoprint bored-on-an-airplane.

Change-Id: Ia89cbbd94a0ac4631d794d658b53c244237e1ca2

[{'created': '2013-02-02 16:50:25.000000000', 'message': "Tweakify is_valid_boolstr().

This function used a few backslashes for continuation.  According to
HACKING, we prefer to not use this.  This code gets rid of them by
changing the way the checks are done.

Look at those backslashes ... sitting there at the end of the line.
It's like they're looking down on the code that precedes them, as if
they are somehow superior to the other characters.  Banish them from
this utility function!

Also add a unit test for this code.

Part of greenprint bored-on-an-airplane.

Change-Id: If88b6e63ab078916ce1b9cf2f5e99623c402996c
"}]
commit_message:
Tweakify is_valid_boolstr().

This function used a few backslashes for continuation.  According to
HACKING, we prefer to not use this.  This code gets rid of them by
changing the way the checks are done.

Look at those backslashes ... sitting there at the end of the line.
It's like they're looking down on the code that precedes them, as if
they are somehow superior to the other characters.  Banish them from
this utility function!

Also add a unit test for this code.

Part of greenprint bored-on-an-airplane.

Change-Id: If88b6e63ab078916ce1b9cf2f5e99623c402996c

commit_message:
Support for ipv6 in wsgi.Service

Enable wsgi.Service to listen on ipv6 address by checking
if the host specified is ipv6. Based on that set the
appropriate family in the eventlet.listen api

More tests for just the ipv6, ipv6 with app, ipv6+ssl with app
to make sure everything is working fine

Change-Id: I2772905128bdbc69dd0fafe4ced848f5c477d7c8

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-30 01:48:14.000000000', 'message': 'Make system_metadata update in place

This makes the system_metadata updated in-place like regular
metadata during instance_update(). It also modifies that function
to avoid actually removing the item from the list, which will cause it
to be deleted from the database when the session ends. The soft_delete
is sufficient for our purposes.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

commit_message:
Make system_metadata update in place

This makes the system_metadata updated in-place like regular
metadata during instance_update(). It also modifies that function
to avoid actually removing the item from the list, which will cause it
to be deleted from the database when the session ends. The soft_delete
is sufficient for our purposes.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I0da28ec485dc7850d246dab0a2bb95ae10c05c3e

commit_message:
Rename run_tests.sh to wrap_nosetests.sh

run_tests.sh has a different purpose in CM than
run_tests.sh in Nova, which causes confusion. Renamed the file
to better reflect its true intent.

Change-Id: I206fdeab8b052f85e1485164f019979ebbff4fbb

documents, references to previous releases that are no longer useful

'}]
commit_message:
Remove Essex/Folsom cruft from Grizzly guides

partially fixes bug 1087484

With Grizzly a couple months away, the documentation team is working
on its documentation as a priority. As part of the release of new
documents, references to previous releases that are no longer useful
or relevent should be removed.

This change:
* removes reference to pre-essex legacy options on keystone import
* removes deleted simple scheduler from glossary
* clarifies XenAPI pools for current status
* removes note about Essex client mismatch in reset-stat
* removes references to Essex and Diablo from dodai-deploy docs
* removes an outdated (Essex) configuration file example
* updates several links to point to Grizzly versions
* removes outdated (Essex) ISO distribution information
* removes outdated (Diablo, Essex) vnc proxy information
* updates guide titles and versions where appropriate
* removes old notes about config syntax

Change-Id: I81fab078f17a003c12b7f86cb266892b89c79a94

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-04 11:47:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

I don't like to see us add config options for this kind of stuff without a really good rationale

See https://etherpad.openstack.org/grizzly-nova-config-options

Could you explain why you think users will want to change this?

Can we not just change from 20 to a value that will satisfy all use cases?"}, {'account_id': 2140, 'date': '2013-01-04 13:46:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Imagine the case of a user (admin) that has to list large amount of images.

If there are ten thousand images, this has to make 500 queries to glance-api server and slow down the response time. We can increase the page_size in glanceclient to reduce queries to glance-api server.

In addition, the max page_size for glanceclient is limited by the api_limit_max setting in glance-registry server.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-04 14:08:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think the argument you're making is just that DEFAULT_PAGE_SIZE in glanceclient and limit_param_default in glance are both too low

Increasing both of those makes sense for all users, right?

If we were to add your config option, the help documentation should say "set this to a higher value to make image listing faster" ... that's pretty silly'}, {'account_id': 2140, 'date': '2013-01-07 05:27:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-07 05:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Increase glanceclient page_size in image.glance

This patch increases the glanceclient page_size to reduce the queries
to glance-api for each image-list.

Change-Id: Ia635fb41f98f22082c691ed63637d08aaf1f06cd

Please add the following to your localrc:

RYU_APPS=ryu.app.gre_tunnel,ryu.app.quantum_adapter,ryu.app.rest,ryu.app.rest_conf_switch,ryu.app.rest_tunnel,ryu.app.tunnel_port_updater,ryu.app.rest_quantum
RYU_REPO=${GIT_BASE}/ykaneko/ryu.git
RYU_BRANCH=live-migration

And remove /opt/stack/ryu, then please try devstack again.


Hi Mark,
Thank you for your review!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-03 02:19:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Improve data access method of ryu-agent

fixes bug #1110174

This patch implement rpc in ryu-agent, instead of accessing a
database directly.
Because it was not necessary to transmit information via database,
therefore the table is eliminated.

Also, I remove openflow controller stuff from a configuration file
of the Ryu plugin because it was not used anymore.

Change-Id: I5e261297c3f92c6a1ac5df229084176e84694e87

My concern with this is that some states may want rebooting disabled because it could lead to other problems, such as synchronization problems of some sort.  I would feel more comfortable if we could add some tests that demonstrate that rebooting in these new states will be OK'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:35:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

I covered this in some detail here: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-January/004662.html

I think there are real issues around allowing a hard reboot to be issued while another hard reboot is in progress'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:58:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I went through the threads and there were no real issues identified, only hypothetical concerns over the possibility of issues.  Also, the behavior of hard_reboot has changed substantially over the past few months. I have yet to encounter a situation where multiple hard_reboots cause a problem.  However, on countless occasions, I've seen hard_reboots never reach the compute node, leaving an instance stuck with no way for the user to recover.

If there's a race in a driver-level operation, it should be protected there, rather than enforced at the API."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-21 23:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Could you reply to the mailing list thread and continue the discussion there please? Thanks'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-24 19:50:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Responded on the mailing list but have not seen a response yet.  Any additional thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-26 19:11:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-26 19:12:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Relax API restrictions around the use of reboot

Fixes bug 1101082 bug 982108

Reboots are the only sledge hammer users have available to resolve
issues with their instances without administrative intervention.
This patch modifies the API policy to allow reboot calls to be made
in many more power and task states.

Change-Id: Ia8702448f6b7b863da40e4d498f2e2ee0a12882e

commit_message:
Updates migration 008 to work on PostgreSQL.

This fixes a regression in 5bc46d8 which caused migration 008 to
fail when using PostgreSQL.

Fixes LP Bug #1112535.

Change-Id: I94f69c2dece3a5753eed3cc3cf7b63ba60208c5c

commit_message:
Add option to control where bridges forward

This adds a new config option to control where bridges can forward.
The default behavior is unchanged, but if you specify:

forward_bridge_interface=foo

Then only traffic on the same bridge or going to and from the foo
interface will be allowed. This is useful in vlan mode when a
deployer doesn't want traffic to be routed between vlans. Note
that forward_bridge_interface can be specified multiple times and
should be specified once for each interface that supports floating
ips. i.e.:

forward_bridge_interface=eth0.10
forward_bridge_interface=eth0.20

DocImpact

Change-Id: I82d6b288b60cd6deae64690b55546730b1c2da55

commit_message:
instance.update notifications don't always identify the service

instance_update in conductor/manager.py doesn't identify the service
when calling notifications.send_update(), resulting in mesages on the
notification queue having a service value of None.

This change makes sure that the correct service is identified even
when running conductor in local mode

Change-Id: I1b22c0b46040f51ba715a4d9fa19ef4c98359070

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-11 05:18:07.000000000', 'message': "Support for SSL and ipv6 in wsgi.Service

Both ipv6 and SSL are entirely optional. ipv6 supports
just raw ipv6 addresses only for now. We'll need to
prompt eventlet folks for better ipv6 dns support.

Enable wsgi.Service to listen on ipv6 address by check
if the host specified is ipv6. Based on that set the
appropriate family in the eventlet.listen api

Enable support for SSL as well using code from glance. We
have some new options for configuring the SSL support.

test_app starts wsgi.Service with a test app, then creates
a url to make sure the http requests are actually served
properly

test_app_using_router adds wsgi.Router and Mapper() to the
mix along with using the wsgify annotation for serving
the http requests

More tests for just the ipv6, ipv6 with app, ipv6+ssl with app
to make sure everything is working fine

Change-Id: Iae47b13b50e00c102c8c36f4a3e73b24fa4e6303
"}, {'created': '2013-01-11 05:20:59.000000000', 'message': "Support for SSL and ipv6 in wsgi.Service

commit_message:
Support for SSL in wsgi.Service

Enable support for SSL as well using code from glance. We
have some new options for configuring the SSL support.

test_app starts wsgi.Service with a test app, then creates
a url to make sure the http requests are actually served
properly

test_app_using_router adds wsgi.Router and Mapper() to the
mix along with using the wsgify annotation for serving
the http requests

Fixes LP# 979488 (partial)
Fixes LP# 869884 (partial)

DocImpact

Change-Id: Iae47b13b50e00c102c8c36f4a3e73b24fa4e6303

Add a new global variable to control when exception format errors
are fatal.

Also, updates the Oslo test base class to enable fatal exception
format errors.

Change-Id: Id8f4a0946b1614c8e987976b79069532a2e8608f

commit_message:
Add _FATAL_EXCEPTION_FORMAT_ERRORS global.

Add a new global variable to control when exception format errors
are fatal.

Also, updates the Oslo test base class to enable fatal exception
format errors.

The motivation for this change is to give projects that use
openstack common a hook to enable exception format checking when
testing.

Change-Id: Id8f4a0946b1614c8e987976b79069532a2e8608f

commit_message:
Condense multiple authorizers into a single one.

Reduces code duplication by creating a single authorizer and passing in
the action that should be checked against policy.

Change-Id: I33cfee8695ddfbba39038fbc608c6c74d258745f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-30 22:01:53.000000000', 'message': 'Extend extension_authorizer to enable cleaner code.

I have seen and used two different methods for authorizing multiple
methods in a class, and both use code duplication that won't be
necessary with this patch.

The first method involves creating multiple authorizers, which can get
out of hand quickly.  i.e.:

authorize_attach_index = extensions.extension_authorizer('compute',
                                                'volume_attachments:index')
authorize_attach_show = extensions.extension_authorizer('compute',
                                                'volume_attachments:show')

The second method involves creating an intermediate method in the
extension like:

def authorize(context, action_name):
    action = 'os-networksv2:%s' % action_name
    extensions.extension_authorizer('compute', action)(context)

but this ends up getting duplicated in each file.  This patch allows
extensions to use the authorizers they already have but gives them finer
control by passing something like "action='index'" to the authorizer.

Change-Id: I6371b2c631acc9345ee6ca4672afa1f49781f22b
'}]
commit_message:
Extend extension_authorizer to enable cleaner code.

I have seen and used two different methods for authorizing multiple
methods in a class, and both use code duplication that won't be
necessary with this patch.

The first method involves creating multiple authorizers, which can get
out of hand quickly.  i.e.:

authorize_attach_index = extensions.extension_authorizer('compute',
                                                'volume_attachments:index')
authorize_attach_show = extensions.extension_authorizer('compute',
                                                'volume_attachments:show')

The second method involves creating an intermediate method in the
extension like:

def authorize(context, action_name):
    action = 'os-networksv2:%s' % action_name
    extensions.extension_authorizer('compute', action)(context)

but this ends up getting duplicated in each file.  This patch allows
extensions to use the authorizers they already have but gives them finer
control by passing something like "action='index'" to the authorizer.

Change-Id: I6371b2c631acc9345ee6ca4672afa1f49781f22b

commit_message:
populate dnsmasq lease db with valid leases

At start dnsmasq retrieves its lease db by calling the nova-dhcpbridge
script with the init action.

Previously we were returning all allocated IPs in the network and
calculating the lease exirpation time based upon instances.updated_at
or instances.created_at.

Now we are only returning entries for IPs that are allocated and leased.
Additionally we set the lease expiration time to be i
now + CONF.dhcp_lease_time

Change-Id: Ie3b4fafd38094dc01ceea592ab5229e581193512
Fixes: bug #1103260

commit_message:
Introduce get_python_exec_prefix function.

get_python_exec_prefix returns the path to the direcotry where python
executables are installed, that is /usr/bin on Fedora and /usr/local/bin
everywhere else.

It is used to properly locate OpenStack executables.

Fixes: bug #1068386

Change-Id: I228498ebe2762568d00757d065e37377ee2c8fb3

commit_message:
Quantum metadata handler now uses X-Forwarded-For

fixes bug 1097524

The guest IP address was not properly forwarded from the Quantum
metadata proxy.  This patch adds support in Nova for reading this
X-Forwarded-For header.  Previously, the internal proxy IP was
mistakenly used exposing internal infrastructure details.

Change-Id: I6d7d21e2aea4ca5debf1ca4ba6802012537f78a5

commit_message:
If the image data is not provide we need throw exception

To enhance the error handler, we need check whether the image data is
provided when create image.

Fixes: bug #1099695

commit_message:
Corrected the base test class.

Use ceilometer.tests.base.TestCase instead of unittest.Testcase as the
base test class so that all tests get the proper setUp and tearDown
needed.

Change-Id: I630032239896f43b13e29946d81c3ec6958987ef

'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-01-25 08:52:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

A brief nit - also, if we're going to add this to ec2 - shouldn't we add a feature to the OpenStack API? At least as an extension? Or?"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-01-25 09:41:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree this feature should also be added to the openstack native API, otherwise we can't use this feature in heat, as all of our API interaction heat->nova is via the native api, not the ec2 one (maybe that should be a separate patch tho?)

Also, there are not any tests for the new API features - IMO there really needs to be, since some of the logic is relatively complex, so even if it works now and has been tested, we need in-tree tests which will ensure it stays working."}, {'account_id': 6624, 'date': '2013-01-25 20:13:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi,

I see this feature could be implemented in one of two ways:
as I've implemented it, as a separate feature to the existing instance_metadata table in nova.  This is because ec2 tags aren't just for instances, aren't available from the metadata server, and are used by both admins and other system process (autoscaling, cloudformation) for tagging arbitrary resource types.  My initial implementation doesn't have support for other resource types yet, but it leaves room in the database schema should we get there.

The other way would be to have an 'instance_metadata', 'security_group_metadata' etc etc tables, and some calls to other APIs for things like glance and quantum, but have it all elided behind the EC2 API.  The 'lookup table of doom' has downsides, of course.

Cheers,"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-02 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-02 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Add support for EC2 tag API

Implement the API calls CreateTags, DescribeTags and DeleteTags and the CRUD
calls to support them.  Unlike EC2, only instance tagging is currently
supported.  Glance/Quantum/Cinder/Swift etc will need to implement tagging
independently if they want to support this as well.

Implements: EC2 tag API for instances
Fixes: bugs #770070, #1096821

Change-Id: I467aa62817c4e56ead955350c909e5b639ebd6a9
Signed-off-by: Stephen Gran <stephen.gran@guardian.co.uk>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-01 05:43:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix the generalized copy_image_to_volume operation.

The Generis iSCSI copy volume<->image patch
(change: Iff097629bcce9154829a7eb5aee0ea6302338b26) did
not account for the fact that the existing volume reference
passed in to the copy method would not have the updated
provider_location and iSCSI info available.

To address this, we simply just get a new ref from the DB
after creation if a copy image is requested.

Also, the list of acceptable formats was not fully inclusive,
not only that, but there's no reason to not let the qemu-convert
handle any errors here.

Change-Id: I7b1910080d285562c7f2d8afa7f65768b1089b73
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the generalized copy_image_to_volume operation.

The Generis iSCSI copy volume<->image patch
(change: Iff097629bcce9154829a7eb5aee0ea6302338b26) did
not account for the fact that the existing volume reference
passed in to the copy method would not have the updated
provider_location and iSCSI info available.

To address this, we simply just get a new ref from the DB
after creation if a copy image is requested.

Also, the list of acceptable formats was not fully inclusive,
not only that, but there's no reason to not let the qemu-convert
handle any errors here.

Change-Id: I7b1910080d285562c7f2d8afa7f65768b1089b73

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-01 17:17:27.000000000', 'message': "Deterministic, repeatable serialization for rings.

The (account|container|object).ring.gz files contain, among other
things, a JSON-encoded dictionary. This change simply makes the JSON
serializer sort the keys of that dictionary so that two
Python-identical rings will result in two bytewise-identical ring
files. Also, to get repeatable compression, we lock down the timestamp
in the gzip output stream to a fixed value. (There's a timestamp value
in a gzip stream header; by default, gzip.GzipFile sticks time.time()
in there.)

This only works on Python 2.7; on 2.6, the 'mtime' argument to
gzip.GzipFile() is unsupported. Don't worry, serialization still works
on 2.6. It just doesn't always produce the same bytes for the same
ring.

Change-Id: Ide446413d0aeb78536883933fd0caf440b8f54ad
"}]
commit_message:
Deterministic, repeatable serialization for rings.

The (account|container|object).ring.gz files contain, among other
things, a JSON-encoded dictionary. This change simply makes the JSON
serializer sort the keys of that dictionary so that two
Python-identical rings will result in two bytewise-identical ring
files. Also, to get repeatable compression, we lock down the timestamp
in the gzip output stream to a fixed value. (There's a timestamp value
in a gzip stream header; by default, gzip.GzipFile sticks time.time()
in there.)

This only works on Python 2.7; on 2.6, the 'mtime' argument to
gzip.GzipFile() is unsupported. Don't worry, serialization still works
on 2.6. It just doesn't always produce the same bytes for the same
ring.

Change-Id: Ide446413d0aeb78536883933fd0caf440b8f54ad

commit_message:
Remove deprecation notice in LibvirtBridgeDriver

After further discussions with Quantum team, it was agreed
not to deprecate the existing libvirt VIF drivers until the
Havana release, to allow more time for Quantum plugins to be
updated.

commit_message:
Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15983/

Fix bug 1061665, --force_hosts hint for launching instance updates

--force_hosts no longer available in Folsom, have to indicate
an availability zone instead.

Patchset attempts to explain how to get the availability zone
name that you want. Please review.

Patchset addresses comments about zone versus host, adding
new section rather than replacing host section completely.

Change-Id: Ifea0df3dc950c165718fa160bc08f1b1487c3f82

Hi, 

I've thought about this patch and I actually run into the same issue with removing security groups from ports since passing in --security_groups=None via the client gets converted to a string.

In my case I cannot pass --security_groups=None to update port because one could actually create a security group with the name "None" (and our client supports doing name lookup to make copying the uuid's easier).  In my opinion we should not be modifying the quantum api because python-quantumclient doesn't have a way to do this currently. Would you checkout this commit https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20967/ and adding something like --no-session-persistence to the lb-vip-update command? (Note: if you do this please rebase on top of my commit since some logic needed to be added to allow UpdateCommand's to have args.  What do you guys think? 
Thanks, 

Aaron'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-02-01 22:38:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

As Nachi mentioned above Yong has made some changes that allow to send a None value with the command line client by specifying action=clear: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17436/ 

I think Yong's solution is more generic so it can be used for resetting different values in a single way instead of adding specific arguments like --no-session-persistence."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 22:38:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Resetting session persisnence for a VIP.

This change allows to reset session persistence, if it
was configured for a VIP. It's possible by passing None
value for session persistence through the REST API.

Change-Id: I8690850d0589065502a8eb774d51fe40851624f8
Fixes: bug #1109101

[{'created': '2013-02-01 14:36:00.000000000', 'message': 'Adds unitest2 and keyring to pip-requires

When running tempest outside of a devstack
machine, the unittest2 and keyring packages
are missing from the virtual environment.

Adding the packages to tools/pip-requires
triggers their installation both when
using run_tests.sh as well as tox.

Fixes: LP bug #1112542
Change-Id: I5c3632394a2b0fe364022854d8ff62ef4866ace9
'}]
commit_message:
Adds unitest2 and keyring to pip-requires

When running tempest outside of a devstack
machine, the unittest2 and keyring packages
are missing from the virtual environment.

Adding the packages to tools/pip-requires
triggers their installation both when
using run_tests.sh as well as tox.

Fixes: LP bug #1112542
Change-Id: I5c3632394a2b0fe364022854d8ff62ef4866ace9

messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:19:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Thanks, but this isn't quite the way I want to see this done.  Also, why were these errors ignored by the test suite run of pep8?  I consider that a bug, and would like to see that fixed as well."}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:38:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:40:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your guidance on format, Kevin, I appreciate it.

"Also, why were these errors ignored by the test suite run of pep8? I consider that a bug, and would like to see that fixed as well."

Do you mean in Tempest, is that the test suite run you are referencing? I have never addressed Tempest before, if this is the suite you mean, I guess there is no time like the present. If you have a link to get me started, I am grateful.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Er, no, not tempest.  The python-novaclient test suite includes a run of pep8.  (You are running the test suite before submitting patch sets, right?  I use "tox -e py26,pep8" (or "py27" when I only have Python 2.7 available).)  It's pretty clear to me that the function calls you changed were longer than 79 characters, which pep8 should have caught and prevented from merging, so the fact that it did not implies that there's some sort of failure here.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:53:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's pretty clear to me that the function calls you changed were longer than 79 characters, which pep8 should have caught and prevented from merging, so the fact that it did not implies that there's some sort of failure here.

Ah, yes, I hadn't changed these function calls originally. I got them like this in my git pull, I just got tired of looking at them. Personally I wouldn't push a patch that gave pep8 errors, I don't know who did. I just wanted to fix the pep8 errors."}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:03:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't think pep8 errors prevent a patch from being merged, do you feel they should?

If so, I think this would affect all projects and I would need some input from more sources on this before I headed in that direction."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:06:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Actually, pep8 errors *do* prevent the patch from merging; the fact that this pep8 error did not do so indicates a problem somewhere.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:20:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
VMware Compute Driver Glance improvement

blueprint vmware-compute-driver

Glance change to fix image download to ESX
The current glance code downloads files in a blocking/synchronous
manner, the fix improves it to work with ESX glance file reader
in a non-blocking manner.
This allows ESX glance file reader to read items from the returned
queue.

Change-Id: I05ab7ac00878aeeea3bbcd7546b05398f2630dd3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-24 23:27:58.000000000', 'message': 'Delete instance resource when heat delete done

When a heat delete operation is done shortly after a create, the
stack disappears immediately and the instance resource it created
leaks without being deleted.

This patch introduces functionality which keeps the stack in the
"DELETE_IN_PROGRESS" state until the instance resource (usually in
the BUILD state) is deleted.

Change-Id: I4a4ad411721b7f65a0d342049c3a75fcc8227ad3
Fixes: bug #1072932
'}]
commit_message:
Delete instance resource when heat delete done

When a heat delete operation is done shortly after a create, the
stack disappears immediately and the instance resource it created
leaks without being deleted.

This patch introduces functionality which keeps the stack in the
"DELETE_IN_PROGRESS" state until the instance resource (usually in
the BUILD state) is deleted.

Change-Id: I4a4ad411721b7f65a0d342049c3a75fcc8227ad3
Fixes: bug #1072932

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-01 16:29:34.000000000', 'message': 'heat engine : WaitCondition add Handle property validation

Add validation to the Handle property for WaitCondition, so
we check that the identifier in the provided URL maps to
a WaitConditionHandle resource in the same stack as the
WaitCondition

fixes bug 1100754

Change-Id: I44c8f52435016fad5a35183472d2b0df26c1915d
'}]
commit_message:
heat engine : WaitCondition add Handle property validation

Add validation to the Handle property for WaitCondition, so
we check that the identifier in the provided URL maps to
a WaitConditionHandle resource in the same stack as the
WaitCondition

fixes bug 1100754

Change-Id: I44c8f52435016fad5a35183472d2b0df26c1915d

commit_message:
Upgraded to PEP8 1.3.3 to stay aligned with Nova, etc.

Made all the necessary changes to pass new PEP8 standards.

Also cleaned up docstrings to conform to the HACKING stanards.

Change-Id: Ib8df3030da7a7885655689ab5da0717748c9edbe

commit_message:
Create a default domain (bp default-domain)

This changes rewrites some of our migration history since the folsom
release so that we can create a default domain prior to creating
non-nullable foreignkey's in the user and project tables in migration
9 (numbered according to this change).

DocImpact

Change-Id: I807f7b1dca1d6a895f7417c316bcbce24ada61c0

commit_message:
heat tests : test_waitcondition move cleanup out of teardown

Move stack delete and mox VerifyAll out of the teardown function
so if either fails the stubs are unset, meaning all subsequent
tests won't fail due to being unable to setup their stubs
stack delete is now performed via the stack_delete_after decorator

Change-Id: I636af84dd66ba4923f068c56ec13e7990d8edc03
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-01 12:11:22.000000000', 'message': 'heat tests : Add utility decorator for deleting stacks

Add decorator function which allows test functions to be wrapped
such that if they create a stack (and it is stored in the testcase
class as self.stack) it is always deleted on test exit, regardless
of test success/failure

Change-Id: Ibde9a2cee08448e3f24c6b7efbfe756a01f9eccc
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat tests : Add utility decorator for deleting stacks

Add decorator function which allows test functions to be wrapped
such that if they create a stack (and it is stored in the testcase
class as self.stack) it is always deleted on test exit, regardless
of test success/failure

Change-Id: Ibde9a2cee08448e3f24c6b7efbfe756a01f9eccc
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

I don't know whether this is a deliberate attempt or not. In my opinion it's more likely that the change-Id was reset during a commit amend and this ended up in a new patch on gerrit.

On the merit of this specific patch, I totally agree with Kyle. So I'm +/- 0 on it."}, {'account_id': 1690, 'date': '2013-02-01 07:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Maru.  Especially since the HACKING change itself is confusing (the not + compound conditional).  Also, please do not intersperse arbitrary whitespace, all rights reserved, import ordering, etc changes to a change labelled simply "Fixes 'not in' operator usage."'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-02-01 07:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maru, just to be sure. What the ML concludes is that this should not be recommended and not forced?'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-02-01 07:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maru,
The reason I abandoned the last patch was because there was two patches that depended on it that did not have anything to do with the "not in" topic.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20787/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20784/

I thought this "not in" thing was a bit controversary so I assumed I would take a bit of a time to gather the consensus of the community so I ditched the patch and moved on with the two patches which were depending on it.

Then I sent out a mail asking how other people thought about this topic and different from what I expected many people agreed on the idea that "not in" should be used.

Therefore I've started with a new branch to address this to Quantum but the original patch was already to messy that I had to reset to master anyway.

So that is my story. You said we need consensus. So I asked though the ML. Seems that people agreed and started with a new branch for Quantum since a lot has changed with the places I needed to handle.

I don't know what it is that I did for your disappointment but I swear I didn't intend to avoid the -1 you gave me.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 07:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Split floating ip functionality into new file.

This is to prepare for moving this code into network.api. There was
one minor change made to associate_floating_ip. It no longer checks
access to the fixed ip's network before associating the floating ip
to the fixed ip. The calling side was already verifying access to the
instance so this is unnecessary. A note was added to the method call
to ensure future usage of associate_floating keeps this in mind.

Part of blueprint optimize-nova-network

Change-Id: I4fcda82eebee46d167e028bb68c8fedf2c3e03a1

subject: Optimize network calls by moving them to api

commit_message:
Optimize network calls by moving them to api

Now that quantumv2 replaces api, there is no need for many of the
network calls to go over rpc. This patch optimizes them by moving
the implementation into the api class. Note that the old methods
are left in place to keep rpcapi compatibility.

This patch also adds api_deprecated in case anyone is using a
custom out-of-tree manager class. It is possible to set:

network_api_class=nova.network.api_deprecated.API

to get the old functionality.

Part of blueprint optimize-nova-network

Change-Id: I130908df060246e8a5f3711cf16d1c49ee3e2664

commit_message:
Add usage command to show usage for single tenant

The usage-list command is admin-only so add a usage command so
that users can see their usage like they do in horizon. Only
admins can see usage for other tenants, so default the value of
tenant to the tenant_id of the current credentials.

Change-Id: Icd6fec36f1f4145b92b227031e5df23db11737f0

commit_message:
Replace nose with testr.

testr allows for more flexible testing, more consistent use of the unittest
protocol and, most importantly, faster testing via parallelism.
Part of blueprint grizzly-testtools.

Change-Id: Ie5d9760b6df652918653018b1bfeb40fbf82a30f

[{'created': '2013-01-02 18:48:28.000000000', 'message': 'Calculate the proper totals for LVM images

Resources were being calculated for the whole disk
when using LVM images. We should be calculating the size
and the free space of the lVM group.

Fixes LP: #1094134

Change-Id: Ieebc024a44ccb46aa6e868c86958d9f1784ce239
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Calculate the proper totals for LVM images

Resources were being calculated for the whole disk
when using LVM images. We should be calculating the size
and the free space of the lVM group.

Fixes LP: #1094134

commit_message:
Store tenant_id from keystone and use for quotas

Some calls in nova require a tenant_id when it could be interpreted
from the current authentication data, so save the tenant id and
use it in the quotas command if tenant_id is not specified.

Change-Id: I89647cfe9da73bc474ef80a61a5678db42a5571c

'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-30 23:30:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So I like the general idea, but I wonder if seed should be stored as a general attribute of the ring (for example, when first generated).  That way you don't accidently rebalance without the correct seed."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2013-01-31 18:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I did that in my first pass, but ideally you want to be able to rebalance with a different seed so you can change seeds for subsequent rebalances. Putting the seed in the constructor ended up being more complex than passing it into the rebalance command.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-01-31 21:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I like this approach'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-31 22:19:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

That seems reasonable.  I did some testing, and so far works as advertised.  There is one small problem though.  One nice thing about using rings that are generated from a single source, is that you can do a quick md5sum of all the rings in your system to validate that your rings are indeed the same.  When using the seed, the resulting ring files are not identical when running md5sum on the file.  This is likely due to the fact that the ring is a dict that is serialized to json and then written to a .gz file.  I was able to validate two generated rings by manually loading the ring in ipyhton, and then doing some introspection. All of that said, I think it would be important to have a way to validate that rings are equal in a cluster.  I'm on the fence weather that should be a requirement for this patch, or hope for a fast follow... What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-31 23:06:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Chuck: I don't think you're guaranteed to get identical ring.gz files even without this change. You've identified the problem: they're serialized in JSON as dictionaries, so key order is indeterminate.

Now, perhaps we're getting lucky with our current set of keys and the ordering is deterministic for some reason. IMHO, ensuring two Python-identical rings are bytewise-identical is a separate change."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-01-31 23:10:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Sam correct, previously, you are not guaranteed to get the same rings, and I wasn't testing that.  I was just looking at a way to validate that two rings are identical.  The only way that you could guarantee previous rings were identical by using md5sum, is if you generate once, then copy rings out to every server.  I'm cool if it gets added as a separate change... just curious if Chris plans on adding that or if it will be left as an exersize for the reader :)"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-01 00:09:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Chuck: you got me thinking. I wrote a diff to sort the keys when serializing the ring, then got into gzip land, and it turns out that I can make it work on Python 2.7, but not 2.6.

There are two pieces to deterministic ring serialization:
1: same ring --> same uncompressed bytes
2: same uncompressed bytes --> same compressed bytes

I can make part 1 happen telling the JSON encoder to sort dictionary keys. For the second part, I can make it happen by passing a hard-coded mtime into GzipFile() instead of letting it use time.time(). Unfortunately, the 'mtime' arg is only supported in Python 2.7; on 2.6, there's no way to override it."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-01 00:09:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Getting back to this changeset: I think it's an odd way to distribute rings, but the code looks good and has tests."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 02:54:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-01 02:54:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 04:04:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Allow rebalance to take a seed.

Passing a seed into rebalance makes the rebalance deterministic
which allows us to generate identical rings across disparate
nodes without having to copy the ring files around.

Change-Id: Ie5ae46ac030e61284bc501fdef9d77eeb5243afd

commit_message:
Add switch to disable token authentication.

This patch allows you to disable token authentication with keystone so
that the client can be used with other backends in heat.

Change-Id: I4b35df82a782ddbc8532e85a7b9d532b327d010a
Signed-off-by: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Set source volume to "in use" during clone

When we are cloning a volume, we now set the source volume's status
to 'in use'. This prevents a user from deleting the source volume while the
backend copies/clones the contents to the new volume.
When the cloning is complete, we reset the status to it's original
state.

Change-Id: Ie43345aba77df4671ed2b429645cf8d1af9b975b

commit_message:
Removes retry of set_admin_password

* An RPC timeout may occur if an agent is missing and set_admin_password is
invoked. This causes 500 errors in the OpenStack API.
* Implemented a 501 error in API if the password set fails.
* Modified xenapi agent to use NotImplementedError instead of Exception in
  set_admin_password.
* Updated test code around set_admin_password to accept different exceptions.
* Fixes bug 1061045

Change-Id: If7fab56c20f12e0490f4774e00004ed1d94242b9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-28 17:19:34.000000000', 'message': "Allow volume back-end to report 'infinite' or 'unknown' as capacity

For some reason, some volume back-ends cannot report actual capacity
that is available or even total capacity (e.g. thin-provisioning),
Cinder should allow such capability report and make placement/schedule
decision based on these status.

In particular, we agree to use 'infinite' to mark unlimited space and
'unknown' to mark unknown/unclear space.  Host manager and CapacityFilter
are updated accordingly to allow such capacity.  For those back-ends
report 'infinite' or 'unknown' capacity, CapacityFilter will let them
pass to give them a chance to try.  Even if failure happened, the retry
mechanism should take care of the case.

Change-Id: I6871a28745111b1878a606372e6edd664f0ea10c
"}, {'created': '2013-01-29 05:09:03.000000000', 'message': "Allow volume back-end to report 'infinite' or 'unknown' as capacity

For some reason, some volume back-ends cannot report actual capacity
that is available or even total capacity (e.g. thin-provisioning),
Cinder should allow such capability report and make placement/schedule
decision based on these status.

In particular, we agree to use 'infinite' to mark unlimited space and
'unknown' to mark unknown/unclear space.  Host manager and CapacityFilter
are updated accordingly to allow such capacity.  For those back-ends
report 'infinite' or 'unknown' capacity, CapacityFilter will let them
pass to give them a chance to try.  Even if failure happened, the retry
mechanism should take care of the case.

Change-Id: I6871a28745111b1878a606372e6edd664f0ea10c
"}]
commit_message:
Allow volume back-end to report 'infinite' or 'unknown' as capacity

For some reason, some volume back-ends cannot report actual capacity
that is available or even total capacity (e.g. thin-provisioning),
Cinder should allow such capability report and make placement/schedule
decision based on these status.

In particular, we agree to use 'infinite' to mark unlimited space and
'unknown' to mark unknown/unclear space.  Host manager and CapacityFilter
are updated accordingly to allow such capacity.  For those back-ends
report 'infinite' or 'unknown' capacity, CapacityFilter will let them
pass to give them a chance to try.  Even if failure happened, the retry
mechanism should take care of the case.

Change-Id: I6871a28745111b1878a606372e6edd664f0ea10c

failureException type logic from the code.

commit_message:
Cleanup based on pyflakes.

pyflakes itself can't be used in any automated gating way, because there are
two sets of false errors it raises. However, as an exercise, cleaning up the
'valid' ones uncovered three actual bugs. The other changes (mostly unused
variables) are included here for fun.

Command run: pyflakes swift | grep -v "undefined name '_'"

Change-Id: I18696bf047dedad1a9fdbde3463e214fba95f7c6

'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-30 09:57:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2013-01-30 10:38:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm always trying to avoid new config variables.

I thought we might infer the current compressed state of the image we're reading and if that's compressed then used compressed output. However compression seems to be an internal only flag and not exposed through qemu-img info.

Perhaps we could have a more general variable like libvirt_compress_images to enable the use of compression, in more places like driver.finish_migration(), driver.migrate_disk_and_power_off() ?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-30 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The problem I see with infering compression is that this makes your host performance / utilization dependant on how users create their qcow2 images in the first place. It would probably be reasonable, only if glance was enforcing a compression setting during upload & re-encoding user provided images accordingly. In other words, if we want to avoid a config param in Nova, we'd probably want to add one in Glance & some code there."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Add support for compressing qcow2 snapshots

Fixes bug 1109923

Adds a new configuration option:
    libvirt_snapshot_compression=False (Default)

When set to True and the snapshot output format is qcow2, we pass
the -c option into qemu-img, which enables compression. This patch
also refactors the extract_image function to make construction of
the whole qemu-img command more dynamic.

Change-Id: I7a7ebcf41a91a8a9cb14be79e9bb79c22acb136e
Flags: DocImpact

This patch updates the network API to be able to use the conductor API
to be able to update the instance info cache.

A previous commit, 5731852f91c32fe09db541888d3fee9e3139fc43, updated
the compute manager to use this method from conductor when getting
network info.  This patch builds on that by moving the conductor usage
down to the network API and using it in more places.  Specifically, the
network API calls used by the compute manager that use the refresh_cache
decorator were updated.

The refresh_cache decorator now checks for a conductor_api kwarg and

commit_message:
Use conductor for instance_info_cache_update.

This patch updates the network API to be able to use the conductor API
to be able to update the instance info cache.

A previous commit, 5731852f91c32fe09db541888d3fee9e3139fc43, updated
the compute manager to use this method from conductor when getting
network info.  This patch builds on that by moving the conductor usage
down to the network API and using it in more places.  Specifically, the
network API calls used by the compute manager that use the refresh_cache
decorator were updated.

The refresh_cache decorator now checks for a conductor_api kwarg and
will use the conductor to update the cache if it's not there.  Otherwise
it goes back to default behavior of using the db directly.

Change-Id: Ib5e17f5f8fb4ee14e3ed305057d18d40f2e905e5
